revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
'''Alexander Donald Cameron''' (21 July 1873 – 23 January 1957) was a trader of [[Scottish people|Scottish]] descent who founded the [[Tonga Ma'a Tonga Kautaha]] (Tonga for Tongans Cooperative) in [[Tonga]] in 1909 to prevent the commercial exploitation of Tongan [[copra]] growers by [[Ethnic groups in Europe|European]] middlemen who controlled the market.
==Family and early life== Cameron, born in [[Tottenham]], [[England]], was the second of eight children of a Scottish headmaster.<ref>{{cite census | title = Census | year =1881 | location =Tottenham, Middlesex, England | roll =RG11 | page =1381 }}</ref> Following an unsuccessful career in a tea company, first in [[London]] and then in [[Ceylon]], [[India]] and [[Australia]], he arrived in Tonga in 1901 as the branch manager of [[Sydney]]-based trading firm [[Burns Philp]].<ref name=Lavaka>{{cite journal |last=Lavaka |first=Penny |year=1981 |title=The Tonga Ma‘a Tonga Kautaha: A Watershed in British-Tongan Relations |journal=Pacific Studies |volume=4 |issue=2, Spring 1981 |publisher=Institute for Polynesian Studies |url=https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/PacificStudies/article/viewFile/9209/8858 |access-date=2016-07-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304201416/https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/PacificStudies/article/viewFile/9209/8858 |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Here, too, he was unsuccessful, soon being dismissed from the business, following which he took to drink and banished himself to a distant island for fifteen months to recuperate.<ref name="Lavaka" /> In 1903 he married Clara Elizabeth (Kelela) Cocker,<ref>"Australia Marriages, 1810-1980," database, FamilySearch(https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:XTZC-PY4 : 12 December 2014), Alexander Donald Cameron and Clara Elizabeth Cocker, 27 Mar 1903; citing Launceston, Tasmania, Australia, reference 13; FHL microfilm 992,697.</ref> daughter of a European trader and a Tongan woman and granddaughter of Joshua Cocker, who had been [[United Kingdom|British]] Vice-[[Consul]] of Tonga from May 1862 to August 1866. For a while he worked a commercial banana plantation on land belonging to his wife's family, but bankruptcy eventually brought an end to this enterprise.
==Tonga Ma'a Tonga Kautaha== In 1909 Cameron devised the idea of a Tongan [[cooperative]] of copra growers called Tonga Ma'a Tonga Kautaha and with the support of a noble titleholder, Vaea of Hauma,<ref name=Grijp>{{cite book |last=van der Grijp |first=Paul |date=2014 |title=Manifestations of Mana: Political Power and Divine Inspiration in Polynesia |url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=1Q2SAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Manifestations+of+mana&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Manifestations%20of%20mana&f=false |location= |publisher=LIT Verlag Münster |page=242 |isbn=978-3-643-90496-6}}</ref> organised meetings in villages around [[Tongatapu]], the main island in the Kingdom of Tonga, to explain the concept, that in addition to providing growers with a more lucrative alternative to the European trader cartel for the export of their produce it would also serve as a vehicle for Tongan aspirations and the acquisition of business skills of non-indigenous residents.
Prior to the formation of Tonga Ma'a Tonga Kautaha, exporting of Tonga's copra crop had been under the control of European traders who benefited greatly from exceedingly high profit margins. They also controlled imports, often charging Tongans twice the price that they charged European residents.<ref name="Lavaka" />
The Kautaha opened in May 1909 with 1,300 members and by later that year had 3,280 from all three main islands in the kingdom - Tongatapu, Vava’u and Ha’apai - including many of Tonga's most influential nobles and chiefs. According to Mateialona, the [[Premier]] of Tonga at that time, Cameron was spoken of generally among Kautaha members as “an angel descended from Heaven to deliver them from the bondage of the White traders.”<ref name="Lavaka" />
Cameron's motivation was not solely benevolent. He earned a modest commission on sales which due to the large quantities of produce exported earned him between £1,300 to £1,500 during the first year of operation, contrasting starkly with his previous status as a bankrupt.
The cooperative drew the ire of the islands' European traders, who through the support of the local British Agent caused the collective to be investigated by the Auditor General and a report of the findings presented to its members, leading to its closure by Tonga's Premier on grounds of financial irregularities, for which Cameron was subsequently charged. On appeal, Cameron was acquitted of any wrongdoing and attempted to reform the collective, which was not successful and closed in about 1916, after which he relocated to Australia.
Cameron's venture had the unanticipated outcome of enhancing the nation's autonomy and significantly strengthening the authority of its [[monarch]], [[George Tupou II|King George Tupou II]], following Cameron's acquittal because of the heavy-handedness of William Telfer Campbell, the British Agent, regarding the investigation and in his dealings with the monarch, which led to a redefining of the role of his office in relation to advice given to the monarch.<ref name="Lavaka" /><ref name="Grijp" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cameron, Alexander}}
[[Category:1873 births]] [[Category:1957 deaths]] [[Category:British businesspeople]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = | name = Anthony Housefather | honorific-suffix ={{post-nominals|country=CAN|MP|size=100%}} | image =Anthony campaign shot december 2014.jpg | parliament = Canadian | office1 = Chairman of the [[Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights|Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights]] | term_start1 = February 16, 2016 | term_end1 = | predecessor1 = [[Mike Wallace (politician)|Mike Wallace]] | successor1 = | riding2 = [[Mount Royal (electoral district)|Mount Royal]] | term_start2 = November 4, 2015 | term_end2 = | predecessor2 = [[Irwin Cotler]] | office3 = Mayor of [[Côte Saint-Luc]] | term_start3 = November 7, 2005 | term_end3 = November 4, 2015 | predecessor3 = [[Robert Libman]] | successor3 = Mitchell Brownstein | office4 = [[Montreal City Council|Councillor]] for the Borough of [[Côte-Saint-Luc–Hampstead–Montreal West]] | term_start4 = 2001 | term_end4 = 2005 | office5 = President of [[Alliance Quebec]] | predecessor5 = [[William Johnson (author)|William Johnson]] | successor5 = [[Brent Tyler]] | term_start5 = 2000 | term_end5 = 2001 | office6 = Town Councillor in [[Hampstead, Quebec|Hampstead]] | term_start6 = 1994 | term_end6 = 2001 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|1|25}} | birth_place = [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada | party = [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] | alma_mater = [[McGill University]]
[[Concordia University (Montreal)|Concordia University]] | occupation = | profession = | website = [http://ahousefather.liberal.ca/ Liberal Party of Canada ] }} '''Anthony Housefather''' {{post-nominals|country=CAN|MP}} (born January 25, 1973) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[Member of Parliament (Canada)|Member of Parliament]] representing the [[Electoral district (Canada)|riding]] of [[Mount Royal (electoral district)|Mount Royal]] on the island of [[Montreal]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishtribune.ca/TribuneV2/index.php/201007143210/Saluting-human-rights-activists-for-oppressed-Jews-in-foreign-lands.html|title=Saluting human rights activists for oppressed Jews in foreign lands|last=Cohen|first=Mike|date=July 14, 2010|work=[[The Jewish Tribune (Canada)|Jewish Tribune]]|accessdate=November 13, 2010}} He is the Chairman of the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]] [[Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights|Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights.]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Committees/en/JUST/Members|title=JUST - Members|website=www.parl.gc.ca|access-date=2016-07-06}} He was first elected to office in 1994 as a municipal councillor in the Town of [[Hampstead, Quebec|Hampstead]]. When Hampstead and all the other cities on the Montreal island were forced to merge into the City of Montreal by the [[Parti Québécois|Parti Quebecois]] government in 2001, he was elected as a municipal councilor in the borough of Côte-Saint-Luc-Hampstead-Montreal West. Housefather then led the demerger movement in his borough. Following the successful demerger of all three municipalities as determined in a referendum on June 20, 2004, he was elected Mayor of the City of [[Côte-Saint-Luc]], and served from 2005 until 2015, when he resigned following his election to Parliament.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/formermayors|title=Former mayors and councillors {{!}} Côte Saint Luc, Quebec, Canada|website=www.cotesaintluc.org|access-date=2016-07-06}} Housefather was first elected to Parliament in the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|Canadian federal election of October 2015]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/election-2015-mount-royal-libman-housefather-israel-1.3278806|title=Liberal Anthony Housefather dashes Conservatives' best hope for a Montreal seat|access-date=2016-07-06}} On February 16, 2016, Housefather was unanimously elected Chairman of the House of Commons Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights. Housefather holds two law degrees (B.C.L. and LL.B.) from [[McGill University]], and an MBA from [[Concordia University]]'s [[John Molson School of Business]]. Before his election to federal office, he served as Executive Vice President, Corporate Affairs and General Counsel, at [[Dialogic Corporation]], a multinational technology company.{{cite web|url=http://www.dialogic.com/en/company/executive-team/anthony-housefather.aspx|title=Anthony Housefather|work=dialogic.com}} Housefather was a nationally ranked athlete as a student. He returned to competitive swimming in 2010, and earned seven medals (two silver, and five bronze) in swimming masters events at the [[2013 Maccabiah Games]] in [[Israel]], and five at the [[2017 Maccabiah Games]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/pr20130806a|title=Côte Saint-Luc swimmers shine at Maccabiah Games: Mayor Housefather wins seven medals {{!}} Côte Saint Luc, Quebec, Canada|website=www.cotesaintluc.org|access-date=2016-07-06}}[http://www.cjnews.com/news/canada/six-jewish-mps-head-to-ottawa Here are the six Jewish MP's headed to Ottawa] ==Early life== Housefather was born in [[Montreal]], Canada, and is Jewish.[https://www.maccabicanada.com/anthony-housefather-mp-maccabean-parliament/ Anthony Housefather, MP: The Maccabean of Parliament | Maccabi Canada] His grandparents were all born in Montreal. He went to [[Herzliah High School]], and is fluent in Hebrew. He earned two law degrees (B.C.L. and LL.B.) from [[McGill University]], and an MBA from [[Concordia University]]'s [[John Molson School of Business]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=47405431&privcapId=2031090|title=Anthony Housefather: Executive Profile & Biography - Businessweek|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-07-06}} == Liberal Party Vice President, and Hampstead Town Councillor (1991-2001)== Housefather became active in the [[Mount Royal]] Liberal Association as a teenager. He was elected as Policy Vice President of the [[Young Liberals of Canada]]'s Quebec wing in 1991, and in 1992 was elected to the Liberal Party's national executive as Policy Vice President of the Young Liberals of Canada. In that role he worked on the platform committee for the development of the Red Book, the Liberal Party platform in the 1993 campaign. When his term on the national executive ended, Housefather ran for [[Hampstead]] Town Council and was elected in 1994, defeating two other candidates.{{Cite web|url=http://magazine.concordia.ca/2008/fall/features/housefather.shtml|title=Improving society — Concordia University Magazine Features|website=magazine.concordia.ca|access-date=2016-07-06}} He was re-elected in 1998, and served in this capacity until 2001, when the Quebec government forced all cities and towns on the Island of [[Montreal]] to [[Montreal Merger|merge]].{{cite news|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/housefather-elected-liberal-candidate-in-mount-royal-riding|title=Montreal Gazette}} === Alliance Quebec President=== Housefather was involved in organizations working on behalf of Quebec's English-speaking minority in the 1990s. In addition to being involved with [[Federation CJA]]'s Pro Montreal at its inception, he was also involved in the creation of Youth Employment Services. Both of these groups concentrated on keeping the youth of the English-speaking community in Quebec by helping them find jobs. He also served on the Board of Directors, and then as the Executive, of [[Alliance Quebec]].{{Cite web|url=http://vigile.quebec/archives/AQ/index.html|title=Alliance-Québec|website=vigile.quebec|access-date=2016-07-06}} Housefather was elected President of Alliance Quebec in 2000 and served until 2001, when he ran for office in the new mega-city of Montreal following the forced mergers. == Councillor in the Mega-City, and Leader of the De-merger Movement (2001-05)== Housefather, together with the vast majority of Mayors and Councillors of suburban municipalities, opposed the forced mergers which created the mega-city of Montreal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/quebecers-eager-to-break-up-mega-cities-in-june-referendums-1.478028|title=Quebecers eager to break up mega-cities in June referendums|access-date=2016-07-06}} When the [[Quebec Court of Appeal]]s ruled that the cities had no constitutional protection against the forced mergers, Housefather joined many suburban mayors and councillors who ran for election in the mega-city of Montreal, campaigning on the promise to support demerger if a new government ever permitted it. In the 2001 election, he was elected as a Councillor for the Borough of [[Côte-Saint-Luc]]–Hampstead–[[Montreal West]], receiving approximately 70% of the vote.{{Cite web|url=https://gjnashen.wordpress.com/2009/09/05/housefather-nashen-brownstein-and-kovac-announce-re-election-bid-for-2009/|title=Housefather, Nashen, Brownstein and Kovac Announce Re-Election Bid for 2009|date=2009-09-06|website=Nashen Notes|access-date=2016-07-06}} When the [[Quebec Liberal Party]] was elected in 2003, it set in motion a process that permitted cities and towns to de-merge from the mega-city. Housefather was alone amongst the three elected Councillors in Côte Saint-Luc-Hampstead-Montreal West to support the demerger of the three communities. In 2004, he served as co-chair of the demerger committee of the Côte-Saint-Luc along with former City Councillors Mitchell Brownstein, Ruth Kovac, and Glenn J. Nashen. He was also a member of the Hampstead Demerger Committee and the Montreal West Demerger Committee. On June 20, 2004, all three communities voted to demerge from Montreal, with the Yes vote representing 91% of the votes cast in Hampstead, 87% of the votes cast in Côte Saint-Luc, and 84% of the votes cast in Montreal West.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/demerger-vote-will-change-map-of-quebec-1.472893|title=Demerger vote will change map of Quebec|access-date=2016-07-06}} Thus, all three municipalities were reconstituted within their former borders as of January 1, 2006, with elections scheduled for November 2005. == Mayor of Côte Saint-Luc (2005-15)== On November 7, 2005, Housefather was elected Mayor of the reconstituted City of Côte-Saint-Luc, winning election with 75% of the vote while former Mayor [[Bernard Lang]] received 14% of the vote, and a third opponent receiving 10% of the vote. Housefather was a very popular and well-respected Mayor, and was re-elected by acclamation to a second term as Mayor of Côte-Saint-Luc on October 2, 2009, in advance of a November 1, 2009, vote.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/ElectionResults|title=Municipal Election Results {{!}} Côte Saint Luc, Quebec, Canada|website=www.cotesaintluc.org|access-date=2016-07-06}} He was acclaimed again on October 4, 2013, in advance of a November 4, 2013, vote.{{Cite web|url=http://montreal.ctvnews.ca/westmount-ddo-csl-mayors-acclaimed-1.1485242|title=Westmount, DDO, CSL mayors acclaimed|access-date=2016-07-06}} As Mayor, Housefather was very involved in provincial as well as local issues. He led the fight by bilingual municipalities against the [[Parti Quebecois]]' government's Bill 14, which amongst other things would have deprived many Quebec municipalities of bilingual status. He drafted and presented a brief with [[Town of Mount Royal]] Mayor [[Philippe Roy]] at the [[National Assembly of Quebec]] on Bill 14 on March 11, 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/files/u1/council_minutes/2013/CSL_Council_Minutes_20130311_EN.pdf|title=MINUTES OF THE REGULAR MEETING OF THE CITY COUNCIL HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 11, 2013, AT 5801 CAVENDISH BOULEVARD, CÔTE SAINT-LUC, AT 8:00 P.M.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} He also held a rally at Côte Saint-Luc City Hall for religious tolerance, and led in the opposition to the PQ's Charter of Values which sought to bar any employee from wearing religious gear in schools, hospitals, municipalities and provincial government.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/news?page=7|title=News and announcements {{!}} Côte Saint Luc, Quebec, Canada|website=www.cotesaintluc.org|access-date=2016-07-06}} Both of these bills were dropped. During the years when Côte Saint-Luc was in Montreal, a collective agreement was signed by the mega-city giving firefighters a monopoly on first response, which put Côte Saint-Luc's much valued Emergency Measures Service at risk of disappearing. With the help of [[D'Arcy-McGee]] MNA [[Lawrence Bergman]], Housefather was able to convince the Quebec Government to add a provision to Bill 22 to allow Côte Saint-Luc to operate its [[first responder|first-responder]] service permanently.{{Cite web|url=https://gjnashen.wordpress.com/tag/bill-22/|title=Bill 22 {{!}} Nashen Notes|website=gjnashen.wordpress.com|access-date=2016-07-06}} Housefather also was able to work with other mayors to save a local police station and to convince the Agglomeration of Montreal to adopt a resolution allocating $44 million for the Cavendish extension. He also worked with Councillor Dida Berku and environmental groups to help preserve the Meadowbrook Golf Vourse as a [[Urban open space|green space]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/pr20120601a|title=Councillor Berku receives Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal {{!}} Côte Saint Luc, Quebec, Canada|website=www.cotesaintluc.org|access-date=2016-07-06}} At a local level, Housefather and his council were viewed as one of the most innovative councils in Quebec. Côte Saint-Luc built an $18 million Aquatic and Community Centre on time and under budget, and developed one of Montreal's leading aquatics programs.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/pr20110404|title=Côte Saint-Luc hires Martin Levine as Aquatics Manager and Head Coach {{!}} Côte Saint Luc, Quebec, Canada|website=www.cotesaintluc.org|access-date=2016-07-06}} Under the Housefather administration, Côte Saint-Luc was the first city on the island of Montreal to launch a composting program for all single-family homes, the first to launch a food policy, and launched a farmer's market and community gardens.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/pr20130418a|title=Côte Saint-Luc launches first-in-Quebec urban agriculture initiative {{!}} Côte Saint Luc, Quebec, Canada|website=www.cotesaintluc.org|access-date=2016-07-06}} The median age of residents of the City of Côte Saint-Luc fell by seven years over Housefather's tenure as Mayor, as the community expanded high-quality programs for children and young adults and sponsored townhouses and other housing favourable to young families.{{Cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2011/dp-pd/prof/details/page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=2466058&Geo2=CD&Code2=2466&Data=Count&SearchText=cote&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=All&Custom=&TABID=1%20|title=Census Profile |last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} But at the same time a permanent home was found for the City's seniors clubs and legion. === Island-wide roles === In addition to his duties within local government, between 2006 and 2015 Housefather also served as the Secretary of the Association of Suburban Municipalities (ASM), which represents the 15 demerged cities and towns on the Island of Montreal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cotesaintluc.org/files/u1/council_minutes/2014/CSL_council_minutes_20140811.pdf|title=MINUTES OF THE REGULAR MEETING OF THE CITY COUNCIL HELD ON MONDAY, AUGUST 11, 2014, AT 5801 CAVENDISH BOULEVARD, CÔTE SAINT-LUC, AT 8:00 P.M.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Housefather was also a member of the island-wide Montreal [[Urban agglomeration of Montreal|agglomeration council]] and the [[Urban agglomerations in Quebec|agglomeration]]'s Public Security Commission. ==Member of Parliament (2015-present)== ===Federal election (2015)=== When [[Liberal Party of Canada]] [[Member of Parliament (Canada)|MP]] [[Irwin Cotler]] announced he would not run in the [[42nd Canadian federal election|2015 federal election]] in the [[Mount Royal (electoral district)|Mount Royal riding]], Housefather was supported by most of the elected officials in the riding when he declared his intention to run.{{Cite web|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/housefather-elected-liberal-candidate-in-mount-royal-riding|title=Housefather elected Liberal candidate in Mount Royal riding|date=2014-12-01|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-06}} His Liberal nomination opponent was communications strategist Jonathan Goldbloom. Housefather said his 20 successful years in municipal politics were excellent preparation for the role of MP. Over the course of the year he signed up over 3,000 residents of the riding to support him at the nominating meeting.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cjnews.com/news/canada/housefather-wins-mount-royal-liberal-nomination|title=Housefather wins Mount Royal Liberal nomination - The Canadian Jewish News|last=Reporter|first=Janice Arnold, Staff|date=2014-12-01|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-06}} The Mount Royal nomination meeting took place on November 30, 2014. With 1,948 ballots cast, Housefather was declared the winner and the official Liberal Party candidate for the 2015 federal election. The Conservative Party targeted Mount Royal in the 2015 election, with Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] launching his party's campaign in Mount Royal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/5-reasons-stephen-harper-started-his-campaign-in-mont-royal-1.3175560|title=5 reasons Harper started his campaign in Montreal's Mont-Royal|access-date=2016-07-06}} Housefather ran a vigorous door-to-door campaign, and managed to assemble support from a wide variety of communities within the riding as well as the majority of elected officials at the municipal and [[school board]] election. Housefather and the [[New Democratic Party|NDP]] candidate debated four times in the riding, with the Conservative candidate participating in two of the debates and refusing two. However, Housefather debated against Conservative candidate [[Robert Libman]] on [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] and [[CKZW|Radio Shalom]], and all three candidates debated on [[CJAD]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2015/09/29/mount-royal-anthony-housefather-robert-libman_n_8215344.html|title=Tory Vows To Take Liberal Stronghold Where Israel Remains A Key Issue|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-07-06}} Following the campaign, Housefather was elected as the Member of Parliament for Mount Royal on October 19, 2015, with 50.4% of the vote, and tripling the Liberal majority from the 2011 election.{{Cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2272005/liberal-anthony-housefather-elected-in-mount-royal/|title=Liberal Anthony Housefather elected in Mount Royal|last=Lau|first=Rachel|access-date=2016-07-06}} Housefather was profiled as one of 10 rookie MPs to watch in the new parliament.{{Cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/nearly-200-rookie-mps-were-elected-in-election-2015-heres-who-to-watch|title=Nearly 200 rookie MPs were elected on Monday. Here's who to watch|access-date=2016-07-06}} === On Parliament Hill === On February 16, 2016, he was elected as Chairman the [[Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights|Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights]].{{Cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2521032/anthony-housefather-elected-chair-of-standing-committee-on-justice-and-human-rights/|title=Anthony Housefather elected chair of Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights|last=Lau|first=Rachel|access-date=2016-07-06}} Later that month, Housefather earned international media attention for a speech he delivered in support of an anti-[[Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions]] (BDS) motion put forward in the House of Commons.{{Citation|last=Anthony Housefather|title=Anthony Housefather Supports Anti-BDS Motion in the House of Commons|date=2016-02-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q3O6O0KhqnY|accessdate=2016-06-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.israellycool.com/2016/02/21/must-watch-canadian-parliamentarian-anthony-housefathers-masterful-ripping-of-bds/|title=MUST WATCH: Canadian Parliamentarian Anthony Housefather's Masterful Ripping Of BDS|last=Dave|first=Aussie|date=2016-02-21|website=Israellycool|access-date=2016-07-06}}{{Citation|last=Anthony Housefather|title=Anthony Housefather Supports Anti-BDS Motion in the House of Commons|date=2016-02-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q3O6O0KhqnY|accessdate=2016-07-06}} The motion urged the government to reject the goals of the BDS movement. while calling on the government to "condemn any and all attempts by Canadian organizations, groups or individuals to promote [it] both here at home and abroad." Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] and most other Liberals voted in favour of the motion, which passed 229-51.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cjnews.com/news/canada/anti-bds-motion-backed-by-liberals-tories-in-parliament|title=Anti-BDS motion backed by Liberals, Tories|last=Reporter|first=Paul Lungen, Staff|date=2016-02-19|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-06}} On March 25, 2015, Housefather echoed Foreign Minister [[Stéphane Dion]]`s criticism of the [[UN Human Rights Council]]`s decision to appoint [[University of Western Ontario]] law professor Michael Lynk as its [[United Nations special rapporteur|Special Rapporteur]] on human rights in Palestine.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ahousefather/status/713139254814195712|title=Anthony Housefather on Twitter|access-date=2016-07-06}} This followed criticism from Jewish groups including the [[Centre for Israel and Jewish Affairs]], which accused Lynk of bias against Israel. Housefather received considerable acclaim for his chairing of the Standing Committee on Justice and Human Rights, with committee members from all parties praising his handling of the difficult committee hearings on the [[assisted dying]] bill C-14.{{Cite web|url=https://www.hilltimes.com/2016/04/25/committee-chair-vows-not-to-impose-personal-views-in-handling-of-assisted-dying-law/59544|title=The Hill Times|website=www.hilltimes.com|access-date=2016-07-06}} As of May 20, 2016, no rookie Liberal MP had spoken more in the House of Commons than Housefather.{{Cite web|url=http://site.macleans.ca/interactives/ic2/|title=Figures of Speech|access-date=2016-06-28}} === In the riding === In February 2016, Housefather relayed the support of the constituents in his [[Electoral district (Canada)|riding]] for the Cavendish Boulevard extension between Côte St. Luc and [[Saint-Laurent, Quebec|St. Laurent]] in the House of Commons.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thesuburban.com/news/city_news/housefather-advocates-for-cavendish-link-in-commons/article_614232e0-a345-5ee8-92ec-7f02da2f6a4f.html|title=Housefather advocates for Cavendish link in Commons|last=Suburban|first=Joel Goldenberg The|access-date=2016-07-06}} In May 2016, Quebec Liberals adopted a resolution calling for the Cavendish extension to be realized.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thesuburban.com/news/city_news/quebec-liberals-call-for-cavendish-extension/article_8f344981-9688-502d-a880-54f2cc4ae664.html|title=Quebec Liberals call for Cavendish extension|last=Suburban|first=Joel Goldenberg The|access-date=2016-07-06}} In April 2016, Housefather and [[Minister of Families, Children and Social Development]] [[Jean-Yves Duclos]] announced the federal government would provide $390,913 over a period of three years for a new drop-in centre, which provides relief for caregivers of seniors, at the Côte St. Luc Aquatic and Community Centre as part of the New Horizons for Seniors Program.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thesuburban.com/news/city_news/feds-announce-funding-for-new-csl-based-seniors-drop-in/article_f1572023-a52f-592c-8576-5c54910d0340.html|title=Feds announce funding for new CSL-based seniors drop-in centre|last=Suburban|first=Joel Goldenberg The|access-date=2016-07-06}} In total $1.1 million was received for senior programs assisting caregivers in the riding. In May, Housefather announced that over 270 summer jobs had been created for students in the riding, with more than double the number of jobs created than in 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thesuburban.com/news/city_news/federal-program-provides-summer-jobs-in-mount-royal/article_485b6cca-a269-5e09-9eab-b0fa39459b1a.html|title=Federal program provides 270 summer jobs in Mount Royal|last=Suburban|first=Joel Goldenberg The|access-date=2016-07-06}} In the election campaign, Housefather had promised to hold quarterly [[town hall meeting]]s in the riding to give constituents a report on what is happening in Ottawa and in the riding and to take questions as he did as Mayor. The first town hall meeting was held in [[Hampstead]] in January and the second was held in the Town of Mount Royal in April.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hampstead.qc.ca/inside_town_hall/news/pre_budget_consultation_meeting|title=Town of Hampstead|website=www.hampstead.qc.ca|access-date=2016-07-06}} The meetings are called Anthony's Assemblies. === In the media === Housefather has written several opinion pieces for Canadian newspapers, and has been interviewed on local and national news networks, sharing his views on subjects including his experience as a member of parliament, [[minority language]] issues, and his support of more permissive [[surrogacy]] laws in Canada.{{Cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/full-comment/anthony-housefather-a-week-in-the-life-of-a-rookie-mp|title=Anthony Housefather: A week in the life of a rookie MP|access-date=2016-07-06}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/opinion/commentary/2016/04/20/paying-for-sperm-should-not-be-illegal.html|title=Paying for sperm should not be illegal {{!}} Toronto Star|website=thestar.com|access-date=2016-07-06}}{{Cite web|url=http://montrealgazette.com/opinion/columnists/opinion-lets-change-laws-that-prevent-some-canadians-from-becoming-parents|title=Opinion: Let's change laws that prevent some Canadians from becoming parents|date=2016-03-08|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-06}} == Athletics == Housefather was a competitive swimmer in his teens, and then a competitive [[water polo]] player. He started competitive swimming again in 2010. In July and August 2013, Housefather won seven medals in the Masters category in swimming at the [[2013 Maccabiah Games]] in [[Israel]]. He won five medals in a number of Masters (35+) swimming events at the [[2017 Maccabiah Games]].[http://www.cjnews.com/culture/sports/canada-wraps-maccabiah-games-50-medals Canada wraps up Maccabiah games with 50 medals - The Canadian Jewish News] Housefather swims on the Parliamentary Swim Team, and runs with the running group on the Hill, which, as part of a wider fitness initiative, aims to keep members of Parliament physically active while promoting health and physical fitness.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/parliamentary-swim-team-1.3424254|title=Everyone in the pool: MPs from 4 parties bring different strokes to Hill swim team|access-date=2016-07-06}} He advocates for athletics and physical fitness as a Member of Parliament, serving as the Liberal Party lead on the Parliamentary fitness initiative started by former MP [[John Weston (politician)|John Weston]]. ==Electoral record== {{Canadian election result/top|CA|2015|percent=yes|change=yes|expenditures=yes}} {{CANelec|CA|Liberal|Anthony Housefather|24,187|50.34|+8.93|–}} {{CANelec|CA|Conservative|[[Robert Libman]]|18,201|37.88|+2.27|–}} {{CANelec|CA|NDP|Mario Jacinto Rimbao|3,884|8.08|-9.77|–}} {{CANelec|CA|BQ|Jade Bossé Bélanger|908|1.90|-1.01|–}} {{CANelec|CA|Green|Timothy Landry|747|1.55|-0.20|–}} {{CANelec|CA|Marxist-Leninist|Diane Johnston|124|0.26|-0.02|–}} {{Canadian election result/total|Total valid votes/Expense limit|48,051|100.00|–|$207,183.11}} {{Canadian election result/total|Total rejected ballots|425|0.88|–|–}} {{Canadian election result/total|Turnout|48,476|65.18|+7.54|–}} {{Canadian election result/total|Eligible voters|74,374|–|–|–}} {{CANelec/source|Source: [[Elections Canada]][http://enr.elections.ca/ElectoralDistricts.aspx?lang=e Elections Canada – Election Results, 22 October 2015][http://www.elections.ca/content2.aspx?section=can&dir=cand/canlim&document=index&lang=e Elections Canada – Preliminary Election Expenses Limits for Candidates] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150815061116/http://www.elections.ca/content2.aspx?section=can&dir=cand%2Fcanlim&document=index&lang=e |date=August 15, 2015 }}}} {{Infobox organization |name = Arab Organization for Industrialization |image = |image_border = |size = 150 |alt = |caption = |abbreviation = AOI |motto = |formation = 1975 |extinction = |type = [[State-owned company]] |status = |purpose = [[Defence industry]] |headquarters = |location = [[Cairo, Egypt]] |region_served = [[Arab World|Arab world]] |membership = [[Egypt]]
[[Qatar]] (until 1993)
[[Saudi Arabia]] (until 1993)
[[United Arab Emirates]] |language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] |leader_title = Chairman |leader_name = [[Abd El Aziz Seif-Eldeen]] |main_organ = Supreme Committee |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = ~16,000 |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [https://www.aoi.org.eg www.aoi.org.eg] |remarks = }} '''''The Arab Organization for Industrialization''''' (AOI) (''{{lang-ar|الهيئة العربية للتصنيع}}'') is an [[Egypt]]-based [[Military of the Arab League|Arab military]] organization established in 1975 by Egypt, The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, The [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE) and Qatar state to supervise the collective development of the Arab [[defence industry|defense industry]]. Following a gradual deterioration in relations between the AOI member-states, Egypt became sole owner of AOI in 1993. As well as meeting the requirements of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]], AOI directs spare capacity to civilian programmed, including civilian transport and [[sanitation]] equipment, AOI has stated its intention of entering the [[wind power]] sector.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Future products | work = Arab Organization for Industrialization | publisher = Arab Organization for Industrialization | date = | url = http://www.aoi.com.eg/aoieng/future_products/future_products.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2010-08-06}} Initially an institution of [[Pan-Arabism]], Saudi Arabia and the [[United Arab Emirates]] returned their shares in AOI, valued at US$1.8 billion, to [[Egypt]] in 1993, leaving AOI wholly owned by the Egypt. AOI has approximately 16,000 employees, out of which 1,250 are engineers. AOI fully owns 12 factories and shares in 1 joint-ventures, besides the Arab Institute for Development Technology. ==History== {{Life in the Arab League}} AOI was established by its four member-states - Egypt, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the UAE - in response to the threat posed by the advanced [[Military equipment of Israel|Israeli defence industry]]. The initial [[Market capitalization|capitalisation]] of AOI was USD 1 billion, contributed in equal part by the four member-states, although with the understanding AOI would be based in Egypt.Shidlo 1993: 241 ===Westland Helicopters v. Arab Organisation for Industrialization=== In 1978, AOI and [[Westland Helicopters]], a British [[aerospace]] company, established the ''[[Arab British Helicopter Company]]'' as a joint venture, but a year later AOI announced the company's [[liquidation]]. In ensuing [[arbitration]], the [[International Chamber of Commerce]] made an [[Arbitration award|award]], on grounds of breach of the principles of [[natural law]] and [[good faith]], in favour of Westland Helicopters and against AOI's four member-states.{{Cite court |litigants = Westland Helicopters Ltd v. Arab Organization for Industrialization, United Arab Emirates, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, State of Qatar, Arab Republic of Egypt and Arab British Helicopter Company |vol = 80 |reporter = ILR |opinion = 600 |pinpoint = 613 |court = |date = 1984-03-05 |url= }} This award was later annulled by the Court of Justice of [[Geneva]],{{Cite court |litigants = Arab Organization for Industrialization and others v. Westland Helicopters Ltd and others |vol = 80 |reporter = ILR |opinion = 622 |pinpoint = |court = |date = 1987-10-23 |url= }} which annulment was upheld by the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland|Federal Supreme Court]], on grounds that the arbitrators had jurisdiction over AOI but not over the organisation's member-states.{{Cite court |litigants = Arab Organization for Industrialization and others v. Westland Helicopters Ltd |vol = 80 |reporter = ILR |opinion = 652 |pinpoint = |court = [[Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland|Federal Supreme Court]] (First Civil Court) |date = 1988-07-19 |url= }} Klabbers 2002: 312 ===Egyptian isolation=== Following the signing of the [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty|Egypt-Israeli peace treaty]] (1979), Egypt had its membership to the [[Arab League]] suspended and a policy of economic isolation implemented against it. It was in this atmosphere that the three AOI member-states other than Egypt - Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the UAE - withdrew from the AOI, causing its collapse.German and Taylor 2004: 322 In 1983, the Egyptian [[Chief of staff|chief-of-staff]] restated his interest in the joint manufacture of weapons, but it was only after the [[1987 Arab League summit]] in [[Amman]], Jordan, when the Arab League re-admitted Egypt and the other Arab states normalised relations with Egypt, that the possibility of renewed co-operation among the AOI member-states seemed possible.German and Taylor 2004: 329 The UAE seemed similarly eager to reinvigorate the AOI:Nolan 1992: 72 in 1988, Egypt and the UAE held talks with Qatar about its re-entry into the AOI, at which an agreement for closer co-operation between Egypt and Qatar in the fields of culture and communication was signed.Rabi 1990: 458 ==Organization== AOI is one of the largest [[Economy of Egypt#Industrial sector|industrial organisations in Egypt]] with significant international relationships both in the [[Defence industry|defence]] and civilian transport sectors. The AOI is wholly [[State ownership|state-owned]] by Egypt and administered by a ''Supreme Committee'', the chairman of which is the [[President of Egypt|Egyptian president]] and which includes several [[Cabinet of Egypt|cabinet ministers]],{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = AOI in brief | work = Arab Organization for Industrialization | publisher = Arab Organization for Industrialization | date = | url = http://www.aoi.com.eg/aoieng/ | format = About us | doi = | accessdate = 2010-08-06}} but it is not a division of the ''[[Egyptian Military Industry|Ministry of Military Production]]'' as the treaty upon which it was established declares the Arab Organization for Industrialization as an independent international Organisation, even though it is now only owned by Egypt but the establishing treaty stays the same, and changing it requires the consent of the establishing parties .Cordesman 2002: 65 ==Current enterprises== All AOI enterprises are [[ISO 9000|ISO 9000/2001]] and [[ISO 14000#ISO 14001|ISO 14001/2004]] certified.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = International certifications | work = Arab Organization for Industrialization | publisher = Arab Organization for Industrialization | date = | url = http://www.aoi.org.eg/ | format = About us | doi = | accessdate = 2010-08-06}} ===AOI Aircraft Factory=== [[File:HA-300 side.jpg|thumb|right|[[prototype]] [[Helwan HA-300]] manufactured at the AOI Aircraft Factory, for which the AOI Engine Factory produced E-300 engines.]] The AOI's ''Aircraft Factory'' ({{lang-ar|مصنع الطائرات}}, abbreviated ''ACF'') was established in 1950 as Helwan Aircraft Factory and is a key [[aerospace manufacturer]] in Egypt.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = About the factory | work = Arab Organization for Industrialization Aircraft Factory | publisher = Arab Organization for Industrialization | date = | format = About us | doi = | language = Arabic | accessdate = 2011-07-01}} It is located in [[Helwan]].{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Contact us | work = Arab Organization for Industrialization Aircraft Factory | publisher = Arab Organization for Industrialization | date = | doi = | language = Arabic | accessdate = 2011-07-01}} The AOI Aircraft Factory manufactures and assembles aircraft for the [[Egyptian Air Force|Egyptian air force]], including: * [[Hispano HA-200|Helwan HA-200 Al Kahirah]] [[Subsonic aircraft|subsonic]] [[Trainer (aircraft)|trainer]] * [[Prototype]] [[Helwan HA-300]] [[Supersonic aircraft|supersonic]] [[Fighter aircraft|fighter]] * [[Dassault/Dornier Alpha Jet|Alpha Jet]] * [[Embraer EMB 312 Tucano|Tucano]] [[turboprop]] trainer * the [[Hongdu JL-8|K-8E]] jet trainer. The K-8E is an Egyptian variant of the Chinese Hongdu JL-8, exported as the Karakorum-8 (or K-8) to (among others) [[Pakistan]], Zambia and [[Myanmar]]. The K-8E's manufacture at the AOI Aircraft Factory began in 2000, under an agreement between the AOI and [[China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation|CATIC]], the Chinese state-owned aerospace manufacturer, to produce a total of 60 K-8s over five years. The contract, valued at US$347.4 million, was signed in 1999 in connection with the [[state visit]] by [[President of the People's Republic of China|Chinese president]] [[Jiang Zemin]] that year.{{cite web | last = Xinhua | first = | authorlink = Xinhua News Agency | coauthors = | title = China award Egypt aircraft production licence | work = China Daily | publisher = | date = 2005-08-30 | url = http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-08/30/content_473362.htm | doi = | language = | accessdate = 2011-07-01}} Initially, most of the parts were manufactured in China and the aircraft were assembled in Egypt, but by the end of the programme the manufacture was to be carried out entirely at the AOI Aircraft Factory. In the end, 98% of each K-8E was locally manufactured. The AOI Aircraft Factory also manufactures [[aircraft part]]s for the [[Ministry of Civil Aviation (Egypt)|Egyptian Civil Aviation Authority]] (ECAA), [[Dassault Aviation]] and [[SAGEM]], and has received certification from the ECAA for its [[welding]], painting, testing and [[calibration]] operations. The AOI Aircraft Factory also engages in civilian and technological projects. ===AOI Engine Factory=== In 1960, the ''Engine Factory'' ({{lang-ar|مصنع المحركات}}) was established by the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]] with German technical assistance as a base to design, develop and produce [[aircraft engine]]s.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = History | work = Engine Factory | publisher = Arab Organization for Industrialization | date = | format = About us | doi = | accessdate = 2010-08-06}} The first engines produced at the Engine Factory were: * the E-200 for the Helwan HA-200 Al Kahirah subsonic trainer; and * the E-300 for the Helwan HA-300 supersonic fighter. In 1975, the Engine Factory was affiliated to AOI, since when it has focused its activities on the manufacture, assembly, repair and overhaul of [[gas turbine]]s and accessories. The AOI Engine Factory has established maintenance facilities for [[auxiliary power unit]]s and [[SNECMA Atar#Atar 08 and 09|SNECMA Atar 09C]], [[Allison T56|T56]], [[General Electric T64#Versions|CT64]], [[Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6#PT6A|PT6]]-25 and -64, [[SNECMA Turbomeca Larzac|Larzac 04]], [[Tumansky R-13|R-13]] and [[Tumansky R-25|R-25]] engines. The AOI Engine Factory directs spare capacity to civilian projects, including the manufacture of [[Fuel injection|fuel injectors]] for [[Robert Bosch GmbH]], [[Railway air brake|air brake systems]] for [[Knorr-Bremse]] and [[Rail fastening system#Clips|rail fastening clips]] for [[Pandrol]]. ===Major products=== Compatible ordnance for [[BM-21 Grad]], [[122 mm howitzer 2A18 (D-30)|D-30]] and [[130 mm towed field gun M1954 (M-46)|M-46]] Artillery systems, [[M60 Patton|M60]] Tanks, [[85 mm divisional gun D-44]], and [[ZSU-23-2]] anti-aircraft guns. [[M60 Patton|M60]] Tanks and [[M1A1 Abrams]] assembly from knock down kits [[M60 Patton|M60]] and [[M1A1 Abrams]] engines and spare parts [[Misr assault rifle]] and [[AK 47]] complete manufacture (7,000 assault rifles a year), compatible ammunition ===Major customers=== [[File:MIAS 260915 EAF K-8E 01.jpg|thumb|Egyptian Air Force K-8E on display at the 2015 Malta International Airshow]] {{noref section|date=December 2017}} *[[Egyptian Army]] *[[Syrian Arab Army]] *[[Iraqi Army]] *[[Libyan National Army]]{{fact|date=December 2017}} *[[UAE Army]] *[[Saudi Arabian National Guard]] ===Other factories and enterprises=== AOI Electronics Factory Sakr Factory for Development Industries (AOI) Kader Factory for Development Industries (AOI) Arab British Engine Co. (ABECO) (AOI) Arab British Dynamics Co. ABD (AOI) [[Arab American Vehicle]] (AAV) Egyptian Railways Equipment (SEMAF (ARE)) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{Cite book | last = Cordesman | first = Anthony H. | author-link = | origyear = | year = 2002 | month= | volume = | edition = | chapter = | chapterurl = | page = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Ol-ud-Lj5zEC&source=gbs_navlinks_s | archiveurl = | archivedate = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-275-96939-4}} * {{Cite encyclopedia | title = Egypt: economy | encyclopedia = The Middle East and North Africa | last = German | first = Richard | last2 = Taylor | first2 = Elizabeth | editor-last = Dean | editor-first = Lucy | edition = 50 | pages = | publisher = Europa Publications | place = London | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-1-85743-184-1 | accessdate
