revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. | image = Lt. Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr. Navy.JPG | image_size = | caption = Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] (c. 1942) | birth_name = Joseph Patrick Kennedy Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date|1915|7|25}} | birth_place = [[Hull, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1944|8|12|1915|7|25}} | death_place = Over [[Blythburgh]], [[East Suffolk (county)|East Suffolk]], United Kingdom (remains never recovered) | death_cause = Naval airplane explosion during [[Operation Aphrodite]] | education = [[Harvard College]]
[[London School of Economics]]
[[Harvard Law School]] | occupation = [[Naval Aviator|U.S. Naval Aviator]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | parents = {{plainlist| * [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.]] * [[Rose Kennedy|Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy]]}} | relatives = See [[Kennedy family]] | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{flag|United States}} | branch = {{flag|United States Navy}} | serviceyears = 1941–1944 | rank = [[File:US-O3 insignia.svg|20px]] [[Lieutenant (navy)|Lieutenant]] |placeofburial= [[Cambridge American Cemetery and Memorial]]
[[Cambridge, England]] |placeofburial_label= Memorial – Wall of the Missing | unit = Patrol Squadron 203
Bombing Squadron 110, Special Air Unit 1 | battles = [[World War II]] | awards = [[File:Navycross.jpg|23px]] [[File:Dfc-usa.jpg|23px]] [[File:Air Medal front.jpg|23px]]
[[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]], [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], [[Purple Heart Medal]], [[Air Medal]] | }} }} '''Joseph Patrick Kennedy Jr.''' (July 25, 1915 – August 12, 1944) was a [[United States Navy]] [[Lieutenant (navy)|lieutenant]]. He was killed in action during World War II while serving as a land-based patrol bomber pilot, and was posthumously awarded the [[Navy Cross]]. He was the eldest of nine children born to [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.]] (1888–1969) and [[Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy]] (1890–1995). He was the only Kennedy son who never sought political office, though he had planned to. Joe Sr. had aspirations for Joe Jr. to become [[President of the United States|president]].{{r|Olsen}}{{Page needed|date=August 2015}} However, Joe Jr. was killed while participating in a [[Operation Aphrodite|top-secret mission]] in 1944, and the high expectations of the father then fell upon Joe Jr.'s younger brother [[John F. Kennedy|John]], who was later elected president. == Early life and education == Kennedy was born in Hull, Massachusetts. He first attended the [[Dexter School]] in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], with his brother, John. In 1933, he graduated from the [[Choate School]] in [[Wallingford, Connecticut]]. He then entered [[Harvard College]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], graduating in 1938. Kennedy participated in [[American football|football]], [[Rugby football|rugby]], and [[sport rowing|crew]], and he served on the student council. Kennedy then spent a year studying under the tutelage of [[Harold Laski]] at the [[London School of Economics]] before enrolling in [[Harvard Law School]]. ===Political ambitions and views=== From a very young age, Kennedy was groomed by his father and predicted to be the first Roman Catholic president of the United States. When he was born, his grandfather [[John F. Fitzgerald]], then Mayor of Boston, told the news, "This child is the future President of the nation." He often boasted that he would be president even without help from his father. He was a delegate to the [[1940 Democratic National Convention|Democratic National Convention]] in 1940. Kennedy planned to run for the U.S. House from [[Massachusetts's 11th congressional district]] in 1946. Kennedy expressed approval of [[Adolf Hitler]] before his conquest of Europe began. His father sent him to visit Nazi Germany in 1934. He wrote to his father, praising Hitler's sterilization policy as "a great thing" that "will do away with many of the disgusting specimens of men." {{cite news|last=Gordon|first=Meryl|title='Rosemary: The Hidden Kennedy Daughter,' by Kate Clifford Larson |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/11/books/review/rosemary-the-hidden-kennedy-daughter-by-kate-clifford-larson.html|accessdate=October 13, 2015|newspaper=New York Times|date=October 6, 2015}} He explained that "Hitler is building a spirit in his men that could be envied in any country."{{cite news|last=Honig|first=Sarah|title=Another Tack:Movie Musings |url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Another-Tack-Movie-musings|accessdate=October 13, 2015|newspaper=Jerusalem Post|date=February 28, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Beauchamp|first=Cari|title=Two Sons, One Destiny|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2004/12/kennedy-200412|accessdate=October 13, 2015|newspaper=Vanity Fair|date=December 2004}} == U.S. Navy (1941–1944) == Kennedy left before his final year of law school at Harvard to enlist in the [[United States Navy Reserve|U.S. Naval Reserve]] on June 24, 1941.{{cite web|url=http://www.navsource.org/archives/05/850.htm|title=Destroyer Photo Index DD-850 USS JOSEPH P. KENNEDY, JR.|website=Navsource.org|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} He entered flight training to be a [[United States Naval Aviator|Naval Aviator]], and after training, he received his wings and was commissioned an [[Ensign (rank)|ensign]] on May 5, 1942. He was assigned to Patrol Squadron 203 and then Bombing Squadron 110. In September 1943, he was sent to Britain and became a member of Bomber Squadron 110, Special Air Unit ONE, in 1944. He piloted land-based [[B-24 Liberator|PB4Y Liberator]] patrol bombers on [[anti-submarine warfare|anti-submarine]] details during two tours of duty in the winter of 1943–1944. Kennedy had completed 25 combat missions and was eligible to return home. He instead volunteered for an [[Operation Aphrodite#Mission theory|Operation Aphrodite mission]].{{r|Sorensen 1966}} === Operations Anvil and Aphrodite === [[Operation Aphrodite]] (U.S. Army Air Corps) & Operation Anvil (U.S. Navy) made use of unmanned, explosive-laden Army Air Corps [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress]] and Navy [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator|Consolidated PB4Y-1 Liberator]] bombers that were deliberately crashed into their targets under [[radio control]].{{r|Sorensen 1966}} These aircraft could not take off safely on their own, so a crew of two would take off and fly to {{convert|2000|ft|m|-1}} before activating the remote control system, arming the detonators, and parachuting from the aircraft. Kennedy was appointed a [[Lieutenant (navy)|Lieutenant]] on July 1, 1944. After the U.S. Army Air Corps operation missions were drawn up on July 23, 1944, Lieutenants Wilford John Willy{{cite web |url= https://valor.militarytimes.com/hero/21633|title=Wilford John Willy |website=Hall of Valor Project |accessdate= September 12, 2018}} and Kennedy were designated as the first Navy flight crew. Willy, who was the executive officer of Special Air Unit ONE, had also volunteered for the mission and "pulled rank" over [[Ensign (rank)|Ensign]] James Simpson, who was Kennedy's regular co-pilot. Kennedy and Willy (co-pilot) flew a BQ-8 "robot" aircraft (drone; a converted B-24 Liberator) for the U.S. Navy's first Aphrodite mission. Two [[Lockheed Ventura]] mother planes and a [[Boeing B-17]] navigation plane took off from [[RAF Fersfield]] at 1800 on August 12, 1944. Then the BQ-8 aircraft, loaded with {{convert|21170|lb|kg|abbr=on}} of [[Torpex]], took off. It was to be used against the U-boat pens at [[Heligoland]] in the [[North Sea]].{{r|Freeman}} [[File:Last photo taken of Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. on August 12, 1944.png|thumb|Last photograph of Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. on day of flight, August 12, 1944.]] [[File:Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. (grave).jpg|thumb|right|Commemorative headstone of Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. at [[Arlington National Cemetery]].]] Following them in a [[USAAF]] [[de Havilland Mosquito|F-8 Mosquito]] to film the mission were pilot Lt. Robert A. Tunnel and combat camera man Lt. David J. McCarthy, who filmed the event from the [[perspex]] nose of the aircraft.{{r|Hansen}} As planned, Kennedy and Willy remained aboard as the BQ-8 completed its first remote-controlled turn at {{convert|2,000| ft|m |abbr=on}} near the North Sea coast. Kennedy and Willy removed the safety pin, arming the explosive package, and Kennedy radioed the agreed code ''Spade Flush'', his last known words. Two minutes later (and well before the planned crew bailout, near [[RAF Manston]]), the [[Torpex]] explosive detonated prematurely and destroyed the Liberator, killing Kennedy and Willy instantly. Wreckage landed near the village of [[Blythburgh]] in [[Suffolk]], England, causing widespread damage and small fires, but there were no injuries on the ground. According to one report, a total of 59 buildings were damaged in a nearby coastal town. {{quote|Attempted first Aphrodite attack Twelve August with robot taking off from Fersfield at One Eight Zero Five Hours. Robot exploded in the air at approximately two thousand feet eight miles southeast of Halesworth at One Eight Two Zero hours. Wilford J. Willy Sr Grade Lieutenant and Joseph P. Kennedy Sr Grade Lieutenant, both USNR, were killed. Commander Smith, in command of this unit, is making full report TO US Naval Operations. A more detailed report will be forwarded to you when interrogation is completed | Top Secret [[telegram]] to General [[Carl Andrew Spaatz]] from General [[Jimmy Doolittle]], August 1944{{r|Renehan 2002}} }} According to USAAF records, the trailing Mosquito "was flying 300 feet above and about 300 yards to the rear of the robot. Engineer photographer on this ship was injured, and the ship was damaged slightly by the explosion."Telegram to AWW, cipher, Top Secret, August 17, 1944, Project Aphrodite box, Air Force Historical Research Agency. The Mosquito, which made an immediate emergency landing at [[RAF Halesworth]], belonged to the [[325th Reconnaissance Wing]], a unit under the command of the son of President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], then Colonel [[Elliott Roosevelt]]. Years later, Roosevelt claimed to have been aboard this trailing aircraft, and his version of the event has gained wide currency.{{r|Searls}} However, Air Force records cannot substantiate this. Instead, an after-action account by the 8th Combat Camera Unit (CCU) noted that: [[File:JosephKennedy.jpg|thumb|upright|Memorial for Joseph Kennedy Jr. inside the [[fortress of Mimoyecques]] (France)]] {{quote|... the Baby just exploded in mid-air as we neared it and I was knocked halfway back to the cockpit. A few pieces of the Baby came through the [[plexiglass]] nose and I got hit in the head and caught a lot of fragments in my right arm. I crawled back to the cockpit and lowered the wheels so that Bob could make a quick emergency landing, ...|Lt. McCarthy reported from his hospital bed.8th AAF CCU unit history for August 1944, 25-GP-HI (Recon), AFHRA}} The 8th CCU film of the event, has, so far as is known, not been found. NARA College Park MD 20 FG Mission Reports. The 20th Fighter Group out of King's Cliffe was tasked with providing escort to the Aphrodite mission. Escort consisted of P-51s out of the 55th and 79th Fighter Squadrons, each squadron provided two aircraft. VIII FC, Field Order 509 stated "20 GP (P-51's, 4 A/C) will proceed to Fersfield and land coordinating with operations where to provide close escort support to one B-34 special Operation." Lt John E. Klink reported in this mission summary report "Took off to excort BXXX, 1 B24, 1 B17, 2 B34s, and 3 photo Recons (2 Mosq. -1 P38). When specially loaded B24 was at approx.. 2000 ft. NE of Ipswich it exploded and crashed near small lake. No one got out of of the plane. Rest of ships OK in spite of terrific concussion from explosion. All returned to base." [Sic] The Navy's informal board of review, discussing a number of theories, discounted the possibility of the crew making a mistake or that suspected jamming or a stray signal could have armed and detonated the explosives. An electronics officer, Earl Olsen, who believed the wiring harness had a design defect, had warned Kennedy of this possibility the day before the mission, but he was ignored.{{r|Renehan 2002}} Kennedy and Willy were both [[Posthumous recognition|posthumously]] awarded the [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]], the [[Air Medal]], and the [[Purple Heart Medal]]. The names of both men are listed on the Tablets of the Missing at the [[Cambridge American Cemetery and Memorial]], a cemetery and chapel near the village of [[Madingley]] in [[Cambridgeshire]], Britain, that commemorates American servicemen who died in World War II.[https://www.fold3.com/page/529902218-wilford-j-willy/facts Fold3 entry for Wilford J Willy][https://www.abmc.gov/node/493282#.W5m2SLjZC00 American Battle Monuments Commission] Later reports that Kennedy's final mission were kept top secret until many years later{{r|Olsen}} are negated by a detailed public account of the operation and Kennedy's death released in 1945.''New York Times'', August 15 and 17, 1944 (announcement of Kennedy's death) and October 25, 1945 (detailed account of the mission) == Military awards == Kennedy's military decorations and awards include: {| style="margin: 1em auto;" |- |style="text-align: center;"|{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Navy Cross ribbon.svg|width=106}} |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Distinguished Flying Cross ribbon.svg|width=106}} |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Air Medal ribbon.svg|width=106}} |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Purple Heart ribbon.svg|width=106}} |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=American Defense Service Medal ribbon.svg|width=106}} |{{ribbon devices|number=1|type=service-star|ribbon=American Campaign Medal ribbon.svg|width=106}} |{{ribbon devices|number=1|type=service-star|ribbon=European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign ribbon.svg|width=106}} |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=World War II Victory Medal ribbon.svg|width=106}} |} {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto; text-align: center;" |- |[[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]] |[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] |[[Air Medal]] | [[Purple Heart Medal|Purple Heart]] |- |[[American Defense Service Medal]] |[[American Campaign Medal]]
with one [[service star|star]] |[[European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal|European-African-Middle
Eastern Campaign Medal]]
with one star |[[World War II Victory Medal]] |} === Navy Cross citation=== {{quote|The President of the United States of America takes pride in presenting the Navy Cross (Posthumously) to Lieutenant Joseph Patrick Kennedy, United States Navy, for extraordinary heroism in operations against the enemy while serving as Commander of a Navy Liberator Patrol Plane in Bombing Squadron ONE HUNDRED TEN (VB-110), Special Air Unit ONE (Europe), during a special air mission directed at Mimoyecques, France, on August 12, 1944. Well knowing the extreme dangers involved and totally unconcerned for his own safety, Lieutenant Kennedy unhesitatingly volunteered to conduct an exceptionally hazardous and special operational mission. Intrepid and daring in his tactics and with unwavering confidence in the vital importance of his task, he willingly risked his life in the supreme measure of service, and, by his great personal valor and fortitude in carrying out a perilous undertaking, sustained and enhanced the finest traditions of the United States Naval Service.{{cite web|url=http://valor.militarytimes.com/recipient.php?recipientid=21302|title=Valor awards for Joseph Patrick Kennedy|website=Valor.militarytimes.com|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}}} ==Legacy== In 1946, the Navy named a [[destroyer]] for Kennedy, the {{USS|Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.|DD-850|6}}, aboard which his younger brother, (future [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]]) [[Robert F. Kennedy]], briefly served. Among the highlights of its service are the blockade of [[Cuba]] during the [[Cuban Missile Crisis]] in 1962 and the afloat recovery teams for ''[[Gemini 6]]'' and ''[[Gemini 7]]'', both 1965 [[Human spaceflight|manned spaceflight]]s in [[NASA]]'s [[Gemini program]]. It is now a floating museum in [[Battleship Cove]], [[Fall River, Massachusetts]]. In 1947, the Kennedys established the [[Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation]] and funded the construction of the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Memorial Hall at [[Boston College]], now a part of [[Lynch School of Education|Campion Hall]] and home to the college's [[Lynch School of Education]]. The foundation was led by his youngest brother, U.S. Senator [[Ted Kennedy]], until his death in August 2009. In 1957, the [[Lieutenant Joseph Patrick Kennedy Junior Memorial Skating Rink]] was opened in [[Hyannis, Massachusetts]], with funds from the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation. In 1969, [[Hank Searls]] wrote a biography of Joe Jr., entitled ''The Lost Prince: Young Joe, the Forgotten Kennedy''. [[Young Joe, the Forgotten Kennedy|A television movie]] based on Searls' book won a [[primetime Emmy]] in 1977.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076943/|title=Young Joe, the Forgotten Kennedy|date=September 18, 1977|accessdate=October 2, 2017|website=IMDb.com}} ==See also== {{Portal|World War II|United States Navy|Biography}} * [[Kennedy curse]] * [[Kennedy family]] * [[Kennedy family#Family tree|Kennedy family tree]] * ''[[Young Joe, the Forgotten Kennedy]]'', a 1977 TV movie ==References== {{Reflist| | refs = {{cite book | last = Sorensen | first = Theodore | authorlink = Ted Sorensen | title = Kennedy | publisher = Bantam | location = New York | type = paperback | origyear = 1965 | year = 1966 | oclc = 2746832 | page = 37 }} {{cite book | last = Olsen | first = Jack | authorlink = Jack Olsen | year = 2004 | origyear = 1970 | title = Aphrodite: Desperate Mission | isbn = 978-0-7434-8670-5 }} {{cite book | last = Searls | first = Hank | authorlink = Hank Searls | year = 1977 | origyear = 1969 | title = Young Joe, the Forgotten Kennedy | publisher = Ballantine | location = New York | type = paperback | isbn = 0-345-27395-8 }} {{cite web |title = US Navy and US Marine Corps Bureau Numbers, Third Series (30147 to 839998) |work = |publisher = Joseph F. Baugher |accessdate = April 10, 2007 |url = http://home.att.net/~jbaugher/thirdseries4.html |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090908124220/http://home.att.net/~jbaugher/thirdseries4.html |archivedate = September 8, 2009 |df = mdy-all }} {{cite book | last = Hansen | first = Chris | authorlink = Chris Hansen | year = 2012 | origyear = 2012 | title = Enfant Terrible: The Times and Schemes of General Elliott Roosevelt | publisher = Able Baker | location = Tucson | isbn = 978-0-615-66892-5 }} {{cite book | last = Renehan | first = Edward J. Jr. | authorlink = Edward Renehan | year = 2002 | title = The Kennedys at War, 1937–1945 | publisher = [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] | location = New York | page = 304 | isbn = 978-0-385-50165-1 }} {{cite book | last = Freeman | first = Roger A. | authorlink = Roger A. Freeman | year = 1970 | origyear = 1970 | title = The Mighty Eighth, A History of the U.S. 8th Army Air Force | publisher = Macdonald | location = London | type = Hardback | isbn = 0-385-01168-7 }} }} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.shapell.org/manuscript.aspx?jfk-kennedy-family-joe-death JFK Letter on the Death of Brother Joe Kennedy Jr.] Shapell Manuscript Foundation * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070607165125/http://www.blythweb.co.uk/blythburgh/kennedy1.htm Eye Witness of Plane Crash], BlythburghWeb.co.uk; accessed September 26, 2017 {{Kennedy family|state=collapsed}} {{John F. Kennedy}} {{Robert F. Kennedy}} {{Ted Kennedy}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kennedy, Joseph P. Jr.}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:People from Brookline, Massachusetts]] [[Category:People from Hull, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Alumni of the London School of Economics]] [[Category:American naval personnel killed in World War II]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]] [[Category:Kennedy family]] [[Category:Military personnel from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Navy Cross (United States)]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:United States Navy pilots of World War II]] [[Category:Recipients of the Air Medal]] [[Category:Aviators killed in aviation accidents or incidents in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Aviators from Massachusetts]]

revision.text:
{{pp-semi-protected|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox basketball biography | name = Lamar Odom | image = Lamar Odom 2012 Shankbone.JPG | caption = Odom at the 2012 [[Tribeca Film Festival]] | position = | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 10 | weight_lb = 230 | league = | team = | nationality = American | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1979|11|6}} | birth_place = [[Queens|Queens, New York]] | high_school = St. Thomas Aquinas
([[New Britain, Connecticut]]) | college = [[Rhode Island Rams men's basketball|Rhode Island]] (1998–1999) | draft_year = 1999 | draft_round = 1 | draft_pick = 4 | draft_team = [[Los Angeles Clippers]] | career_start = 1999 | career_end = 2014 | career_position = [[Forward (basketball)|Forward]] | career_number = 7 | years1 = {{nbay|1999|start}}–{{nbay|2002|end}} | team1 = [[Los Angeles Clippers]] | years2 = {{nbay|2003|full=y}} | team2 = [[Miami Heat]] | years3 = {{nbay|2004|start}}–{{nbay|2010|end}} | team3 = [[Los Angeles Lakers]] | years4 = {{nbay|2011|full=y}} | team4 = [[Dallas Mavericks]] | years5 = {{nbay|2012|full=y}} | team5 = Los Angeles Clippers | years6 = [[2013–14 ACB season|2014]] | team6 = [[Saski Baskonia|Laboral Kutxa Baskonia]] | highlights = *2× [[NBA champion]] ({{nbafy|2009}}, {{nbafy|2010}}) * [[NBA Sixth Man of the Year Award|NBA Sixth Man of the Year]] ({{nbay|2010|end}}) * [[NBA All-Rookie First Team]] ({{nbay|1999|end}}) * First-team All-[[Atlantic 10]] (1999) * Atlantic 10 Rookie of the Year (1999) * [[Parade High School Basketball Player of the Year|''Parade'' Player of the Year]] (1997) * 2× [[Parade All-America Boys Basketball Team|''Parade'' All-American]] (1996, 1997) | bbr = odomla01 | medal_templates = {{MedalCountry | USA }} {{MedalSport|Men's Basketball}} {{MedalCompetition|[[2004 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Athens]] | [[2004 United States men's Olympic basketball team|National team]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIBA World Championship]]s}} {{MedalGold|[[2010 FIBA World Championship|2010 Turkey]] | [[2010 United States men's FIBA World Championship team|National team]]}} }} '''Lamar Joseph Odom'''{{cite web | url = http://documents.latimes.com/lamar-odom-arrest-report/ | title = Report of Arrest / Unusual Incident | publisher = State of California, Department of California Highway Patrol via the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date= August 30, 2013 | accessdate= September 25, 2013}} (born November 6, 1979){{cite web | url = http://www.lamarodom.com/?q=biography | title = Biography | publisher = Lamar Odom (official site) | accessdate= August 26, 2013 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120412181756/http://www.lamarodom.com/?q=biography | archivedate= April 12, 2012}} is an American retired professional [[basketball]] player. As a member of the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA), he won [[NBA Finals|NBA championship]]s in 2009 and 2010 and was named the [[NBA Sixth Man of the Year Award|NBA Sixth Man of the Year]] in 2011. As a high school player, Odom received national player of the year honors from ''[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]'' in 1997. He played [[college basketball]] for the [[Rhode Island Rams men's basketball|University of Rhode Island]], earning all-conference honors in his only season in the [[Atlantic 10 Conference]]. He was drafted in the first round of the [[1999 NBA draft]] with the fourth overall pick by the [[Los Angeles Clippers]]. He was named to the [[NBA All-Rookie Team]], but twice he violated the league's drug policy in his four seasons with the Clippers. He signed as a [[Restricted free agent (NBA)|restricted free agent]] with the [[Miami Heat]], where he played one season in 2003–04 before being traded to the Lakers. Odom spent seven seasons with the Lakers, who traded him to the [[Dallas Mavericks]] in 2011. After the move, his career declined. He was traded back to the Clippers in 2012 and played briefly in Spain in 2014. Odom played on the [[United States men's national basketball team|United States national team]], winning a bronze medal in the [[Olympic Games|Olympics]] in 2004 and a gold medal in the [[FIBA World Championship]] (known later as the World Cup) in 2010. Odom was married to [[Khloé Kardashian]] from 2009 to 2016. During their marriage, Odom made several appearances on the [[reality television]] show, ''[[Keeping Up with the Kardashians]]''. He and Kardashian also had their own reality series, ''[[Khloé & Lamar]]''. In October 2015, Odom fell into a coma and was hospitalized with life-threatening medical problems. Odom has since recovered from his health scare and obtained drug treatment.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} ==Early life== Odom was born in [[South Jamaica, Queens]], New York City, to Joe Odom and Cathy Mercer. His father was a [[heroin]] addict, and Odom's mother died of [[colon cancer]] when he was twelve years old.{{cite web |url = http://www.sportingnews.com/nba/story/2011-04-11/lamar-odom-reveals-that-his-father-is-a-heroin-addict | title = Lamar Odom reveals that his father is a heroin addict | work = [[Sporting News]] | date = April 11, 2011 | accessdate = September 25, 2013}}{{cite web| url=http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/news/story?id=6389586|title=Lakers' Lamar Odom top sixth man| first= Dave | last= McMenamin| publisher=[[ESPN (United States)|ESPN]]|date=April 20, 2011}} At her deathbed, Odom's mom told him: "Be nice to everybody". Afterwards, he was raised by his maternal grandmother, Mildred Mercer.{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/vault/2009/03/23/105789399/another-sunny-day-in-lamars-la |title=Another Sunny Day In Lamar's L.A. |last1=Jenkins |first1=Lee |date=March 23, 2009 |work=Sports Illustrated |accessdate=October 15, 2015}} In his first three years of high school, Odom played for [[Christ The King Regional High School]] in [[Middle Village, New York|Middle Village]], Queens. He left the school at the start of his senior year due to poor grades, transferring first to Redemption Christian Academy in [[Troy, New York]] and then to the now-defunct St. Thomas Aquinas High School in [[New Britain, Connecticut]], where he was coached by [[Jerry DeGregorio]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/sports/1998/11/01/1998-11-01_odom_is_on_right_rhode_to_su.html |title=Odom Is On Right Rhode To Success |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081101173333/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/sports/1998/11/01/1998-11-01_odom_is_on_right_rhode_to_su.html|archive-date=November 1, 2008 | last1=Weiss |first1=Dick |date=November 1, 1998 |work=[[New York Daily News]] |accessdate=August 7, 2010}}{{cite web | url=http://espn-i.starwave.com/nba/draft99/players/profiles/odom_lamar.html | title=Lamar Odom: 1999 NBA Draft Tracker | work=ESPN.COM | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619094053/http://espn-i.starwave.com/nba/draft99/players/profiles/odom_lamar.html | archive-date=June 19, 2009}} As a senior, Odom was recognized nationally as the [[Parade High School Basketball Player of the Year|''Parade'' Player of the Year]] in 1997.{{cite web |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1997-03-28/sports/18038473_1_all-star-hoops-auburn-hills|title=Odom Steering College Course|publisher=New York Daily News|first= Anthony | last= McCarron|date=March 28, 1997|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} He also was named to the [[Parade All-America Boys Basketball Team|''Parade'' All-American]] First Team for the second consecutive year,{{cite news|title=Odom Is Player of Year |date=March 27, 1997 |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/sports/odom-is-player-of-year.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cJFThDGX?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/sports/odom-is-player-of-year.html |archivedate=October 16, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} and earned ''[[USA Today]]'' All-USA 1st Team honors.{{cite web|url=http://basketball.realgm.com/highschool/awards/5/12|title=High School Basketball Awards|publisher=RealGM.com|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} During his youth, Odom was teamed with future NBA players [[Elton Brand]] and [[Metta World Peace|Ron Artest]] (later known as Metta World Peace)--each of whom would become teammates with Odom in the NBA--on the same [[Amateur Athletic Union|AAU]] team,{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/columns/story?id=4871463 |title= Lakers' Ron Artest looking, feeling like old self |publisher= ESPN.com |first= Dave | last= McMenamin |date=January 30, 2010|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} and played with future Lakers teammate [[Kobe Bryant]] at [[Adidas ABCD]] camps. Adidas executive [[Sonny Vaccaro]] commented at the time that Odom possessed a "$2 million smile". ==College career== Odom contemplated entering the NBA directly out of high school, and consulted with Bryant, who had made the jump a year earlier. He decided he was not ready, and decided to attend the [[UNLV Runnin' Rebels men's basketball|University of Nevada at Las Vegas]]. However, after a ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' report questioned his unexpectedly high score of 22 out of 36 in the [[American College Testing|ACT]], the school released him in July 1997 before he ever played a game for them. That same summer, he received a citation for soliciting prostitution following an undercover operation by the Las Vegas police.{{cite news |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/1997/Aug-19-Tue-1997/news/5912511.html |title=Odom cited for soliciting prostitution|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] |first=Glen |last=Pruitt |date=August 19, 1997 |accessdate=July 23, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040227045741/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/1997/Aug-19-Tue-1997/news/5912511.html |archivedate=February 27, 2004 |deadurl=yes}} Later, an [[NCAA]] inquiry found Odom received payments amounting to $5,600 from booster David Chapman.{{cite web |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2000/Mar-15-Wed-2000/news/13173026.html |title=NCAA reveals inquiry of UNLV |last1=Carp |first1=Steve |date=March 15, 2000 |work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] |accessdate=August 7, 2010}} Coach [[Bill Bayno]] was fired and UNLV was placed on probation for four years.{{cite web |url=http://articles.courant.com/2000-12-13/features/0012131907_1_bill-bayno-unlv-booster-umass |title=UNLV Gets Probation, Bayno Fired|first=Jeff | last= Goldberg| work=[[Hartford Courant]] |date=December 13, 2000|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} Odom transferred to the [[Rhode Island Rams men's basketball|University of Rhode Island]] but was forced to sit out the 1997–98 season.{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/basketball/college/features/1998/preview98/seasonglance/ |title=CNN/SI 1998 College Basketball Preview |publisher=[[CNN Sports Illustrated]] |first=Dan |last=Shanoff |accessdate=December 28, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229034354/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/basketball/college/features/1998/preview98/seasonglance/ |archivedate=February 29, 2008 }} He was admitted as a [[Matriculation#Special student|non-matriculating student]], and was not allowed to play [[Intramural sports|intramural]] basketball. His room and board was paid for by his father, who was covered by the [[G.I. Bill]]. After two semesters and a summer session, Odom earned his eligibility to play basketball. His career at Rhode Island had been in jeopardy after the first semester, when he vanished before finals. However, Rhode Island coach [[Jim Harrick]] persuaded three of his four instructors to allow him to make up his work. The coach also had Odom work with DeGregorio, who had become a Rams assistant and was the player's closest friend in college. Odom was also inspired by his maternal grandmother, a nurse who had raised five children and returned to school to earn her degree in 1980 at age 56. Odom played one season for the Rams in the [[Atlantic 10 Conference]], where he averaged 17.6 points per game and led the Rams to the conference championship in 1999.{{cite web| url=http://hoopsblog.projo.com/2010/01/former-uri-bask-1.html#.Tvt_fUqU5ls| title=Former URI basketball star Lamar Odom Is Living His Dream|work=[[The Providence Journal]] |first= Robert | last= Lee|date=January 31, 2010|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} He earned first-team all-conference honors and was named the Atlantic 10 Rookie of the Year. He was named the [[most valuable player]] of the [[Atlantic 10 Men's Basketball Tournament|Atlantic 10 Tournament]] after his [[three-point field goal|three-pointer]] against [[Temple Owls men's basketball|Temple University]] at the buzzer gave the Rams their first A-10 Tournament title.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==Professional career== ===Los Angeles Clippers (1999–2003)=== [[File:Lipofskydotcom Lamar Odom-13052.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Odom with the Clippers.]] Odom declared his eligibility for the [[1999 NBA draft]] after his freshman year at the [[Rhode Island Rams men's basketball|Rhode Island]] in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1999_3139644/rhode-island-s-odom-declares-for-nba-draft.html|title=Rhode Island's Odom declars for NBA Draft|work=Houston Chronicle|date=May 18, 1999|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} He then tried to return to college, thinking he was not ready for the NBA; however, had already signed with an agent and was no longer eligible to withdraw from the draft.{{cite news|last=Jenkins|first=Lee|title=The gifts and ghosts of Lamar Odom|date=October 15, 2015|work=Sports Illustrated|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2015/10/15/lamar-odom-lakers-clippers-rhode-island-new-york|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018012257/http://www.si.com/nba/2015/10/15/lamar-odom-lakers-clippers-rhode-island-new-york|archivedate=October 18, 2015|deadurl=no}} Odom was selected by the [[1999–2000 Los Angeles Clippers season|Los Angeles Clippers]] with the fourth overall pick.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2606637|title=Lakers' Odom still mourning sudden death of infant son|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} In his first season with the Clippers, Odom averaged 16.6 points, 7.8 rebounds, and 4.2 assists per game, including 30 points and 12 rebounds in his NBA debut.{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/199911020LAC.html|title=Seattle SuperSonics at Los Angeles Clippers Box Score, November 2, 1999|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} He was named to the 2000 NBA All-Rookie First Team.{{cite web|url=http://www.usabasketball.com/bios/odom_lamar.html|title=USA BAsketball: Lamar Odom|publisher=USABasketball.com|date=September 15, 2010|accessdate=December 28, 2011}} In the [[2000–01 Los Angeles Clippers season|2000–01 season]], Odom increased his scoring average to 17.2 points a game as he started in 74 games. The Clippers failed to make the playoffs again however, as the young team could not improve their positioning in the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]]. In March 2001, Odom was suspended for five games for violating the NBA's drug policy.{{cite news|last1=Teaford|first1=Elliot|title=Odom Is Suspended for Drug Violation|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/nov/06/sports/sp-747|accessdate=October 14, 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 6, 2001}} In [[2001–02 Los Angeles Clippers season|the following season]], he was suspended in November for violating the drug policy again, his second offense in eight months.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=alipour/061102|title=ESPN.com: Page 2 : Odom seeks reason to smile|work=go.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} He admitted to using [[marijuana]] after the suspension.{{cite news|last=Medina |first=Mark |title=Analysis: Lamar Odom's downward spiral has uncertain ending |date=August 30, 2013 |newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News |url=http://www.dailynews.com/sports/20130830/analysis-lamar-odoms-downward-spiral-has-uncertain-ending |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cMaa2w5i?url=http://www.dailynews.com/sports/20130830/analysis-lamar-odoms-downward-spiral-has-uncertain-ending |archivedate=October 18, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} Odom only played 29 games during the season, and his production slipped. He would only play in 49 games during the [[2002–03 Los Angeles Clippers season|2002–03 season]], and would be a restricted free agent the following summer. The [[2003–04 Miami Heat season|Miami Heat]] offered a deal that the Clippers declined to match after already matching another offer the Heat made to [[Elton Brand]]. ===Miami Heat (2003–2004)=== The Heat had previously won only 25 games, but had drafted young talent such as [[Dwyane Wade]] and [[Caron Butler]]. Odom was brought in to play as the team's starting power forward, and along with the budding Wade and veteran [[Eddie Jones (basketball)|Eddie Jones]] shared the scoring load with 17.1 points a game to go with a career high 9.7 rebounds. The Heat opened the season losing 7 straight games, but ended up playing better and competing for a seed in the playoffs. On March 6, Odom posted a triple double, scoring 30 points with 19 rebounds and 11 assists in a home win against the [[2003–04 Sacramento Kings season|Sacramento Kings]]. The Heat would go on to the clinch the 4th seed in the [[2004 NBA Playoffs|playoffs]], facing off the [[2003–04 New Orleans Hornets season|New Orleans Hornets]] in the first round. Each team won at home, and the Heat would win a 7th deciding game to advance to the second round to face the number one seeded [[2003–04 Indiana Pacers season|Indiana Pacers]]. The Pacers would win the first two games in Indiana, but the Heat responded with two straight home wins, including a game 4 victory led by Odom's 22 points. The Pacers' experience proved to be too much for the younger Heat, as they would go to win games 5 and 6 to wrap up the series.{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/MIA/2004_games.html|title=2003-04 Miami Heat Schedule and Results|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} He had a solid season{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/o/odomla01.html|title=Lamar Odom NBA & ABA Statistics|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} compared to his sub-par season with the Clippers the previous year. After the season, Odom was traded in a package with [[Caron Butler]] and [[Brian Grant]] to the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] for [[NBA All-Star Game|All-Star]] [[Shaquille O'Neal]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/basketball/nba/2004-07-14-shaq-trade_x.htm|title=It's Official: Shaq Traded to Heat for Three Players, Draft Pick|work=USA Today|author=David DuPree|date=July 14, 2004|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} ===Los Angeles Lakers (2004–2011)=== [[File:Lamar Odom 2.jpg|thumb|150px|Odom in a [[Los Angeles Lakers|Lakers]] vs [[San Antonio Spurs|Spurs]] game in 2007.]] In his first year with the Los Angeles Lakers, Odom incurred a left shoulder injury which forced him to miss the end of the [[2004–05 Los Angeles Lakers season|2004–05 season]].{{cite web|url=http://www.covers.com/articles/articles.aspx?theArt=45023|title=Lakers Place Lamar Odom on Injured List|date=April 3, 2005|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} Despite Odom averaging 15.2 points and a career high 10.2 rebounds, the Lakers finished out of the playoffs for only the 5th time in franchise history.{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/2005_games.html|title=2004-05 Los Angeles Lakers Schedule and Results|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} Following the 2004–05 season, they re-hired former coach [[Phil Jackson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.covers.com/articles/articles.aspx?theArt=48971&tid=25&t=1|title=L.A. Lakers Re-Hire Phil Jackson|date=June 14, 2005|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} In the first half of [[2005–06 Los Angeles Lakers season|2005–06]], Odom displayed inconsistency while playing with the Lakers. However, as Los Angeles progressed towards the end of the season, his performance steadily improved. Along the way, he posted consecutive [[triple-double]]s for the first time as a Laker against the [[2005–06 Golden State Warriors season|Golden State Warriors]]{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/200604110LAL.html|title=Golden State Warriors at Los Angeles Lakers, April 11, 2006|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} and [[2005–06 Portland Trail Blazers season|Portland Trail Blazers]].{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/200604140LAL.html|title=Portland Trail Blazers at Los Angeles Lakers, April 14, 2006|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} The Lakers were eliminated in 7 games in the first round of the playoffs against the [[2005–06 Phoenix Suns season|Phoenix Suns]], after the Lakers lost a 3–1 series lead.{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/2006_games.html|title=2005-06 Los Angeles Lakers Schedule and Results|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} Odom averaged 14.8 points and 9.2 rebounds during the season and increased his scoring (19.1) and rebounds (11) in seven playoff games. Battling injuries, Odom was limited to 56 games in [[2006–07 Los Angeles Lakers season|2006–07]], but finished with an average of 15.9 points and 9.8 rebounds per game.{{cite web|title=Lamar Odom NBA & ABA Statistics| publisher=Basketball-Reference.com}} In a rematch of the previous year's series, the Lakers were again defeated by the [[2006–07 Phoenix Suns season|Phoenix Suns]] in the first round of the [[2007 NBA Playoffs]].{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/2007.html|title=2006-07 Los Angeles Lakers Roster and Statistics|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} After young center [[Andrew Bynum]] went down with a knee injury during the [[2007–08 Los Angeles Lakers season|2007–08 season]],{{cite news|title=Bynum knee injury deals major blow to Lakers|first=Scott|last=Boeck|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/basketball/nba/lakers/2009-02-02-bynum-stats_N.htm|newspaper=USA Today|date=February 3, 2009|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} and [[Pau Gasol]] was acquired by the Lakers midseason,{{cite web|title=LAKERS: Lakers Acquire Gasol From Grizzlies|publisher=NBA.com|date=February 1, 2008}} Odom played well, averaging 15.3 points, 12 rebounds, and 4 assists per game.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/la-sp-elliott23apr23,1,6066980.column |title=Role Model |last1=Elliott |first1=Helene |date=April 23, 2008 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=August 7, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522105911/http://www.latimes.com/la-sp-elliott23apr23%2C1%2C6066980.column |archivedate=May 22, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Odom finished the season with 14.2 ppg 10.6 rpg and 3.5 apg.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/lamar_odom/career_stats.html|title=NBA.com/Stats|work=nba.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130702165429/http://www.nba.com/playerfile/lamar_odom/career_stats.html|archivedate=July 2, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Odom's numbers were down in [[2008 NBA Finals|the Finals]], however, where he averaged 13.5 points, 9.0 rebounds and 3.0 assists per game,{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/lamar_odom/index.html|title=NBA.com/Stats|work=nba.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} with the Lakers losing in the [[2008 NBA Finals]] to the [[2007–08 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]].{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/playoffs/NBA_2008_finals.html|title=2008 NBA Finals Composite Box Score|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 31, 2011}} In [[2008–09 Los Angeles Lakers season|2008–09]], Odom arrived at training camp out of shape.{{cite news|last=Streeter |first=Kurt |title=Don't be so hard on Odom |date=October 23, 2008 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/oct/23/sports/sp-streeter23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cMPR4DiX?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/oct/23/sports/sp-streeter23 |archivedate=October 18, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} Jackson shared his plan to move Odom to the [[Substitution (sport)|bench]] as their [[sixth man]], backing up the Lakers' frontcourt of Gasol, Bynum, and [[Trevor Ariza]]. A free agent after the season, Odom initially balked at the plan to be a reserve for the first time in his career. However, he came around, and was resolved to make his teammates happy and sacrifice his own individual numbers in the hopes of securing his first NBA championship. When Bynum was injured in a game against the [[2008–09 Memphis Grizzlies season|Memphis Grizzlies]] in January, Odom returned to the starting lineup. In the month of February, Odom, playing 36 minutes per game, averaged 16.5 points, 13.4 rebounds (4.9 offensive and 9.5 defensive), 2.4 assists, 1.4 blocks, and .9 steals.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/lamar_odom/game_by_game_stats.html |title=Lamar Odom Game By Game Page |publisher=NBA.com |date=November 6, 1979 |accessdate=August 4, 2012}} The February run included a good performance at [[Quicken Loans Arena]] at [[2008–09 Cleveland Cavaliers season|Cleveland]]. With 15 points in the 3rd quarter, Odom helped the Lakers out of a 12-point deficit to turn it into a 10-point victory, breaking Cleveland's 23 game home win-streak.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20090208/LALCLE/playbyplay.html |title=Lakers at Cavaliers Play By Play |publisher=NBA.com |date= |accessdate=August 4, 2012}} He finished the game with 28 points, 17 rebounds and 2 assists.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/games/20090208/LALCLE/recap.html |title=Lakers stop Cavaliers' home winning streak |last1=Withers |first1=Tom |date=February 8, 2009 |work=[[National Basketball Association|NBA]] |accessdate=August 7, 2010}} [[File:LamarOdomLakers.jpg|thumb|Odom in 2011, when he was named [[NBA Sixth Man of the Year]].]] Odom adjusted back to his sixth man role when Bynum returned for an April 9 home matchup versus the [[2008–09 Denver Nuggets season|Denver Nuggets]].{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/200904090LAL.html|title=Denver Nuggets at Los Angeles Lakers, April 9, 2009 Box Score|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} Odom finished his season with 11.3 points, 8.2 rebounds, 2.6 assists, 1.0 steals and 1.7 blocks with 29.7 minutes per game. He won his first NBA championship when the Lakers defeated the [[2008–09 Orlando Magic season|Orlando Magic]] in the [[2009 NBA Finals]]. During the 2009 off-season, Odom was courted heavily by his former team, Miami.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=4336149|title=Sources: Heat Prepared to Offer Odom|publisher=ESPN.com|author=Marc Stein|date=July 20, 2009|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} Despite pleas from Heat guard [[Dwyane Wade]], and Heat Executive [[Pat Riley]],{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/2009/news/features/david_aldridge/07/30/odom/index.html|title=Odom agrees to help Lakers defend their crown|publisher=NBA.com|author=David Aldridge|date=July 31, 2009|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} [[Kobe Bryant]] remained optimistic Odom would return to Los Angeles{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=4347050|title=Kobe: Odom Makes Us Stronger|publisher=ESPN.com|date=July 23, 2009|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} to team up with newly acquired forward and Odom's fellow New Yorker, [[Ron Artest]]. After a month of tedious negotiations, on July 31, 2009 the Lakers announced that they had agreed to a four-year deal worth up to $33 million with Odom.Ramona Shelburne. "[http://www.sbsun.com/sports/ci_12971087 Odom relieved to be back with world champs]". ''San Bernardino Sun''. July 31, 2009. Retrieved on August 11, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229152528/http://www.sbsun.com/sports/ci_12971087 |date=February 29, 2012 }} The investment would pay off as Odom would play a crucial role for the Lakers on the way to another NBA Championship, with the Lakers winning over the [[2009–10 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]] in the [[2010 NBA Finals]].{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/2010.html|title=2009-10 Los Angeles Lakers Roster and Statistics|publisher=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} Odom continued his strong play for the Lakers with another solid season in the [[2010–11 Los Angeles Lakers season|2010–11 season]] where he posted career highs in 3 point shooting percentage (.382) and overall field goal percentage (.530). He started 35 games in Bynum's absence during the season and averaged 16.3 points and 10.2 rebounds in those starts. In 47 games off the bench, Odom averaged 13.5 points, 7.5 rebounds in 28.4 minutes.{{cite web|title=Lamar Odom Stats, Splits |publisher=ESPN |url=http://espn.go.com/nba/player/splits/_/id/617/lamar-odom |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y4IojtQd?url=http://espn.go.com/nba/player/splits/_/id/617/lamar-odom |archivedate=April 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Meeting the requirement to come in as a reserve more games than he started, Odom was awarded the [[NBA Sixth Man of the Year Award]], becoming the first player in Lakers history to do so.{{cite news|last=Medina |first=Mark |title=Lamar Odom's Sixth Man of the Year award epitomizes his selfless approach to basketball and life |date=April 19, 2011 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://lakersblog.latimes.com/lakersblog/2011/04/lamar-odoms-sixth-man-of-the-year-award-epitomizes-his-selfless-approach-to-basketball-and-life.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y4uJcJ7m?url=http://lakersblog.latimes.com/lakersblog/2011/04/lamar-odoms-sixth-man-of-the-year-award-epitomizes-his-selfless-approach-to-basketball-and-life.html |archivedate=April 20, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|last=McMenamin |first=Dave |title=Lakers' Lamar Odom top sixth man |publisher=ESPN |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/news/story?id=6389586 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y4sp1jKN?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/news/story?id=6389586 |archivedate=April 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|last=Shelburne |first=Ramona |title=Lamar Odom's Sixth is his best |date=April 19, 2011 |work=ESPNLosAngeles.com |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/columns/story?id=6392501 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y4u8FUt6?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/columns/story?id=6392501 |archivedate=April 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Bryant called it Odom's most "consistent season". During the offseason, Odom considered taking a break from basketball after a close cousin was murdered and Odom was a passenger in a SUV involved in an accident that killed a teenage cyclist.{{cite news|last=McMahaon |first=Tim |title=Rick Carlisle benches Lamar Odom |work=ESPNDallas.com |date=March 24, 2012 |url=http://espn.go.com/dallas/nba/story/_/id/7730755/dallas-mavericks-lamar-odom-benched-first-time-career |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66Obi9a79?url=http://espn.go.com/dallas/nba/story/_/id/7730755/dallas-mavericks-lamar-odom-benched-first-time-career |archivedate=March 24, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|last=Turner |first=Broderick |title=Lakers' Lamar Odom has to deal with death all over again |date=August 2, 2011 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/aug/02/sports/la-sp-lamar-odom-accident-20110803 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cMYk2a0Z?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/aug/02/sports/la-sp-lamar-odom-accident-20110803 |archivedate=October 18, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} The car accident had occurred the day after Odom attended his cousin's funeral. ===Dallas Mavericks (2011–2012)=== On December 11, 2011, Odom was traded to the [[2011–12 Dallas Mavericks season|Dallas Mavericks]], the defending NBA champions, for a first-round draft pick and an $8.9 million trade exception after NBA Commissioner [[David Stern]] vetoed a proposed three-team trade that would have sent Odom and [[Houston Rockets]] teammates [[Kevin Martin (basketball, born 1983)|Kevin Martin]], [[Luis Scola]], and [[Goran Dragić]] to the [[2011–12 New Orleans Hornets season|New Orleans Hornets]]; [[Chris Paul]] to the Lakers; and [[Pau Gasol]] to the [[2011–12 Houston Rockets season|Houston Rockets]].{{cite web | url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/111211lakers_acquire_draftpick.html | title=Lakers Acquire First Round Draft Pick from Dallas in Exchange for Lamar Odom & Second Round Draft Pick | work=NBA.com | publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc | date=December 9, 2011 | accessdate=December 9, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://friends.mavs.com/profiles/blogs/mavericks-acquire-2011-sixth-man-of-the-year-lamar-odom?xg_source=activity|title=MAVERICKS ACQUIRE 2011 SIXTH MAN OF THE YEAR LAMAR ODOM|work=mavs.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107135638/http://friends.mavs.com/profiles/blogs/mavericks-acquire-2011-sixth-man-of-the-year-lamar-odom?xg_source=activity|archivedate=January 7, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Odom felt "disrespected" after he learned of the Hornets trade publicly, and he requested a trade from the Lakers to another contending team.{{cite news|last=Caplan |first=Jeff |title=Lamar Odom on Lakers exit: 'Surreal' |date=December 13, 2011 |work=ESPNDallas.com |url=http://espn.go.com/dallas/nba/story/_/id/7349010/dallas-mavericks-lamar-odom-los-angeles-lakers-felt-little-disrespected |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63ubsc9Zx?url=http://espn.go.com/dallas/nba/story/_/id/7349010/dallas-mavericks-lamar-odom-los-angeles-lakers-felt-little-disrespected |archivedate=December 14, 2011 |deadurl=no|df= }} The Lakers were also concerned that Odom's contract was pricey since he was not needed to initiate the [[triangle offense]] with [[Mike Brown (basketball, born 1970)|Mike Brown]] replacing Phil Jackson as Lakers coach.{{cite news|last=McMenamin |first=Dave |title=Lamar Odom dealt to Dallas |work=ESPNLosAngeles.com |date=December 12, 2011 |url=http://espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/story/_/id/7341952/los-angeles-lakers-lamar-odom-dealt-dallas-mavericks-asking-trade |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63skSz7XP?url=http://espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/story/_/id/7341952/los-angeles-lakers-lamar-odom-dealt-dallas-mavericks-asking-trade |archivedate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} In January 2012, [[Sports Illustrated]] reported that "Odom [had] yet to find his niche in Dallas. His struggles [made] him a frequent target of [Mavericks coach Rick] Carlisle, who [harped] on Odom's need to understand the coverages, be more alert, communicate and get in better shape... Team sources say Odom...appeared stressed by what they believe [was] the mental burden of an overwhelming offseason."{{cite news|last=Mannix |first=Chris |title=Odom struggling to find niche |work=Sports Illustrated |date=January 12, 2012 |access-date=February 26, 2018 |url=https://www.si.com/more-sports/2012/01/12/lamar-odom }} On March 2, 2012, Odom was assigned to the [[Texas Legends]] of the [[NBA D-League]]. He had missed the prior three games due to personal reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/dleague/news/mavericks_assign_odom_2012_03_02.html|title=NBA Development League: Dallas Mavericks Assign Lamar Odom to NBA D-League Affiliate Texas Legends|work=nba.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} His stint with the Legends was canceled on March 3, 2012, and he returned to the Mavs' active roster.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/2012/news/03/03/mavs-odom/index.html|title=Mavericks recall Odom from D-League's Legends|work=NBA.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} On March 24, Odom did not play in a 104–87 loss to the [[2011–12 San Antonio Spurs season|San Antonio Spurs]]; this was the first time he could remember not playing due to a coach's decision. On April 9, 2012, it was announced that Odom had parted ways with the Mavericks. Instead of releasing him, the team listed Odom as inactive for the remainder of the season. The move allowed the Mavericks to trade him at the end of the season. In a statement to [[ESPN]], Odom said, "I'm sorry that things didn't work out better for both of us, but I wish the Mavs' organization, my teammates and Dallas fans nothing but continued success in the defense of their championship."{{cite web |last=Stein |first=Marc |title=Lamar Odom, Mavs sever ties |date=April 9, 2012 |work=ESPNDallas.com |url=http://espn.go.com/dallas/nba/story/_/id/7791431/dallas-mavericks-lamar-odom-sever-ties-immediately |accessdate=April 10, 2012}} Mavericks owner [[Mark Cuban]] admitted that a clash between the two during halftime in a game against the [[2011–12 Memphis Grizzlies season|Memphis Grizzlies]] on April 7 was the last straw. Odom reportedly responded angrily when Cuban questioned his commitment, asking if he was "in or out."{{cite web |last=MacMahon |first=Tim |title=Mark Cuban: Clash was 'the end' |date=April 11, 2012 |work=ESPNDallas.com |url=http://espn.go.com/dallas/nba/story/_/id/7796599/lamar-odom-argued-dallas-mavericks-owner-mark-cuban |accessdate=April 15, 2012}} Odom averaged only 6.6 points in 20.5 minutes along with career lows in shooting percentage (35.2), rebounds (4.2) and assists (1.7) . ===Return to Los Angeles Clippers (2012–2013)=== On June 29, 2012, Odom was traded back to the [[2012–13 Los Angeles Clippers season|Los Angeles Clippers]] as part of a four-team deal. The deal sent Odom to the Clippers, the rights to [[Tadija Dragićević]] and cash considerations to the [[2012–13 Dallas Mavericks season|Dallas Mavericks]], [[Mo Williams]] and the draft rights to [[Shan Foster]] to the [[2012–13 Utah Jazz season|Utah Jazz]], and the draft rights to [[Furkan Aldemir]] to the [[2012–13 Houston Rockets season|Houston Rockets]].[http://www.nba.com/clippers/news/odom-acquired-120629.html Clippers acquire Odom as part of four-team trade]. NBA.com. June 29, 2012. Retrieved on June 29, 2012. He played all 82 games of the season for the third time in his career, but only started two of them. Out of shape for half the season, he averaged career lows of 4.0 ppg and 1.7 apg in 19.7 mpg during the season. He also averaged 5.9 rebounds, but shot just 39.9 percent. The Clippers finished 56-26 and won their first-ever [[Pacific Division (NBA)|Pacific Division]] title. In July 2013, Odom became a free agent, but did not land an NBA contract despite some interest from the Clippers in his return.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/10473042/lamar-odom-make-comeback-spain|title=Lamar Odom to make comeback in Spain|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} The Lakers also contemplated re-signing him, but both teams committed to other players instead. ===Laboral Kutxa Baskonia (2014)=== On February 18, 2014, Odom signed with [[Saski Baskonia|Laboral Kutxa Baskonia]] of the [[Liga ACB|Spanish League]] and the [[Euroleague]] on a two-month deal with an option to extend it for the remainder of the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/cat/nba/111667/laboral-kutxa-officially-signs-lamar-odom.html|title=Laboral Kutxa officially signs Lamar Odom|date=February 18, 2014|work=Sportando|accessdate=October 16, 2015}}[http://www.euroleague.net/euroleaguenews/transactions/2013-14-signings/i/132330 Laboral Kutxa lands Lamar Odom] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222230001/http://www.euroleague.net/euroleaguenews/transactions/2013-14-signings/i/132330 |date=February 22, 2014 }} A month later, he returned to the United States due to a back injury after his personal doctors in New York ruled him unfit to play out his contract. He appeared in just two games for Baskonia.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/10607290/lamar-odom-injures-back-likely-miss-month-spanish-team|title=Lamar Odom injures back, likely to miss month from Spanish team|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} ===New York Knicks (2014)=== On April 16, 2014, Odom signed with the [[2013–14 New York Knicks season|New York Knicks]] for the remainder of the 2013–14 season,{{cite web|url=http://knicksnow.com/posts/5677/knicks-sign-lamar-odom-for-remainder-of-the-season|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419012527/http://knicksnow.com/posts/5677/knicks-sign-lamar-odom-for-remainder-of-the-season|title=Knicks Now – Knicks Sign Lamar Odom For Remainder Of The Season|archivedate=April 19, 2014|work=Knicksnow|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} but did not appear in the team's season finale. The Knicks finished with a 37–45 win/loss record and missed the playoffs. On July 11, 2014, he was waived by the Knicks.{{cite web|url=http://www.insidehoops.com/blog/?p=16206|title=Knicks waive Lamar Odom|work=insidehoops.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} ==National team career== [[File:Billups & Odom holding World Cup trophy.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Chauncey Billups]] (left) and Odom holding 2010 [[FIBA World Championship]] trophy.]] Odom played in the [[2004 United States men's Olympic basketball team|2004 Summer Olympics]] in Athens for the [[United States national basketball team|US national team]], averaging 9.3 ppg while helping the U.S. to a bronze medal.{{cite web|url=http://www.usabasketball.com/bios/odom_lamar.html|title=USA Basketball: Lamar Odom|work=usabasketball.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} He was invited to play for the [[International Basketball Federation|FIBA]] World Championships for 2006 but declined the invitation because of the tragic death of his son{{cite web|title=Odom, Pierce to miss Team USA Camp|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-07-14/sports/0607140173_1_paul-pierce-lamar-odom-minor-surgery|work=Chicago Tribune|date=July 14, 2006|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} and in 2007 because of a shoulder injury.{{cite web|title=Team USA F Bosh withdraws due to foot injury|url=http://areyouwatchingthis.com/olympics/news/32775-Team-USA-F-Bosh-withdraws-due-to-foot-injury|date=August 16, 2007|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} Odom would, however, be invited back for the national team's run at the [[2010 United States men's FIBA World Championship team|2010 FIBA World Championship]] in Istanbul, Turkey where the U.S. would win gold for the first time since 1994.{{cite web|url=http://nba.fanhouse.com/2010/09/12/durant-leads-team-usa-to-first-worlds-gold-since-1994/|title=Durant Leads Team USA to First Worlds Gold Since 1994|publisher=AOL.com|author=Chris Tomasson|date=September 12, 2010|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} Odom, being one of the elder statesmen on a young U.S. squad, served as a mentor for many of the younger players{{cite web|url=http://lakersblog.latimes.com/lakersblog/2010/09/lamar-odoms-participation-in-2010-fiba-world-championships-could-prove-critical-in-early-season.html|title=Lamar Odom's Participation in 2010 FIBA World Championships Could Prove Critical in Early Season|work=Los Angeles Times|author=Mark Medina|date=September 28, 2010}} and even played out of position at center for the tournament. He led the U.S. in rebounds and finished the FIBA championships with double-doubles in the semi-final{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fa/game/p/gid/A/grid/77/rid/6947/sid/4728/_/2010_FIBA_World_Championship/statistic.html|title=archive.fiba.com: 2010 FIBA World Championship|publisher=FIBA.com|date=September 11, 2010|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} and championship games{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fa/game/p/gid/A/grid/80/rid/6948/sid/4728/_/2010_FIBA_World_Championship/statistic.html|title=archive.fiba.com: 2010 FIBA World Championships|publisher=FIBA.com|date=September 12, 2010|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} while becoming the first player in history to win both an NBA championship and FIBA gold in the same year. ==Player profile== Odom was renowned for the impact his positive personality had on his teams. Lakers general manager [[Mitch Kupchak]] called him "the most popular player in our locker room".{{cite news|last=Howard-Cooper |first=Scott |title=Respected Odom has special place among NBA family |date=October 14, 2015 |website=NBA.com |url=http://www.nba.com/2015/news/features/scott_howard_cooper/10/14/lamar-odom-holds-special-place-among-teammates-and-the-nba/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cKsL9Soz?url=http://www.nba.com/2015/news/features/scott_howard_cooper/10/14/lamar-odom-holds-special-place-among-teammates-and-the-nba/ |archivedate=October 17, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} Odom valued the concept of a team and played unselfishly,{{cite news|last=Ding |first=Kevin |title=For Lamar Odom, Team Has Always Mattered More Than Anything, Even Himself |date=October 14, 2015 |work=Bleacher Report |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2579081-for-lamar-odom-team-has-always-mattered-more-than-anything-even-himself |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cMNFrUjQ?url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2579081-for-lamar-odom-team-has-always-mattered-more-than-anything-even-himself |archivedate=October 18, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} and was content deferring to teammates while playing a supporting role. Standing at {{convert|6|ft|10|in|m}}, he was still adept at dribbling the ball and directing the offense, and could also rebound proficiently as a [[small forward]]. He was able to score as a [[post player]], on mid-range jumpers, as well as from outside. He could start a fast break with an outlook pass, finish it with a layup, or simply drive from coast to coast for a dunk. Though he was a reserve on the Lakers championship teams, he typically finished games in place of starter [[Andrew Bynum]]. Odom was cooperative with the media, and provided both thoughtful and open responses. ==Career statistics== {{NBA player statistics legend}} ===NBA=== {| class="wikitable" |- | style="background:#afe6ba; width:3em;"|† |Denotes seasons in which Odom won an [[List of NBA champions|NBA championship]] |} ====Regular season==== {{NBA player statistics start}} |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{nbay|1999|trunc=y}} | style="text-align:left;"| [[1999–2000 Los Angeles Clippers season|L.A.
