Lamar Jr. (b. 2002)[http://hollywoodlife.com/celeb/lamar-odom-jr/ ''Lamar Odom Jr.'' in: hollywoodlife.com] [retrieved 25 May 2016]. and Jayden (2005–2006), with Liza Morales before they separated. On June 29, 2006, 6½-month-old Jayden died from [[sudden infant death syndrome]] while sleeping in his crib in New York.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2504783|title=Lamar Odom's infant son dies while sleeping|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} At the time, Odom was already in town for the funeral of an aunt.{{cite news|last1=Cacciola |first1=Scott |last2=Witz |first2=Billy |title=Lamar Odom's Decline, Played Out on TV |date=October 15, 2015 |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/16/sports/basketball/lamar-odoms-decline-played-out-on-tv.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cJTpozXI?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/16/sports/basketball/lamar-odoms-decline-played-out-on-tv.html?_r=0 |archivedate=October 16, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} Odom developed a relationship with his father, who became drug-free; however, he remains closer to his high school coach, Jerry DeGregorio, who he calls [his] "white dad". DeGregorio is the godfather to Destiny and Lamar Jr. In September 2009, Odom married [[Khloé Kardashian]] after a month of dating.{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20308442,00.html |title=Khloe Kardashian Is Married! |last1=Garcia |first1=Jennifer |last2=Wihlborg |first2=Ulrica |date=September 27, 2009 |work=People |accessdate=August 7, 2010}} He had met her at a party for Lakers teammate Artest. Their wedding was featured on the [[E!]] reality-based series ''[[Keeping Up with the Kardashians]]'', in which she stars. Odom became a fixture on the show and a household name to millions who were not already familiar with him as a basketball player.{{cite news|last=Zeitchik|first=Steven|title=Lamar Odom: A Shakespearean tale for the TMZ era|date=October 14, 2015|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|url=http://graphics.latimes.com/lamar-odom/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016093408/http://graphics.latimes.com/lamar-odom/|archivedate=October 16, 2015|deadurl=no}} In December 2010, E! announced another spinoff from the series featuring Odom, Kardashian, and his two children from his previous relationship. The series, titled ''[[Khloé & Lamar]]'', debuted on April 10, 2011.[http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/khloe-kardashian-and-lamar-odom-reportedly-getting-reality-show-11844.php "Khloe Kardashian and Lamar Odom reportedly getting reality show"] from Reality TV World (December 29, 2010) Soon thereafter, Odom almost opted out of the show as the filming wore him down. The series was canceled in 2012 after two seasons. On August 30, 2013, Odom was arrested on charges of [[driving under the influence]] (DUI).{{cite web | last = Winton | first = Richard | first2 = Kate | last2 = Mather | title = Lamar Odom to lose driver's license after DUI arrest, CHP says | url = http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-lamar-odom-to-lose-driviers-license-after-dui-arrest-chp-says-20130830,0,302142.story | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = August 30, 2013 |accessdate=September 25, 2013}} After the arrest, he refused to submit to a chemical test. Almost a week earlier, gossip websites had alleged that Odom had been abusing drugs, which prompted worried tweets from former teammates and coaches.{{cite news|last1=Bolch |first1=Ben |last2=Winton |first2=Richard |title=Lamar Odom's DUI arrest adds to concerns |date=August 30, 2013 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/2013/aug/30/sports/la-sp-lamar-odom-20130831 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cJmnHB7a?url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/2013/aug/30/sports/la-sp-lamar-odom-20130831 |archivedate=October 16, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|last=Pollakoff |first=Brett |title=TMZ report: Lamar Odom has had a drug problem for the last two years |date=August 24, 2013 |website=NBCSports.com |url=http://nba.nbcsports.com/2013/08/24/tmz-report-lamar-odom-has-had-a-drug-problem-for-the-last-two-years/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cJmwdaE2?url=http://nba.nbcsports.com/2013/08/24/tmz-report-lamar-odom-has-had-a-drug-problem-for-the-last-two-years/ |archivedate=October 16, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} On December 9, Odom pleaded no contest to the DUI charges and accepted a sentence of three years' probation and three months of alcohol abuse treatment.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nba/eye-on-basketball/24371355/lamar-odom-pleads-no-contest-in-dui-case|title=Lamar Odom pleads no contest in DUI case|work=CBSSports.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} On December 13, after months of speculated separation, Kardashian filed for divorce from Odom and for legal restoration of her last name.{{cite news|title=Khloe Kardashian filing for divorce from Lamar Odom, reports say|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2013/12/13/khloe-kardashian-filing-for-divorce-from-lamar-odom-reports-say/|accessdate=December 13, 2013|date=December 13, 2013|author=[[Fox News]]}} Divorce papers were signed by both parties in July 2015;{{cite web|last1=Harrison|first1=Lily|title=Khloé Kardashian ''Has Been Worried'' About Lamar Odom, Family Source Says Hospitalization ''Isn't Shocking''|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/706259/khloe-kardashian-has-been-worried-about-lamar-odom-family-source-says-hospitalization-isn-t-shocking|website=E! Online|accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=October 13, 2015}}{{cite web|title=TMZ: Lamar Odom Found Unconscious After Partying At Brothel In Nevada|url=http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2015/10/13/tmz-lamar-odom-being-treated-after-being-found-unconscious-in-nevada/|website=CBS Los Angeles|accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=October 13, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Khloe Kardashian, Lamar Odom Finally Sign Divorce Papers Two Years After Split|url=http://m.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/khloe-kardashian-lamar-odom-sign-divorce-papers-two-years-after-split-2015217|website=Us Magazine|accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=July 21, 2015}} however, the divorce did not receive final approval from a judge before being dismissed by request in October 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/14/us/lamar-odom-condition/|title=Lamar Odom used cocaine, brothel workers say – CNN.com|author=Kyung Lah, Eliott C. McLaughlin and Steve Almasy, CNN|date=October 14, 2015|work=CNN|accessdate=October 16, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/basketball/ct-lamar-odom-hospitalized-20151014-story.html|title=Lamar Odom's spiral leaves ex-NBA star fighting for his life|author=Chicago Tribune|date=October 14, 2015|work=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}}{{Cite web|title = Khloé & Lamar Odom Calling Off Divorce|url = http://www.eonline.com/news/708755/khloe-kardashian-and-lamar-odom-calling-off-divorce|website = E! Online|accessdate = 2015-10-23|language = en}} On October 13, 2015, Odom was hospitalized after being discovered unconscious at the [[Dennis Hof's Love Ranch|Love Ranch]], a legal brothel in [[Crystal, Nye County, Nevada|Crystal, Nevada]].{{cite news|last1=Panzar|first1=Javier|last2=Muskal|first2=Michael|last3=Pearce|first3=Matt|title=Lamar Odom took cocaine and Viagra-like drugs, sheriff says|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/sportsnow/la-sp-lamar-odom-las-vegas-brothel-20151013-story.html|accessdate=October 14, 2015|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=October 14, 2015}}{{cite news|title=Former NBA star Lamar Odom found unconscious, taken to Nevada hospital|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/13883127/lamar-odom-taken-hospital-being-found-unconscious-nevada-brothel|accessdate=October 13, 2015|date=October 13, 2015|work=ESPN.com}} Odom, who had used cocaine in the days prior to his medical emergency, suffered kidney failure and several strokes; he became comatose and was placed on [[life support]] in a hospital in Las Vegas before regaining consciousness.{{cite news|last1=Panzar|first1=Javier|last2=Muskal|first2=Michael|last3=Pearce|first3=Matt|title=Lamar Odom took cocaine and Viagra-like drugs, sheriff says|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/sportsnow/la-sp-lamar-odom-las-vegas-brothel-20151013-story.html|accessdate=October 14, 2015|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=October 14, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Turner |first=Broderick |title=Lamar Odom feeling 'way better,' but recovery will be long |date=October 20, 2015 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/sportsnow/la-sp-sn-lamar-odom-improvement-20151020-story.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cRGJf3Ww?url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/sportsnow/la-sp-sn-lamar-odom-improvement-20151020-story.html |archivedate=October 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} He was transferred from Las Vegas to a Los Angeles hospital by medical transport.{{cite news|title=Lamar Odom moved from Las Vegas to Los Angeles hospital |date=October 20, 2015 |website=ESPN.com |url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/13928863/lamar-odom-losangeles-hospital-las-vegas-via-medical-transport-helicopter |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cRGX0vGc?url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/13928863/lamar-odom-losangeles-hospital-las-vegas-via-medical-transport-helicopter |archivedate=October 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} In the aftermath of the incident, Kardashian withdrew her request for a divorce; she stated that she had not reconciled with Odom, but wished to assist him in making medical decisions during his recovery.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/10/28/entertainment/khloe-kardashian-lamar-odom-people-feat/|title=Khloe Kardashian breaks silence on Lamar Odom|publisher=[[CNN]]|last=Respers France|first=Lisa|date=October 28, 2015}} Odom's recovery went well.{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/lamar-odoms-aunt-talks-about-his-miraculous-recovery-w161122|title=Lamar Odom making remarkable strides|last=Chen|first=Joyce|work=[[Us Weekly]]|accessdate=February 9, 2016}} On January 8, 2016, Odom's paternal aunt JaNean Mercer told ''[[Us Weekly]]'' that "the former NBA star is on the road to recovery after finally leaving the hospital earlier in the week." She said "Lamar continues to make remarkable strides." In early 2016, Khloé Kardashian said "I'm just there to support and care for him. But he is doing amazing." However, on May 26, 2016, Kardashian filed for divorce again.{{cite web |url=http://hollywoodlife.com/2016/05/29/lamar-odom-wants-khloe-kardashian-back-stop-divorce/ |title=Lamar Odom plans to win Khloe back |last=Thompson |first=Avery |date=May 29, 2016 |website=[[hollywoodlife.com]] |access-date=May 30, 2016}} Their divorce was finalized in December 2016.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2016/12/10/entertainment/kardashian-odom-divorce-finalized-trnd/index.html|title=Khloe Kardashian, Lamar Odom divorce finalized|last=Preuss|first=Andrea|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=December 10, 2016|access-date=February 26, 2018}} In 2017, Odom spoke publicly about his health struggles, his cocaine addiction, and his recovery from that addiction;{{cite news|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2017/03/29/lamar-odom-regrets-affairs-says-cocaine-helped-end-career|title=Lamar Odom regrets affairs, says cocaine helped end career|publisher=Sports Illustrated|date=March 29, 2017|access-date=February 26, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theplayerstribune.com/lamar-odom-done-in-the-dark/|title=Done in the Dark|last=Odom|first=Lamar|publisher=The Players' Tribune|date=July 27, 2017|access-date=February 26, 2018}} he called himself a "'walking miracle'" who had "'cheated death'", and acknowledged that his past drug use had made "'the end of [his basketball] career come along a little faster'".{{cite news|url=https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/lamar-odom-says-hes-clean-now-opens-up-about-drug-addiction-brothel-incident-more/|title=Lamar Odom says he's clean now; opens up about drug addiction, brothel incident, more|last=Herbert|first=James|publisher=CBS Sports|date=March 29, 2017|access-date=February 26, 2018}} Odom has his own music and film production company, Rich Soil Entertainment. He appeared in a [[Taco Bell]] commercial with [[Charles Barkley]] during [[Super Bowl XLIV]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/mar/19/sports/la-sp-lakers-fyi-20100320 |title=Lakers forward Lamar Odom has commercial appeal |last1=Bresnahan |first1=Mike |date=March 19, 2010 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=August 7, 2010}} Additionally, Odom made a cameo on the second season of the HBO television series ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]''. Odom is noted for his fondness for candy. [[Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company|Wrigley]] made a replica of the [[Larry O'Brien Championship Trophy]] out of candy in celebration of the Lakers' victory in the [[2009 NBA Finals|2009 Finals]], and Odom's name is featured on the base.{{cite web|url=http://lakersblog.latimes.com/lakersblog/2009/06/lamar-odom-candy-larry-o-brien.html|title=The Finals, where delicious happens|work=latimes.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} In 2015, Odom was #1 on the [[Google Trends]] list for living people, which measures the highest spikes in traffic over a sustained period compared to the previous year.{{cite news|title=Here Are the 10 Most Popular People of the Year According to Google|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/celebs/news/g5237/most-searched-people-on-google-2015/|accessdate=16 December 2015|publisher=CosmoPolitan|date=December 16, 2015}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year !Title !Role !class="unsortable"|Notes |- | 1996 | ''[[Arli$$]]'' | {{Infobox company | name = '''Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation'''| | logo = [[File:Lorimar-Telepictures.svg|250px]] | fate = Purchased by [[Warner Communications]]| | successor = | hq_location = [[Culver City, California]], [[United States]] | type = [[Entertainment]]| | industry = [[Television production|Television]] and [[film production]], syndication, home video, television broadcasting| | foundation = April 21, 1986 | defunct = January 11, 1989 | key_people = | parent = [[Warner Communications]] }} '''Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation''' was an entertainment company established on April 21, 1986 with the merger of [[Lorimar Television|Lorimar Productions]] and [[Telepictures Corporation]]. Its assets included television production and [[television syndication|syndication]] (which operated under the Lorimar-Telepictures name), feature films, home video, and broadcasting. ==History== The merger of Lorimar-Telepictures was announced on October 7, 1985, by [[Merv Adelson]].[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0ewdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jmIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6143,4739853&dq=lorimar-telepictures&hl=en "Lorimar in Merger."] ''[[The Pittsburgh Press]]'' (October 7, 1985).[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1986/05/12/67553/index.htm "A TV TITAN WAGERS A WAD ON MOVIES Lorimar-Telepictures makes a ton of money producing and distributing such TV hits as Dallas and The People's Court. Unsatisfied, chief Merv Adelson is trying to expand in theatrical films. The profits are potentially huge -- but a lot less certain."] ''[[CNN Money]]'' (May 12, 1986). On April 21, 1986, the merger was complete. [[Lee Rich]], one of the other founders of Lorimar, sold his shares in 1986 and left the company. On January 11, 1989, Warner Communications acquired Lorimar-Telepictures after shaking off the hostile takeover of the company.{{cite news|title= Warner Completes Merger With Lorimar Telepictures|work= The Los Angeles Times|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1989-01-12/business/fi-413_1_lorimar-telepictures-corp|accessdate=2010-10-23}} ==List of programs produced/distributed by Lorimar-Telepictures== '''Note:''' All series listed here are now owned and distributed by [[Warner Bros. Television]] with a few exceptions. * ''[[The $1,000,000 Chance of a Lifetime]]'' * ''[[Aaron's Way]]'' (1988) * ''[[ALF (TV series)|ALF]]'' (1986–1989)Currently distributed by [[Lionsgate]]'s [[Debmar-Mercury]] under license from Alien Productions. * ''[[ALF: The Animated Series]]'' (1987–1989) * ''[[ALF Tales]]'' (1988–1989) * ''[[Alvin and the Chipmunks (1983 TV series)|Alvin and the revision.text:
'''Marc van der Chijs''' (born 11 October 1972, [[Arnhem]])<ref name="Chijs2007">{{citation|url=http://www.marc.cn/2007/10/birthday-party-spill-dinner-at-casa-13.html|date=2007-10-11|accessdate=2009-03-25|title=Birthday party @ Spill & Dinner at Casa 13|last=Chijs|first=Marc van der|periodical=Marc van der Chijs' Shanghaied Weblog}}</ref> is a business man and investor. Among others he was the co-founder, with [[Gary Wang]], of popular Chinese [[video hosting service|video sharing]] website [[Tudou.com]].<ref name="Trouw">{{citation|title=Het gewone leven op de site: De populairste website in China is gemaakt door de Nederlander Marc van der Chijs|periodical=[[Trouw]]|last=Lange|first=Henny de|date=2006-06-27|accessdate=2009-03-25|url=http://www.trouw.nl/achtergrond/deverdieping/article1309145.ece}}</ref> After moving to Canada in 2013 he became active in [[Bitcoin]] and [[blockchain]], among others founding [http://www.firstblock.capital First Block Capital], [http://www.hut8mining.com Hut 8 Mining], and [http://www.firstcoin.com FirstCoin.com]
==Career== Raised mostly in the [[Netherlands]], he lived in many different countries, including Curacao, Belgium, France, Germany, Indonesia, China, and Canada.<ref name="Ref_2008">{{citation|url=http://chijs.com/full_profile.php|title=Full profile|publisher=chijs.com|accessdate=2009-09-16|year=2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506060510/http://www.chijs.com/full_profile.php|archivedate=2009-05-06|df=}}</ref> From 1991 Van der Chijs studied business economics in [[Maastricht]], and then took a traineeship at [[Daimler-Benz]]; after working at their headquarters in [[Stuttgart]] as well as in [[Indonesia]], he moved to [[Beijing]] in 1999 to take up a position as senior controller for Daimler-Benz' China operations.<ref name="Intermediair">{{citation|url=http://www.intermediair.nl/artikel.jsp?id=1515165|periodical=Intermediar|title=Marc van der Chijs, oprichter van de Chinese YouTube: 'Als het eenmaal loopt, wil ik weer wat anders'|last=Oosterhout|first=Bart van|date=2008-07-28|accessdate=2009-03-25}}</ref> Soon after, he resigned from that position and began working as an independent consultant while also studying [[Chinese language|Chinese]] on the side.<ref name="Trouw"/>
In 2004, Van der Chijs's wife Grace Wang introduced him to Gary Wang, a former classmate of hers at [[Insead]].<ref name="Balfour2007">{{citation|title=You say Guanxi, I Say Schmoozing|url=http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/nov2007/gb2007118_431130.htm?chan=top+news_top+news+index_global+business|periodical=BusinessWeek|date=2007-11-08|accessdate=2009-03-25|last=Balfour|first=Frederik}}</ref> The two men established Tudou in [[Shanghai]] in 2005; van der Chijs was the one to suggest the name.<ref name="Trouw"/> {{asof|2008}}, van der Chijs has left more of the operation of Tudou to Gary Wang, who has taken up the [[chief executive officer]] position. Instead, van der Chijs concentrated on his responsibilities as CEO of Spil Games Asia, a Dutch internet games company.<ref name="Intermediair"/>
In 2013 Van der Chijs [http://money.cnn.com/2013/03/26/news/economy/china-business-pollution/index.html left China] and moved to Vancouver, where he became a managing partner in venture capital fund [http://xpcp.ca/team-2/marc-van-der-chijs/ CrossPacific Capital]. His main activities were in FinTech, with a focus on cryptocurrencies and blockchain technologies. In early 2017 Van der Chijs founded the [http://www.bcsc.bc.ca/News/News_Releases/2017/69_B_C__Securities_Commission_grants_landmark_bitcoin_investment_fund_manager_registration/ first registered cryptocurrency investment fund] in Canada, [http://firstblock.capital/ First Block Capital], and launched the first licensed Bitcoin fund in the world (FBC Bitcoin Trust). He also founded Initial Coin Offering investment bank [https://www.firstcoin.com/ First Coin Capital] that he sold to Mike Novogratz in January 2018 and the largest Bitcoin miner in North America [https://www.hut8mining.com/ Hut 8 Mining] that he took public in March 2018.
Since July 2013 he is also on the board of [http://www.marc.cn/2013/07/joining-the-sinolending-%E7%82%B9%E8%9E%8D%E7%BD%91-board.html Chinese P2P lending company Dianrong.com] (Sinolending) and in 2014 Van der Chijs co-founded the [http://www.uvamo.com/?page_id=3512 world's first P2P insurance company Uvamo.com]. Additionally, he is an advisor for Emercoin<ref>{{citation|title=Emercoin, Our Advisors|url=https://emercoin.com/en|publisher=emercoin.com|accessdate=2018-03-18|year=2018}}</ref>.
==Personal life== Van der Chijs was married to Grace Wang, Tudou's former [[chief financial officer]]. They have a son, Scott, born in 2007,<ref name="Intermediair"/> and a daughter, Elaine, born in 2009<ref name="Chijs2009">{{citation|url=http://www.marc.cn/2009/05/hello-world-elaine-van-der-chijs.html|date=2009-05-21|accessdate=2009-12-10|title=Hello world: Elaine van der Chijs|last=Chijs|first=Marc van der|periodical=Marc van der Chijs' Shanghaied Weblog}}</ref>. In his free time Van der Chijs is a sailor and skier. ==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.marc.cn Marc van der Chijs' personal weblog]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chijs, Marc Van Der}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Dutch expatriates in China]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Arnhem]]
{{Netherlands-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox politician |name = Narong Wongwan
ณรงค์ วงศ์วรรณ |honorific-prefix = |honorific-suffix = |nationality = [[Thailand|Thai]] |image = |office = [[Prime Minister of Thailand|Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand]] |term_start = 7 April 1992 |term_end = 9 June 1992 |primeminister = [[Suchinda Kraprayoon]] |office1 = [[Leader of the Opposition in House of Representatives of Thailand]] |term_start1 = 3 August 1988 |term_end1 = 9 December 1990 |primeminister1 = [[Chatichai Choonhavan]] |predecessor1 = [[Pol Rengprasertwit]] |successor1 = [[Bhichai Rattakul]] |office2 = [[Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives (Thailand)|Minister of Agriculture and Cooperatives]] |term_start2 = 7 May 1983 |term_end2 = 5 August 1986 |primeminister2 = [[Prem Tinsulanonda]] |predecessor2 = [[Chuan Leekpai]] |successor2 = [[Han Leelanon]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1925|12|25|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Phrae Province|Phrae]], Siam |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[United Thai Party]]
[[Solidarity Party (Thailand)|Solidarity Party]]
[[Justice Unity Party]]
[[Thai Nation Party]] |spouse = |profession = |alma_mater = |religion = |signature = ลายเซ็นณรงค์ วงศ์วรรณ.png ||width=}} '''Narong Wongwan''' ({{lang-th|ณรงค์ วงศ์วรรณ}}; born 25 December 1925) is a former [[Thailand|Thai]] [[Prime Minister-designate]], politician and tobacco industrialist. He was a long-term member of parliament representing [[Phrae Province|Phrae]], leader of the [[United Thai Party]] and the [[Justice Unity Party]]. He was publicly known as the "godfather" ''(jao pho)'' of Phrae{{Citation |author1=Pasuk Phongpaichit |author2=Sungsidh Piriyarangsan |title=Corruption & Democracy in Thailand |publisher=Silkworm Books |year=1996 |pages=80–81}}{{Citation |first=James |last=Ockey |title=Making Democracy: Leadership, Class, Gender, and Political Participation in Thailand |publisher=University of Hawai'i Press |year=2004 |pages=40, 203}} or even "godfather of the North".{{Citation |first=James P. |last=LoGerfo |title=Beyond Bangkok: The Provincial Middle Class in the 1992 Protests |work=Money & Power in Provincial Thailand |publisher=NIAS Publishing |year=2000 |page=232}}{{Citation |first=Guilhem |last=Fabre |title=Criminal Prosperity: Drug Trafficking, Money Laundering and Financial Crisis after the Cold War |publisher=Routledge |year=2003 |page=122}} == Life and career == Narong Wongwan was born in Phrae, where his grandfather had acquired a fortune from wood production. Narong studied economics in the United States. After working for the family's saw mill for some time, he went into tobacco growing and curing in the 1950s. During the 1970s the tobacco business in Northern Thailand boomed and Narong became a multi-millionaire. Many peasants of Phrae and the neighbouring provinces were employed on Narong's and his family's plantations and in their curing plants. Therefore, he accumulated considerable economic and social influence in the region. This was used by him as a base for his political career. Narong was a member of Phrae's provincial council as early as 1949. He founded the [[United Thai Party]] and was elected member of parliament in 1979. He was steadily re-elected in all elections until 1992. He joined the government of prime minister [[Prem Tinsulanonda]], becoming deputy interior minister in 1980, deputy minister of agriculture in 1981, rising to be minister in 1983. After the election of 1986, his party was in the opposition. In 1989, he merged his party with three minor parties and renamed it [[Solidarity Party (Thailand)|Solidarity Party]]. After a cabinet reshuffle, the party became part of [[Chatichai Choonhavan]]'s government coalition and Narong was again made minister of agriculture. After the coup d'état of 1991 and ahead of the [[Thai general election, March 1992|election in March 1992]], he joined with other provincial businessmen, bureaucrats and supporters of the military coup group to form the [[Justice Unity Party]], of which he became the chairman. The party won the election and Narong was designated prime minister, when media alleged that the United States had refused him entry admission due to the suspection of involvement in drug trafficking. The US government threatened that relations between the two countries could worsen in case that Narong became head of government.{{Citation |first=James |last=Ockey |title=The Rise of Local Power in Thailand: Provincial Crime, Elections and the Bureaucracy |work=Money & Power in Provincial Thailand |publisher=NIAS Publishing |year=2000 |page=89}} He had to relinquish premiership and the parliament instead nominated the putschist General [[Suchinda Kraprayoon]].{{Citation |first=James P. |last=LoGerfo |title=Beyond Bangkok: The Provincial Middle Class in the 1992 Protests |work=Money & Power in Provincial Thailand |publisher=NIAS Publishing |year=2000 |page=233}} Really, Narong had not been prosecuted as there was no sufficient evidence. As the leader of the biggest coalition party, Narong still became deputy prime minister under Suchinda. After the bloody crackdown on the oppositional movement protesting against the military-backed government, the Justice Unity Party was discredited and dissolved.{{Citation |author=Surin Maisrikrod |title=Thailand's Two General Elections in 1992: Democracy Sustained |publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies |year=1992 |page=24}} Narong instead joined the [[Thai Nation Party]]. After the party's electoral success in 1995, Narong was poised to become minister of interior, but again he was hindered by allegations of criminal activity. In 2000, Thailand's Supreme Court condemned the tabloid newspaper ''Khao Sot'' for spreading false allegations against Narong.{{Citation |first=David |last=Streckfuss |title=Truth on Trial in Thailand: Defamation, Treason, and Lèse-Majesté |publisher=Routledge |year=2011 |pages=171–172}} == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Wongwan, Narong}} [[Category:Thai businesspeople]] [[Category:Deputy Prime Ministers of Thailand]] [[Category:Government ministers of Thailand]] [[Category:Thai Nation Party politicians]] [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Justice Unity Party politicians]]

{{unreferenced|date=March 2014}} '''About Produce Marketing Association '''
The '''Produce Marketing Association''' ('''PMA''') is a global [[trade association]] whose 2200 members represent the full [[supply chain]] of the [[produce]] and mass-market floral industry, from seed producer to [[supermarket]] or [[foodservice]] outlet. It was founded in 1949. Mike O'Brien of Schnucks Markets in St. Louis, MO is the current chairman of the board of directors. The CEO is Bryan Silbermann, and the president is Cathy Burns. PMA sponsors an annual convention and exposition called Fresh Summit.
PMA has 2,900-member companies in 54 countries. The company focuses on the five-following member needs: Demand Creation, Global Connections, Science & Technology, Industry Talent and Sustainability.
<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pma.com/about-pma/history|title=History|website=www.pma.com|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref>'''History:''' Formed in 1949 during the inaugural National Conference on Prepackaging, PMA (then Produce Prepackaging Association) was led by Paul B. Dickman and aimed to revolutionize the produce industry by delivering member networking and educational opportunities.
In 1958, official headquarters moved from New York to Newark, Delaware, with Robert Carey as Executive Secretary. This marks a turning point for the organization.
The organization officially changed its name to Produce Marketing Association in 1970. This is when PMA created three operating division to address increasing member demand for services: retailer, producer and distributor.
In 1974 PMA joined the floral industry when it formed the Floral Marketing Division to represent mass-market floral members.
The Produce Electronic Identification Board (PEIB) was created by PMA in 1987 to administer standardized Price Look-Up (PLU) codes. The following year, in 1988, PMA joined with United Fresh & Vegetable Association to establish the Center for Produce Quality.
In 1989 Bob Carey became President of PMA after three decades of service to the association.
PMA.com was launched in 1995, establishing the association as an online destination for produce industry members. By taking advantage of new communications technologies to connect to members worldwide, the association could now provide 24-hour access to information and create a virtual trade show.
In 1996 Bryan Silbermann succeeded Bob Carey as President and CEO. During his time with PMA Bryan Silbermann helped standardize PLU/UPC codes, spearheaded the Produce Traceability Initiative (PTI), began the import-export committee that became the International Trade Committee to Global Strategy and Development committees. Silbermann also helped institute the Produce for Better Health (PBH) program, FNV, Center for Produce Quality, Center for Produce Safety and Partnership for Food Safety Education, along with many other achievements during his time with PMA.
PMA initiated the Pack Family/Career Pathways Program in 2004, which would later be re-named the Center for Growing Talent.
In 2017 Cathy Burns succeeded Bryan Silbermann as CEO of PMA. Burns currently holds the CEO position at PMA.
== References == [http://producenews.com/the-produce-news-today-s-headlines/19298-innovate-today-for-tomorrow-s-success]<references/>
[[Category:Business organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Food industry trade groups]] [[Category:Marketing in the United States]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Cleveland Public Square | image = File:Public Square (Cleveland).jpg | location = Superior Avenue and Ontario Street
[[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] 44106 | locmapin = United States Cleveland#Ohio#USA | coordinates = {{coord|41|29|59|N|81|41|38|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built = 1857-1861 | architect = | architecture = | added = December 18, 1975 | designated_other1_name= | designated_other1_date= | designated_other1_abbr= | designated_other1_link= Cleveland Landmark | designated_other1_color= #aaccff | refnum = 75001361{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/oh/Cuyahoga/districts.html |title= Ohio(OH), Cuyahoga County |accessdate=July 11, 2011 |work=National Register of Historic Places |publisher=Nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com}} | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Cleveland Public Parks District]] }} '''Public Square''' is the two-block (formerly four-block) [[town square|central plaza]] of [[downtown Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]. Based on an 18th-century [[New England]] model, it was part of the original 1796 town [[plat]] overseen by [[Moses Cleaveland]], and remains today as an integral part of the city's center. The {{convert|10|acre|ha|adj=on}} square is centered on the former intersection of [[U.S. Route 6 in Ohio|Superior Avenue]] and [[U.S. Route 422|Ontario Street]].{{cite web |url=http://ech.case.edu/ech-cgi/article.pl?id=PS6 |title=Public Square |work=The Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]] |date=July 30, 1999 |accessdate=November 8, 2012}} Cleveland's three tallest buildings, [[Key Tower]], [[200 Public Square]] and the [[Terminal Tower]], face the square. Other Public Square landmarks include the 1855 [[Old Stone Church (Cleveland)|Old Stone Church]] and the former [[Higbee's]] department store made famous in the 1983 film ''[[A Christmas Story]]'', which reopened as the [[Jack Cleveland Casino|Horseshoe Casino Cleveland]] on May 14, 2012. The square was redeveloped in 2016 by the city into a more pedestrian-friendly environment with green space on the northern half of the square, a hard surface on the southern half of the square, and transit lanes on a newly constructed Superior Avenue (which is open only to bus traffic). A {{convert|125|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} [[Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument (Cleveland)|monument to Civil War soldiers and sailors]] occupies the southeast section of the square. City founder [[Moses Cleaveland]] and reformist mayor [[Tom L. Johnson]] each have statues on the square. ==History== [[File:Public square postcard.jpg|thumb|right|Postcard of Public Square in the 1910s]] Public Square was part of the [[Connecticut Land Company]]'s original plan for the city, which were overseen by [[Moses Cleaveland]] in the 1790s. The square is signature of the layout for early New England towns, which Cleveland was modeled after. While it initially served as a common pasture for settlers' animals, less than a century later Public Square was the height of modernity, when in 1879 it became the first street in the world to be lit with electric [[street light]]s, [[arc lamp]]s designed by Cleveland native [[Charles F. Brush]]. The square was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on December 18, 1975. A parking lot now faces the northwest quadrant of the square. A 12-story building, which was built on the spot in 1913, was demolished in 1990 to make way for the new Ameritrust Center, an {{convert|1197|ft|m|adj=on}} [[skyscraper]] designed by New York's [[Kohn Pedersen Fox]].[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=103095 Emporis.com: Ameritrust Center]. Accessed December 15, 2006. Before construction began, Ameritrust was acquired by [[Key Bank|Society Bank]], which was also planning to construct and subsequently relocate to a new building on Public Square—Key Tower (formerly known as Society Center). Because Society did not need two skyscrapers, plans for the Ameritrust building across the square were scrapped. Other buildings that face the square include [[55 Public Square]] (1958), [[75 Public Square]] (1915), the [[Society for Savings Building]] (1890), [[Metzenbaum Courthouse]] (1910), the former [[May Company Ohio|May Company]] department store (1914), the [[Park Building (Cleveland, Ohio)|Park Building]] (1903), and the [[Renaissance Cleveland Hotel]] (1918). The demolished [[Cuyahoga Building]] (1893) and [[Williamson Building]] (1900) formerly stood on the site of 200 Public Square. Public Square is often the site of political rallies and civic functions, including a free annual [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] concert by the [[Cleveland Orchestra]]. At the [[Balloonfest '86]], close to 1.5 million balloons rose up from Public Square, engulfing the Terminal Tower and setting a world record.{{cite news | url=http://www.cleveland.com/remembers/index.ssf/2011/08/balloonfest_1986_the_spectacle.html | title=Balloonfest 1986, the spectacle that became a debacle: Cleveland Remembers | work= [[The Plain Dealer]] |location= Cleveland | date=August 15, 2011 | accessdate=March 15, 2014 | author=Kroll, John}} ===2010s renovation=== In collaboration with landscape architect [[James Corner]], the city in 2009 began to explore concepts for a redesign of the square.{{cite web |title=Redesigning Public Square |url=http://www.downtownclevelandalliance.com/page/Public-Square.aspx?parent=34 |publisher=Downtown Cleveland Alliance |accessdate=January 9, 2010}}{{cite news |first=Steven |last=Litt |title=Re-imagining Cleveland's Public Square |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/architecture/2009/12/reimagining_clevelands_public.html |work= The Plain Dealer |location= Cleveland |date=December 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 9, 2010}} In October 2011, Cleveland mayor [[Frank G. Jackson|Frank Jackson]] proposed his plan to redevelop the square, which included closing Superior Avenue and Ontario Street to create a large green space in the center.{{cite news |first=Steven |last=Litt |title=Cleveland Mayor Frank Jackson envisions unified Public Square as symbol of greener city |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/architecture/2011/10/cleveland_mayor_frank_jackson.html |work=The Plain Dealer |location= Cleveland |date=October 29, 2011 |accessdate=November 23, 2011}} On October 23, 2014, the Cleveland Landmarks Commission approved a plan which closed Ontario Street but kept Superior Avenue open to bus traffic, and kept the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument prominent.{{cite news |first=Michelle |last=Jarboe McFee |title=Public Square overhaul gets OK from Cleveland Landmarks Commission, after truce over Soldiers and Sailors Monument |url=http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2014/10/public_square_overhaul_gets_ok.html |work=The Plain Dealer |location= Cleveland |date=October 23, 2014 |accessdate=October 24, 2014 }}{{cite web |title=Cleveland Public Square |url=http://www.fieldoperations.net/project-details/project/cleveland-public-square.html |publisher=James Corner Field Operations |accessdate=October 24, 2014}} The project began construction on March 9, 2015,{{cite news |first=Steven |last=Litt |title=It's official: Public Square renovation to launch Monday, March 9 |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/03/its_official_public_square_ren.html |work=The Plain Dealer |location= Cleveland |date=March 2, 2015 |accessdate=March 3, 2015 }} and was officially opened on June 30, 2016.{{cite news |first=Steven |last=Litt |title=Ceremony Marks Official Opening of Public Square with Music, Dancing and Water|url=http://www.cleveland.com/architecture/index.ssf/2016/06/ceremony_marks_official_openin.html |work=The Plain Dealer |location= Cleveland |date=June 30, 2016 |accessdate=July 1, 2016 }} Public Square's development was showcased during the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] championship parade as a welcome sight with much of the construction materials removed to display the renovation. At first, buses did not run along Superior Avenue as planned,{{cite news|first=Ginger|last=Christ|title=Cleveland opts to keep Public Square closed to buses|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2016/11/cleveland_announcement_on_publ.html|work=The Plain Dealer|date=November 15, 2016|access-date=November 15, 2016}} but in order to avoid a $12 million repayment of grants to the [[Federal Transit Administration]], the [[Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority]] agreed to run buses along it by March 2017.{{cite news |first=Ginger |last=Christ |title=Breaking down the Public Square bus debate: Q & A |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2017/03/breaking_down_the_public_squar.html |work=The Plain Dealer |location= Cleveland |date=March 7, 2017 |accessdate=January 1, 2018}} An episode of NBC's American Ninja Warrior was held in Public Square and aired in July 2017{{cite news|first=Ginger|last=Christ|title=RTA hopes to reopen Public Square to buses by March 6|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2017/02/rta_plans_to_reopen_public_squ.html|work=The Plain Dealer|date=February 21, 2017|access-date=February 22, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Christ |first=Ginger|date=August 16, 2016|title=Federal agency says closed Public Square is a violation of funding deal |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2016/08/federal_agency_says_closed_pub.html|work=The Plain Dealer|access-date=August 18, 2016}} A privately operated cafe, Rebol, located in the southwestern area of Public Square, opened in July 2016.{{cite news| last=Trattner | first=Douglas |title=Rebol at Public Square Unveils Concept and Menu |url=https://www.clevescene.com/scene-and-heard/archives/2016/06/24/rebol-at-public-square-unveils-concept-and-menu |work=The Cleveland Scene |date=June 24, 2016 |access-date=January 1, 2018}} ==Transportation== ===Road=== Public Square is bounded by East Roadway and West Roadway at the western and eastern ends and by Rockwell Avenue and South Roadway at the northern and southern ends. In total, ten U.S. and state routes meet at Public Square. It is the northern terminus of [[Ohio State Route 3|SR 3]], [[Ohio State Route 8|SR 8]], and [[Ohio State Route 43|SR 43]]; the western terminus of [[U.S. Route 322|US 322]], [[U.S. Route 422|US 422]], [[Ohio State Route 14|SR 14]], and [[Ohio State Route 87|SR 87]]; and the northeastern terminus of [[U.S. Route 42|US 42]]. [[U.S. Route 6 in Ohio|US 6]] passes through the square on Superior, and [[U.S. Route 20 in Ohio|US 20]] enters from the west on Superior and leaves via [[Euclid Avenue (Cleveland, Ohio)|Euclid Avenue]]. [[U.S. Route 21#History|US 21]] also terminated at Public Square until that route was truncated to [[Marietta, Ohio|Marietta]] in 1967.{{Ohio road map|year=1967}}{{AASHTO minutes|year=1967A|page=6|link=y}} ===Public transit=== Public Square is adjacent to the [[Tower City station|Tower City transit station]], served by three [[Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority|RTA]] rail lines. The [[HealthLine]], a [[bus rapid transit]] line that travels along [[Euclid Avenue (Cleveland, Ohio)|Euclid Avenue]], terminates at Public Square.{{cite map |date=February 11, 2015 |title=Public Square Bus Stops |url=http://www.riderta.com/sites/default/files/pdf/major-projects/PublicSquare/Public-Square-Stop-Map.pdf |publisher=Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority |accessdate=August 18, 2016}} ==Historical Events and Popular Culture== * On April 28, 1865, [[Funeral and burial of Abraham Lincoln|the casket of President Abraham Lincoln]] was on public view in Public Square during his body's trip back to Illinois. * On the evening of April 29, 1879, [[Charles F. Brush]]'s new streetlights lit up Public Square for the first time utilizing a generator situated near the Square itself.http://teachingcleveland.org/12-most-significant-events-in-cleveland-history/https://case.edu/ech/articles/p/public-square * In 1881, President [[James A. Garfield]] lies in state in Public Square following his deathhttps://case.edu/ech/timeline * In 2011, Public Square was transformed into a beer garden and street scene in [[Stuttgart]], [[Germany]], for the filming of [[The Avengers (2012 film)|The Avengers]].{{cite news |last=Sangiacomo |first=Michael |date=23 August 2011 |title=Avengers filming moves to Public Square |url=http://s.cleveland.com/QEqxQ2G |work=The Plain Dealer |location=Cleveland, Ohio |access-date=27 June 2018 }} ==Gallery== [[File:Public Square 1912.jpg|thumb|450px|center|Public Square in 1912, facing east. The Old Stone Church is the third building on the left. The Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument is on the right, in front of the Williamson Building, which was later demolished for 200 Public Square.]] File:Public_Square,_Cleveland.jpg|alt=Public Square in 2016|Public Square in 2016 facing west on Superior Avenue's vehicle-free bus/bike lanes File:Looking north.jpg|The north side of Public Square in 2012 File:Rally to end Family Separation Cleveland.jpg|Rally against [[Protests against Trump administration family separation policy|family separation]] in Public Square (June 30, 2018) ==See also== *[[Tower City Center]] *[[The Mall (Cleveland)|The Mall]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book |first=Eric |last=Johannesen |title=From Town to Tower |publisher=[[Western Reserve Historical Society]] |year=1983 |isbn=978-0-911704-31-0}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline}} [[Category:Squares in Cleveland]] [[Category:Urban public parks]] [[Category:Historic districts in Cleveland]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Cleveland, Ohio]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Cleveland]] [[Category:U.S. Route 6]] [[Category:U.S. Route 20]] [[Category:U.S. Route 42]] [[Category:U.S. Route 322]] [[Category:Downtown Cleveland]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Ohio]] [[Category:U.S. Route 21]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Ramiro L. Colón | image = Ramiro Colon.JPG |imagesize = 200px | caption = Credited with saving the coffee industry in Puerto Rico | birth_date = 1904 | birth_place = [[Ponce, Puerto Rico]] | death_date = 1983
Ponce, Puerto Rico | nationality = [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] | occupation = General Manager of the [[Cafe Rico|Cooperativa de Cafeteros de Puerto Rico]] (1925–1965)
Senator (1952-1965) | salary = | networth = | spouse = | children = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Ramiro L. Colón''' (1904–1983), was the general manager of the [[Cafe Rico|Cooperativa de Cafeteros de Puerto Rico]]. He reorganized the company during its time of crisis and is credited with having saved the [[coffee]] [[industry]] in [[Puerto Rico]]. ==Early years== Colón (birth name: '''Ramiro L. Colón Colón'''{{Spanish name|'''Colón'''|'''Colón'''|plain=yes}}[http://bibliotecadigital.uprrp.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/ELM4068&CISOPTR=1043&CISOBOX=1&REC=4 ''Senador Ramiro L. Colón junto a panel que discutió sobre cooperativas agrícolas.''] Biblioteca Digital Puertorriqueña. Retrieved 13 October 2011.[http://www.de.gobierno.pr/sites/de.gobierno.pr/files/report-card/52548_Perfil.pdf ''Perfil Escolar de la Escuela Elemental Ramiro Colón Colón.'']{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Puerto Rico Department of Education. San Juan, Puerto Rcio. 16 March 2010. Retrieved 13 October 2011.), was born in and raised in the countryside of [[Ponce, Puerto Rico]]. There he received his [[primary education|primary]] and [[secondary education]]. Being raised in the country, he developed an intense love for the island's [[agriculture]]. He went to work for the "Cooperativa de Cafeteros de Puerto Rico" ([[Cooperative]] of Coffee Growers of Puerto Rico) in 1925, the same year it was founded, at the age of 21. =="Cooperativa de Cafeteros de Puerto Rico"== The cooperative was the first one of its kind in Puerto Rico. It was founded to protect the coffee industry, which was one of the island's most important [[export]] [[product (business)|product]]s, from outside imitators. The situation was the following: many [[merchant]]s were importing coffee from other countries, of poor quality and freshness, and passing them off as locally produced. When tourists and local consumers tasted the coffee, they complained about how bad it was, and as a result sales declined drastically and the coffee industry suffered greatly.[http://www.caferico.com/history-frames.htm Company History] In 1928, [[1928 Okeechobee Hurricane|hurricane San Felipe]] destroyed most of the coffee [[plantation]]s on the island, and the [[Great Depression]] also affected the economy. ==Colón becomes general manager== In 1932, Colón was named general manager of the cooperative and undertook the reorganization of the company during its time of crisis. The cooperative was almost [[bankrupt]], and the first thing Colón did was to obtain a loan from the Department of Agriculture and [[Commerce]]. With the money, he bought new equipment to replace the old and outdated equipment in the company. Colón was able to convince the Puerto Rican [[legislature]] to pass a law against the then-rampant [[adulteration]] and [[contraband]] of coffee. =="Cafe Rico"== Colón was credited with convincing the government to impose [[import tariff]]s on coffee, thereby ensuring the island would not be invaded by cheap coffee of poor quality, which often was advertised as locally produced. The cooperative purchased and installed a new [[torrefaction]] [[physical plant|plant]] in which the local coffee was processed. Colon set out to gain access to the United States coffee market, helped the local coffee growers obtain lines of [[credit (finance)|credit]] from local bankers, and got financial help from the [[Federal government of the United States|federal]] and [[local government]] for the export of the cooperative's coffee. This coffee was named "[[Cafe Rico]]" and was well received locally and internationally, soon reestablishing the good fame of Puerto Rico's coffee worldwide. The cooperative became the first coffee manufacturer to sell its coffee in sealed cans. The quality of Cafe Rico has received numerous medals and recognitions in contests celebrated all over the world. Colón established the only coffee tasting [[laboratory]] in Puerto Rico. One of Cafe Rico's byproducts, "San Carlos Selection", is the official coffee of [[Vatican City]]. ==Cooperative expansion== Under Colon's leadership, the cooperative was able to expand and diversify. The company sells food and agricultural equipment with sales of over $5 million. It also owns and operates an [[egg (food)|egg]] processing company which calls its product "Huevos Rico" (Rico Eggs). The cooperative owns an [[insurance]] company, its own credit [[corporation]] that grants loans to [[farmer]]s, and its own [[printing]] plant that prints and distributes an agricultural [[magazine]] worldwide. Recently, the cooperative has started to operate [[gasoline station]]s in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]], [[Mayaguez, Puerto Rico|Mayaguez]] and Ponce. When Colón took over the company in 1932 as a general manager the cooperative had only $284,000 in annual sales. By 1963 the cooperative had over $35,000,000 in sales. The cooperative has [[office]]s and [[warehouse]]s in Ponce (main offices), San Juan, Mayagüez, [[Arecibo, Puerto Rico|Arecibo]], [[Yauco, Puerto Rico|Yauco]], [[San Sebastián, Puerto Rico|San Sebastian]], [[Utuado, Puerto Rico|Utuado]], [[Adjuntas, Puerto Rico|Adjuntas]], [[Jayuya, Puerto Rico|Jayuya]] and [[Ciales, Puerto Rico|Ciales]]. ==Legacy== Colón served as a senator, representing the district of Ponce in the [[Puerto Rican Senate]] and was named [[Administration (business)|Administrator]] of the cooperative, a position he held until his retirement in 1965. In 1952 the [[Constitution of Puerto Rico]] was adopted, creating the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and Colón was a member of the [[Constitutional Convention of Puerto Rico]]. He was a delegate to [[Republican National Convention]] from Puerto Rico in the years 1948, 1952 and 1956.[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/collinsworth-combest.html#0091EV93A Political Graveyard] Ramiro L. Colón was candidate for governor in 1968 for the Republican Statehood Party. Ramiro L. Colón died in the city of [[Ponce, Puerto Rico|Ponce]], which honored his memory by naming an elementary school after him. He is remembered as the man who saved the Puerto Rican coffee industry. ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Biography}} *[[List of famous Puerto Ricans]] {{Clear}} ==Notes== ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.caferico.com/history-frames.htm Company History] {{DEFAULTSORT:Colon, Ramiro L.}} [[Category:1904 births]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:Puerto Rican businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Ponce]] [[Category:Cooperative organisers]]

{{Infobox person | birthname = Robert Arthur Bernhard | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1928}} | birth_place = New York City | education = [[Williams College]] (BA/BS)
[[Harvard University]] (MBA) | employer = | title = Former [[Partner (business rank)|Partner]] of [[Lehman Brothers]] and [[Salomon Brothers]] | salary = | networth = | nationality = United States | predecessor = | successor = | boards = [[Montefiore Medical Center]], [[Congregation Emanu-El of New York]], [[Lincoln Center Institute]], [[Albert Einstein College of Medicine]], [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[Cooper Union]] | ethnicity = | parents = Richard Jaques Bernhard
[[Dorothy Lehman Bernhard]] | spouse = Frances Wells
Joan Mack Sommerfield | partner = | children = 4 | family = [[Adele Lewisohn Lehman]] (grandmother) }} '''Robert Arthur Bernhard''' (born 1928) is an American banker best known as the last [[Lehman Brothers]] descendant to serve as partner of the firm.{{cite news |author=Brostoff, Marissa| url=http://forward.com/news/14237/the-lehmans-they-ve-moved-on-sad-a-little-02554/ |date=September 18, 2008 |accessdate=28 March 2016|title=The Lehmans? They've moved on. Sad? A little |newspaper=[[The Forward]]}} ==Life and career== Bernhard was born in 1928 to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family in New York City, the son of Richard Jaques Bernhard and [[Dorothy Lehman Bernhard]].Rosenberg, Jennifer [https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/bernhard-dorothy-lehman Jewish Women's Archive: "Dorothy Lehman Bernhard (1903 – 1969)"]. Retrieved January 28, 2017 He graduated from [[Williams College]] in 1951 and the [[Harvard School of Business]] in 1953. Bernhard joined Lehman Brothers in 1953, and became General Partner in 1962. At Lehman Brothers, Bernhard was Head of Investment Management Division and served on the Boards of the Lehman Corporation and the One William Street Fund. Bernhard left Lehman Brothers in 1972, becoming a partner at Salomon Brothers in 1974 until its merger with Phibro in 1981.{{cite news | title = Merger of Salomon Impresses Analysts | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/business/merger-of-salomon-impresses-analysts.html | first=Karen | last=Arenson | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = August 5, 1981}} In 1981, he opened his own firm, Bernhard & Associates.{{cite news | title = Life After Salomon Brothers | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/business/life-after-salomon-brothers.html | first=William | last=Glaberson | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = October 11, 1987}} In 1990 it merged with Orson Munn & Company to create Munn, Bernhard & Associates (MB Investment Partners). In 1997 he became a partner of McFarland Dewey & Company.{{cite web | title = Robert A. Bernhard | url = http://www.cooper.edu/about/trustees/robert-bernhard | website = [[Cooper Union]] }}{{cite web | title = Robert A. Bernhard: Executive Profile & Biography | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=667755&privcapId=23135629 | publisher = Bloomberg }} Bernhard is a Life Trustee of [[Congregation Emanu-El of New York|Temple Emanu-El]] in Manhattan, New York City, after having previously served as its President.[http://www.emanuelnyc.org/simple.php/about_staff2 "Staff"] [[Congregation Emanu-El of New York|Temple Emanu-El]] website He also serves on the boards of the [[Montefiore Medical Center]] and its [[Albert Einstein College of Medicine]] and is a Trustee of the [[Lincoln Center Institute]]. He was a Director of [[Medscape|Medscape LLC]] and, from 1993 to 2011, of [[Stone Energy Corporation]]. ===Cooper Union=== Bernhard was chairman of the board of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art from 1995 to 2004 and served on the board of trustees from 1975 until 2016. He was responsible for choosing [[George Campbell Jr.]] as successor to [[John Jay Iselin]] as president of the school.{{cite news | title = Cooper Union Picks Physicist as First Black President | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/18/nyregion/cooper-union-picks-physicist-as-first-black-president.html | first=Lynette | last=Holloway | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = November 18, 1999}} A friend of [[Jerry Speyer]], Bernhard was involved in the [[Tishman Speyer]] bid to take over management of the [[Chrysler Building]], the land under which is Cooper Union's biggest asset, by agreeing to Tishman's proposal for a new lease for the building.{{cite news | title = New York's Cultural Power Brokers; Mixing the Real Estate Business and Everyone's Pleasure | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/02/arts/new-york-s-cultural-power-brokers-mixing-real-estate-business-everyone-s.html | first1=Robin | last1=Pogrebin | first2=Charles | last2=Bagli |lastauthoramp=yes| newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = June 2, 2004}} ==Personal life== In 1949, he married Frances Wells; they had 4 children: Adele, Michael, Susan, Steven. In 1970, he married Joan Mack Sommerfield.{{Cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|title= Mrs. Joan Sommerfield Is Wed In Suburbs to Robert Bernhard |publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=August 2, 1970 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1970/08/02/archives/article-1-no-title.html |accessdate=March 23, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bernhard, Robert A.}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:Jewish American bankers]] [[Category:American chief executives of financial services companies]] [[Category:American corporate directors]] [[Category:American financial traders]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:American chief operating officers]] [[Category:Lehman Brothers people]] [[Category:Cooper Union]] [[Category:American bankers]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Williams College alumni]] [[Category:Lehman family]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox Politician | name =Robert Bonner | image = | caption = |birth_name= | birth_date ={{birth date|1920|9|10}} | birth_place = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] | death_date={{Death date and age|2005|8|12|1920|9|10}} | death_place=[[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] | constituency_AM1 = [[Cariboo (provincial electoral district)|Cariboo]] | assembly1 = British Columbia Legislative | term_start1 = November 28, 1966 | term_end1 = July 22, 1969 | predecessor1 = [[William C. Speare]] | successor1 = [[Alex Fraser (politician)|Alex Fraser]] | constituency_AM2 = [[Vancouver-Point Grey]] | assembly2 = British Columbia Legislative | alongside2 = [[Thomas Audley Bate]] (1953-1963)
[[Arthur Laing]] (1953-1956)
[[Buda Hosmer Brown|Buda Brown]] (1956-1962)
[[Pat McGeer]] (1962-1966)
[[Ralph Raymond Loffmark|Ralph Loffmark]] (1963-1966) | term_start2 = June 9, 1953 | term_end2 = September 12, 1966 | predecessor2 = [[George Clark Miller]] | successor2 = [[Garde Gardom]] | constituency_AM3 = [[Columbia (electoral district)|Columbia]] | assembly3 = British Columbia Legislative | term_start3 = November 24, 1952 | term_end3 = June 9, 1953 | predecessor3 = [[Richard Orr Newton]] | successor3 = [[Richard Orr Newton]] | party =[[British Columbia Social Credit Party|Social Credit]] | religion = | profession = Lawyer | residence = | spouse = | children = }} '''Robert Bonner''', [[LL.B.]] (September 10, 1920 – August 12, 2005) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[lawyer]], [[politician]], and [[corporation|corporate]] executive. He pursued his career working in the [[British Columbia]] government and in B.C.-based companies. Bonner was born and raised in [[Vancouver]], and served with the [[Seaforth Highlanders]] in [[Italy]] in the [[Second World War]]. Upon his return to Canada, Bonner took a law degree from the [[University of British Columbia]] in 1948, and joined a practice in [[Vancouver]]. Active in politics from an early age, Bonner became a supporter and confidant of [[W.A.C. Bennett]], who would go on to lead the [[British Columbia Social Credit Party|Social Credit Party]] to victory in the [[British Columbia general election, 1952|1952 provincial election]]. To the surprise of many, Bennett appointed the unelected, 32 year-old Bonner as the province's [[Attorney General of British Columbia|Attorney General]] — the youngest in B.C.'s history. Bonner would be elected to represent the riding of [[Vancouver-Point Grey]] in the [[British Columbia general election, 1953|provincial election of 1953]], which was also the first Social Credit majority government in the province. He would retain the position of Attorney General for the next sixteen years, quickly becoming one of the most powerful ministers and closest advisors to Bennett in the Socreds' long spell of governance. Bonner's tenure as Attorney General was marked by legal clashes with [[First Nations]] tribes over land and resource rights, especially in light of the rapid [[hydroelectric]], [[mining]], and [[forestry]] development of the province's hinterland. Perhaps more significantly, from a historical perspective, was the provincial government's conflicts with the [[Freedomites|Sons Of Freedom]], an anti-government sect of [[Doukhobors]] resident in the [[Kootenays|Kootenay]] region of the province. Clashes over [[public education]] led to the apprehension en masse of Freedomite children, and their confinement in government schools. During his time in cabinet, Bonner also served at various times concurrently as Minister of Education and Minister of Trade and Commerce. In the [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia|legislature]], Bonner proved capable, serving as Bennett's [[House Leader]]. Contemporaries described him as "articulate, urbane, and always well prepared, with a demonstrated air of superiority and a ready laugh."[http://www.parl.gc.ca/Infoparl/english/issue.htm?param=104&art=516] Bonner left provincial politics in 1968 to become vice-president of [[MacMillan Bloedel]], a Vancouver-based [[logging]] and [[lumber]] company. He would later go on to become the firm's president and [[chief executive officer]]. Bonner left Mac Blo in 1976 to become chairman of [[BC Hydro]], the provincial [[crown corporation]] responsible for producing and supplying hydroelectric power. He retired from that position in 1985. Bonner died in Vancouver in 2005. ==Cabinet Positions== {{s-start}} {{Canadian federal ministry navigational box header |ministry=WAC_Bennett}} {{ministry box cabinet posts | post4preceded = [[William Kenneth Kiernan]] | post4 = Minister of Commercial Transport | post4years = March 20, 1964–May 27, 1968 | post4note = | post4followed = [[Frank Richter Jr.|Frank Richter]] | post3preceded = ''Ministry Established'' | post3 = Minister of Industrial Development, Trade and Commerce | post3years = March 28, 1957–March 20, 1964 | post3note = | post3followed = [[Ralph Raymond Loffmark]] | post2preceded = [[Tilly Rolston]] | post2 = Minister of Education | post2years = October 19, 1953–April 14, 1954 | post2note = | post2followed = [[Ray Williston]] | post1preceded = [[Gordon Wismer]] | post1 = [[Attorney General of British Columbia]] | post1years = August 1, 1952–May 27, 1968 | post1note = | post1followed = [[Leslie Peterson]] }} {{s-end}} ==References== *''Encyclopedia of British Columbia''. Vancouver:Harbour Publishing, 2001. *David Mitchell, [http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/Infoparl/english/issue.asp?param=104&art=516 "The Good Old Days? W. A. C. Bennett and the Legislative Assembly"], in the ''Canadian Parliamentary Review'', vol. 6, 1983. {{WAC Bennett Ministry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bonner, Robert}} [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:Attorneys General of British Columbia]] [[Category:British Army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:British Columbia Social Credit Party MLAs]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Vancouver]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of the Executive Council of British Columbia]] [[Category:Peter A. Allard School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Politicians from Vancouver]] [[Category:Lawyers in British Columbia]] [[Category:20th-century Canadian politicians]]

In September 2006, the [[Financial Accounting Standards Board]] (FASB) of the United States issued '''Statement of Financial Accounting Standards 157''': Fair Value Measurements<ref>[http://www.fasb.org/pdf/aop_FAS157.pdf SFAS No. 157]</ref>), which “defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in [[generally accepted accounting principles]] (GAAP), and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.” This statement is effective for financial reporting fiscal periods commencing after November 15, 2007 and the interim periods applicable.
==Defining "fair value"== Paragraph 5 of SFAS No. 157 (now known as ASC 820 in the updated FASB Codification) defines fair value as “the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.” Of note, this Statement requires consideration of the exit price paid (if liability) or received (if asset) in a hypothetical transaction in an orderly market (i.e., not a forced liquidation or sold under duress).
This Statement also introduces two more concepts to the definition of fair value – the Principal (or Most Advantageous) Market and Highest and Best Use.
Principal (or Most advantageous) Market – Fair Value Measurement assumes the hypothetical transaction occurs in a principal market, “the market in which the reporting entity would sell the asset or transfer the liability with the greatest volume and level of activity for the asset or liability.” In the absence of a principal market, the asset or liability is assumed to be transferred in the most advantageous market, “the market in which the reporting entity would sell the asset or transfer the liability with the price that maximizes the amount that would be received for the asset or minimizes the amount that would be paid to transfer the liability, considering transaction costs in the respective market(s).”
Highest and Best Use – Fair Value Measurement assumes the asset is being utilized in a manner that will maximize its value. For example, where a company owns a factory, but the property would have a higher value as a residential lot, the asset should be fair valued as a residential lot.
==Establishing a framework for measuring fair value== The concept of the Fair Value Hierarchy there for is introduced in paragraphs 22 through 31 in SFAS No. 157. To provide the financial statement user with more insight into the valuation techniques and to create comparability among financial statements, SFAS No. 157 requires the fair value assets and liabilities to be allocated to [[Wikinvest:Level_1,_Level_2,_Level_3_Assets | different levels or hierarchies]] based on the transparencies of the inputs to valuing the assets/liabilities.
Level 1, the highest on the hierarchy, indicates assets/liabilities with the most transparent and tangible valuation techniques. A Level 1 financial instrument typically has quoted prices and active markets – for example, an equity stock. This type of instrument has the most verifiable and reliable fair value measurement.
Level 2 instruments require more involvement in valuing than Level 1 instruments. Level 2 “inputs are inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly.” For example, an interest rate swap uses known, public data, such as interest rates and the contract terms can be used to calculate a value of the interest rate swap. The instrument can be valued indirectly using observable data. Another example would be using quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets.
Level 3 is the most unobservable of the levels and indicates use of valuation techniques and data that may not be verifiable. These types of instruments involve a great deal of assumptions and estimates. Examples may include infrequently traded asset backed securities or investments in privately owned companies
==Expanding disclosures== SFAS No. 157, paragraph 32 requires two main types of disclosures – a Fair Value Balance Sheet and a Level 3 Rollforward.
The Fair Value Balance Sheet is similar to a typical balance sheet by disclosing the value of the assets and liabilities as of a specific date. However, the Fair Value Balance Sheet only includes financial instruments and uses fair value (concept defined above) as of a specific date. Additionally, the Fair Value Balance Sheet is segregated into the three fair value hierarchies described above – Level 1, Level 2, and Level 3.
The Level 3 Rollforward reconciles the Level 3 balances for assets and liabilities from the prior reporting period to the current reporting period. This reconciliation must include the total gains and losses (realized and unrealized) for the period, the purchase, sales, issuances, and settlements (net), the transfers in and/or out of Level 3. These components should reconcile the prior period’s balance to the current period’s balance.
These are the two main tables disclosed, but additional information is required such as description of the valuation techniques, significant transfers between levels, etc. Additionally, various regulatory bodies, such as the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC), [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] (AICPA), and other groups within the FASB, will issue further guidelines on SFAS No. 157 disclosures.
==See also== * [[Mark-to-market accounting#FAS_157]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:United States Generally Accepted Accounting Principles]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Sebastiano Montelupi de Mari | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Sebastian Montelupi (1516 - 1600).jpg | image_size = 190px | alt = | caption = Commemorative stamp issue, 2008 (detail). | birth_name = | birth_date = 1516 | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1600|8|18|1516}} | death_place = [[Kraków]] | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = Montelupi Monument, [[St. Mary's Basilica, Kraków]] | residence = [[Montelupi House]], [[Main Square, Kraków]] | nationality = Polish (patent of naturalization awarded by King Sigismund II) | other_names = Sebastian Wilczogórski | citizenship = Florentine (awarded 1567) | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = merchant, banker, postmaster | years_active = 1557–1600 | employer = | organization = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = estate at death estimated at fl.150,000 | title = Master of the Royal Posts | term = 1568–1600 | predecessor = [[Pietro Maffon]] | successor = [[Valerio Tamburini Montelupi]] | spouse = Urszula Baza (1551–1586), m. 1567 | partner = Carlo Montelupi (younger brother) | children = Valerio Tamburini Montelupi (adopted) | parents = Valerio Montelupi de Mari | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = {{Infobox noble|type| name = Montelupi| CoA = [[File:POL COA Montelupi.svg|120px]]| more = no | successor = | styles = | titles = | noble family = }} | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Sebastiano Montelupi''' ({{lang-pl|Sebastian Montelupi}}, name occasionally Polonized as ''Wilczogórski'', 1516 – 18 August 1600),<ref name="Jagiełło"/> was an Italian-born merchant and banker in [[Kraków]], Poland, and [[Postmaster]] General of the Polish royal postal service under [[Sigismund II Augustus]], [[Henry III of Poland]], [[Anna Jagiellon]], [[Stephen Báthory]] and [[Sigismund III Vasa]].
==Life== Montelupi left Italy in 1536, settling in the [[Kingdom of Poland (Jagiellonian)|Kingdom of Poland]] in 1557. He worked for the merchants and bankers Carlo and Bernardo Soderini until establishing himself independently in partnership with his younger brother Carlo.<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/> [[File:Dom Włoski.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Montelupi House (now a hostel) on the main square in Kraków]]In 1567 he married the teenaged Urszula, daughter of doctor of medicine [[Wojciech Baza]] (died 1569),<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/> physician to the court.<ref name="Lisowski"/> The year after the wedding the couple moved into a ''[[Kamienica (architecture)|kamienica]]'' residence in the centre of Kraków, rebuilt in the Renaissance style. This building, known as the [[Italian House]] or Montelupi House, also served as the central post office. Urszula was to die without surviving issue on 12 July 1586, aged 35, after 19 years of marriage.<ref name="Starowolski"/> At one point [[Francesco Pucci]] had consulted [[John Dee]] on Montelupi's behalf, to determine whether their childlessness could be due to witchcraft.<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/>
==Career== As a merchant, Montelupi traded with Italy, Germany, England, Austria and Russia. As a banker, his clients included the [[Apostolic Nuncio to Poland|papal nuncios at the Polish court]].<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/> In 1574, the city reimbursed Montelupi a little over ''[[Polish złoty#First z.C5.82oty|fl]]''.1,827 for his contributions to the ceremony of receiving and performing hommage to the new king, Henry III; these contributions included a yard and a half of red Chinese cloth for the dish holding the keys to the city, and a number of [[vermeil]] vessels and a large silver vase that were presented to the king.<ref name="Fournier"/> In 1581 Montelupi advanced ''fl''.3,000 to King Stephen Báthory to help finance that year's [[Siege of Pskov|campaign against Muscovy]].<ref name="Fournier"/> Towards the end of his life he became court banker to King Sigismund III, and consul of the Italian community in the capital.<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/> In the 1580s he funded the publication of work by the Franciscan writer [[Annibale Rosselli]].<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/> He died in Kraków on 18 August 1600, aged 84,<ref name="Starowolski"/> leaving an estate valued at ''fl''.150,000.<ref name="goldthwaite"/> He was succeeded by his nephew and adopted heir, [[Valerio Tamburini Montelupi]] (Walerian Montelupi, 1548–1613), who thus became the richest citizen in Kraków.<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/>
===Master of the Royal Post=== From 1568 Montelupi was postmaster general of the [[Polish Royal Post]] (succeeding [[Pietro Maffon]]), running one public service to [[Vilnius]] (in three weeks) and another to Vienna and Venice (in ten days).<ref name="Ronchi De Michelis"/> These services were suspended in 1572 and when resumed in 1574 were reserved for the carriage of royal messages. In 1583 he was confirmed as royal postmaster general by the new king, Stephen Báthory, on condition he maintain public deliveries between the major cities of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]], and an international service to and from Venice at least twice each month. His position enabled Montelupi to provide high-level information services for correspondents including the [[Medici]] in Florence and the [[Fugger]] in Augsburg.<ref name="nachrichtenverkehr"/>
At Sebastiano's death the postmastership also passed to his nephew Valerio, and in time to Valerio's descendants, the last postmaster of the dynasty being [[Carlo Montelupi de Mari]] (Karol Montelupi, died 1662).<ref name="Montelupi"/> Another Italian, [[Angelo Maria Bandinelli]], then became royal postmaster general.<ref name="Bandinelli, Roberto"/>
==Commemoration== A magnificent monument to Sebastiano Montelupi and his wife Urszula was erected in [[St. Mary's Basilica, Kraków]]. The work has been attributed to the workshop of Italian-Polish architect and sculptor [[Santi Gucci]].<ref name="Rudzinski"/>
A street in Kraków is named after his family, as is his [[kamienica (architecture)|kamienica]], and [[Montelupi Palace|a palace]] built by his descendants.<ref name="pudlowski"/>
In 2008 a commemorative stamp set celebrating the 450th anniversary of the Polish postal service was issued, featuring portraits of [[Prosper Provano]] and Sebastiano Montelupi.<ref name="Joystamps"/> The portrait of Montelupi was based on the effigy incorporated into the Montelupi monument.
==See also== * [[Montelupich Prison]] along the Montelupich Street in Kraków, the notorious Gestapo torture chamber throughout World War II.<ref name="yadvashem"/>
