{{redirect-distinguish|Solar road|SolaRoad}} '''Smart highway''' and '''smart road''' are terms for a number of different proposals to incorporate technologies into roads for generating [[solar energy]], for improving the operation of [[autonomous car]]s, for lighting, and for monitoring the condition of the road.
== Vehicle infrastructure integration == {{Further|Platoon (automobile)|Vehicle infrastructure integration}}
== Structural health monitoring == {{Main|Structural health monitoring}}
== Intelligent transportation systems == {{Main|Intelligent transportation system}} {{See also|Virginia Smart Road}}
''Intelligent transportation systems'' usually refers to the use of information and communication technologies (rather than innovations in the construction of the roadway) in the field of road transport, including infrastructure, vehicles and users, and in traffic management and mobility management, as well as for interfaces with other modes of transport.<ref>http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2010:207:0001:0013:EN:PDF</ref>
== Photovoltaic pavement == Photovoltaic pavement is a form of pavement that generates electricity by collecting [[solar power]] with [[photovoltaics]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Matej Lufčić|author2=Marina Maras|author3=Mario Vukelić|title=Energy Saving Design and Materials in Road Transport|url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/540022.Energy_saving_design_and_materials_in_road_transport.doc|accessdate=23 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524041829/http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/540022.Energy_saving_design_and_materials_in_road_transport.doc|archivedate=24 May 2014|df=}}</ref> Parking lots, footpaths, driveways, streets and highways are all candidate locations where this material could be used.
In 2013 Students at the Solar Institute at George Washington University installed a solar panel walking path designed by [[Onyx Solar]], something they call ''solar pavement''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://inhabitat.com/students-install-the-worlds-first-solar-pavement-panels-in-virginia/ |title=Students Install the World's First Solar Pavement Panels in Virginia | Inhabitat - Sustainable Design Innovation, Eco Architecture, Green Building |publisher=Inhabitat |accessdate=2014-06-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531095151/http://inhabitat.com/students-install-the-worlds-first-solar-pavement-panels-in-virginia/ |archivedate=2014-05-31 |df= }}</ref>
''[[SolaRoad]]'' is a system being developed by the [[Netherlands Organisation for Applied Scientific Research]] (TNO), the [[Ooms Groep]], [[Imtech]] and the Netherlands province of [[North Holland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solaroad.nl/|title=SolaRoad website|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606205735/http://www.solaroad.nl/ |archivedate=2014-06-06|df=}}</ref> They plan to install their panels on 100 m of cycle path in [[Krommenie]], [[Netherlands]] in November 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://inhabitat.com/the-netherlands-to-pave-roads-with-solaroad-solar-panels/ |title=The Netherlands to Pave Roads with Solaroad Solar Panels | Inhabitat - Sustainable Design Innovation, Eco Architecture, Green Building |publisher=Inhabitat |date=2012-05-23 |accessdate=2014-06-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426110537/http://inhabitat.com/the-netherlands-to-pave-roads-with-solaroad-solar-panels/ |archivedate=2014-04-26 |df= }}</ref> A variant concept of a "solar road" installed in [[Avenhorn]], by Ooms Avenhorn Holding AV, uses asphalt and tarmac to absorb the sun’s rays and heat water for use in domestic heating.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecmag.com/section/miscellaneous/dutch-company-drives-new-solar-power|title=Dutch Company Drives New Solar Power|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527214130/http://www.ecmag.com/section/miscellaneous/dutch-company-drives-new-solar-power|archivedate=2014-05-27|df=}}</ref>
The [[Solar Roadways]] company of Idaho, USA, is developing a prototype system to replace current roads, parking lots, and driveways with photovoltaic solar road panels that generate [[electricity]].<ref name="Solar Roadways">[http://singularityhub.com/2014/05/22/following-the-solar-brick-road-to-clean-energy-and-smart-roadways/ Following the Solar Brick Road] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524004212/http://singularityhub.com/2014/05/22/following-the-solar-brick-road-to-clean-energy-and-smart-roadways/ |date=2014-05-24 }} singularityhub.com</ref>
[[South Korea]] has built a freeway with the median covered by solar panels above a bikepath.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.techtimes.com/articles/72306/20150727/daejeon-sejong-bike-highway-solar-powered-good-environment.htm |title = The Daejeon-Sejong Bike Highway Is Solar Powered And Good For The Environment |last = Reich |first = J.E. |date = July 27, 2015 |website = Tech Times |publisher = |access-date = 2016-11-02 |quote = The solar panels are used to power the lights that line the highway proper, as well as ... electric car chargers. |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161104002413/http://www.techtimes.com/articles/72306/20150727/daejeon-sejong-bike-highway-solar-powered-good-environment.htm |archivedate = November 4, 2016 |df = }}</ref>
The first photovoltaic road in the world was constructed in [[Tourouvre]], [[Orne]], France in 2016.<ref> {{cite web | url = | title = France gets a step closer to solar roads | last = Tsagas | first = Ilias | date = August 4, 2016 | website = PV Magazine Global | publisher = | access-date = 2016-11-02 | quote = ...the product is based on crystalline silicon, and although it is very thin, ... it is also “very sturdy, skid-resistant and designed to last,” with the durability to bear all types of vehicles, including trucks.}}</ref><ref name="sudestsegoleneroyallance">{{cite news|last1=Bourgin|first1=Yohann|title=High Tech. Ségolène Royal lance la première route solaire dans l'Orne|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/environnement/amenagement-du-territoire/high-tech-segolene-royal-lance-la-premiere-route-solaire-dans-l-orne-4582630|accessdate=November 2, 2016|work=[[Sud-Ouest (newspaper)|Sud-Ouest]]|date=October 25, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028223847/http://www.ouest-france.fr/environnement/amenagement-du-territoire/high-tech-segolene-royal-lance-la-premiere-route-solaire-dans-l-orne-4582630|archivedate=October 28, 2016|df=}}</ref> Called "Wattway", it was built by [[Société Nouvelle Aeracem]] (SNA), and dedicated by the French Minister of Ecology, [[Ségolène Royal]] on October 25, 2016.<ref name="sudestsegoleneroyallance"/> The 1-km section of road opened to traffic on 22 December 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/dec/22/solar-panel-road-tourouvre-au-perche-normandy |title=World's first solar panel road opens in Normandy village |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Kim Willsher |date=December 22, 2016 |accessdate=December 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222204933/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/dec/22/solar-panel-road-tourouvre-au-perche-normandy |archivedate=December 22, 2016 |df= }}</ref> It is believed the road will provide enough power for the town's streetlights.
The [[Jinan]] solar highway opened in China in December 2017 along a 1.2 mile stretch. It uses [[transparent concrete]] on the top layer with the solar panels underneath. It was the second solar roadway in the city, the first opened in September 2017 using a different technology.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://electrek.co/2017/12/21/china-solar-roadways-transparent-concrete-solar-cells-charge-cars/ |title=China is building solar roadways – ‘transparent concrete’ atop solar cells that charge driving cars |work=Electrek |author=John Fitzgerald Weaver |date=December 21, 2017 |accessdate=January 15, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116135255/https://electrek.co/2017/12/21/china-solar-roadways-transparent-concrete-solar-cells-charge-cars/ |archivedate=January 16, 2018 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/12/30/china-opens-1-kilometer-long-solar-road/ |title=China Opens 1-Kilometer Long Solar Road |work=CleanTechnica |author=Steve Hanley |date=December 30, 2017 |accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref>
===Solar Road Panels=== The main purpose of solar roadways is to replace asphalt roads with Solar Panels which generate energy through the sun that can be used by local houses or businesses that are connected to the system from either the house’s driveway or the businesses parking lot. The panels will also increase the number of charging stations for electric cars if that station is connected to the solar roadway. Each panel is roughly 12’ by 12’ of interlocking panels that have their own LED lights that will be used as the road lines, and can also be used to spell out words like “Reduce Speed” or “Traffic Ahead” to help the flow of traffic.<ref name = Ranjan>{{cite journal|last1=Ranjan|first1=Rajeev|title=Solar Power Roads: Revitalising Solar Highways, Electrical Power and Smart Grids|journal=International Journal of Engineering Research and General Science|date=January–February 2015|volume=3|issue=1|pages=380–385}}</ref>
There are 3 layers that make up the solar panels:
1. The Road Surface Layer - The Road Layer is the High Strength layer that has the photovoltaic cells which attracts the sun’s rays, it has traction so vehicles don’t slide off the road, and it’s waterproof to protect the layers below.<ref name = Ranjan/>
2. The Electronic Layer - The Electronic Layers contain a mini microprocessor board that helps control the heating element of the panels, this technology can help melt the snow that lands on the panels so that hazardous road conditions will no longer be an issue in the more northern regions. This layer can sense how much weight is on the panels and can control the heating element to melt the snow.<ref name = Ranjan/>
3. The Base Plate Layer - The Base Plate Layer is the layer that collects the energy from the sun and distributes the power to the homes or businesses that are connected to the solar roadways. This will also be used to transfer the energy to cars as they drive over the strip to recharge the battery.<ref name = Ranjan/>
===Criticism=== ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' magazine stated that solar roadways would produce less electricity than solar cells that are placed at an angle, and that less light would touch them because of shade, dirt covering the road, and cars blocking the sun from touching the panels. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2017/12/solar_roads_are_almost_definitely_not_the_future.html|title=What Is the Point of a Solar Road?|first=Neel V.|last=Patel|date=December 28, 2017|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref>
Critics have pointed out that solar roadways would be both more expensive, and less productive than more conventional ways of combining solar power with infrastructure, such as building shelters over roads and parking areas and putting traditional solar panels on the roofs; [[Elon Musk]] demonstrated that there is ample space in the US, apart from roads, to fulfill the power requirements of the country.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.equities.com/news/elon-musk-demonstrates-why-solar-roadways-would-be-really-silly|title=Elon Musk Demonstrates Why Solar Roadways Would be Really Silly|last=equities.com|work=Equities.com|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}}</ref> . <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://interestingengineering.com/solar-roadways-engineering-failure|title=Solar Roadways: An Engineering FAILURE|date=2017-05-18|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvhn.nl/drenthe/Parkeren-onder-zonnepanelen-bij-TT-Circuit-21255430.html|title=Cookiemelding - DVHN.nl|website=www.dvhn.nl}}</ref>
===Smart pavement=== The Missouri Department of Transportation (MoDOT) began testing out “smart pavement” at a rest stop outside of Conway, Missouri along historic Route 66 late in 2016. The pilot program currently covers about 200 square feet of sidewalk at the visitor center and cost $100,000 (Landers), largely subsidized by the Federal Highway Administration.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cronkleton|first1=Robert A.|title=Missouri’s solar roadways to begin with sidewalk at historic Route 66 Welcome Center|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article93755517.html|accessdate=20 April 2017|agency=Kansas City Star|date=August 4, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170511125201/http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article93755517.html|archivedate=11 May 2017|df=}}</ref> It’s all part of Missouri’s Road to Tomorrow initiative to find new innovations in their transportation infrastructure. Missouri wants to take advantage of these roadways to implement other, related technologies. The panels will heat the road and keep snow and ice from accumulating. They will also feature LED diodes that will increase the visibility of road lines. The LEDs would also double in helping prevent paint from inhibiting solar power generation.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Landers|first1=Jay|title=Missouri to Test Solar Roadways, Smart Pavement as Part of Road to Tomorrow Project|journal=Civil Engineering—ASCE|date=2016|volume=86|issue=9|pages=30–31|url=http://cedb.asce.org/CEDBsearch/record.jsp?dockey=0352321|accessdate=20 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170504172325/http://cedb.asce.org/CEDBsearch/record.jsp?dockey=0352321|archivedate=4 May 2017|df=}}</ref> The panels have not had enough time to determine durability, energy efficiency, or cost effectiveness in a real world sense yet, so MoDOT has not reach any conclusions about feasibility and future application yet.
==Wireless vehicle charging== {{See|In-road electric vehicle charger|Inductive charging|Wireless power transfer}}
The [[Online Electric Vehicle]] being developed by [[KAIST]] (the  Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology) has electrical circuits built into the road which will power suitably adapted vehicles via contactless [[electromagnetic induction]]. A pilot system powering electric buses is under development. Germany's [[IAV#In-road electric vehicle charger|IAV]] is another company that is developing induction chargers.
===Electromechanical batteries=== Roadway-powered electric vehicle system is the patent held by Howard R. Ross. It has several components. The first of which is an all electric vehicle that would be fit with electromechanical batteries that accept a charge from the road. The road is the second component and would have strategically placed charging coils as to only charge the car when needed. These cars and roads would not require gas or solar power.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ross|first1=H.R.|title=Roadway-Powered Electric Vehicle System|url=https://www.google.com/patents/US5669470|website=Google Patents}}</ref>
Nowhere in the world is an invention like this currently implemented, and this is due to the cost of the infrastructure overhaul that would be needed to bring this patent into reality.
== Road markings == [[File:Glowing Lines Roosegaarde.jpg|thumb|Glowing Lines, Studio Roosegaarde]] The ''Smart Highway'' concept developed by [[Studio Roosegaarde]] and the infrastructure management group [[Heijmans]] in the Netherlands incorporated [[Photoluminescence|photo-luminescent]] paint for road markings, which absorb light during the day then glow for up to 10 hours. The technology was demonstrated on a stretch of highway in [[North Brabant|Brabant]], Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web |last=Clark |first=Liat |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-10/30/smart-highway-glows-in-the-dark |title=Netherlands highways will glow in the dark from mid-2013 (Wired UK) |publisher=Wired.co.uk |accessdate=2014-06-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530095727/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-10/30/smart-highway-glows-in-the-dark |archivedate=2014-05-30 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-27021291 |title=Glow in the dark road unveiled in the Netherlands |publisher=BBC |date=2014-04-14 |accessdate=2014-06-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140703073055/http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-27021291 |archivedate=2014-07-03 |df= }}</ref>
== Frost protection and melting snow, ice == [[Snowmelt system]]s using electricity or hot water to heat roads and pavements have been installed in various locations.
[[Solar Roadways]] has proposed including a snowmelt system with their photovoltaic road panels since the panels already have electrical power connections for harvesting photovoltaic power.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/01/19/smart.roads/ "Solar-powered 'smart' roads could zap snow, ice"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204050905/http://www.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/01/19/smart.roads/ |date=2017-02-04 }}, Thom Patterson. CNN. January 19, 2011. Retrieved 8 feb 2017</ref> Skeptics point to the energy requirements.<ref name="Z">[http://www.zeroto60times.com/2016/06/solar-powered-roads-future/ "Solar Powered Roads: The Future, or Just Hype?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211081821/http://www.zeroto60times.com/2016/06/solar-powered-roads-future/|date=2017-02-11}}, Andy Jensen. Zero to 60 Times. June 2016. Retrieved 8 feb 2017</ref>
ICAX Limited of London's "Interseasonal Heat Capture" technology captures solar energy in thermal banks and releases it back under a roadway, heating it and keeping asphalt free of ice.<ref>[http://www.icax.co.uk/toddington_results.html "Independent results published by TRL on Toddington ice clearing demonstration using Interseasonal Heat Transfer™ to heat roads"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219074315/http://icax.co.uk/toddington_results.html |date=2016-12-19 }}, ICAX. April 2008. Retrieved 8 feb 2017</ref>
==See also== * [[Autopilot]] * [[Building information modeling]] * [[Connected car]] * [[Digital modeling and fabrication]] * [[Open hardware]] * [[Open Design Alliance]] * [[Platoon (automobile)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://solarroadways.com Solar Roadways]

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:Permalink/772743896#Future of magic links|local RfC]] and [[:mw:Requests for comment/Future of magic links|MediaWiki RfC]]
revision.text:
In the business of [[insurance]], '''statutory reserves''' are those assets an insurance company is legally required to maintain on its [[balance sheet]] with respect to the unmatured obligations (i.e., expected future claims) of the company. Statutory reserves are a type of [[actuarial reserve]].
==Purpose== Statutory reserves are intended to ensure that insurance companies are able to meet future obligations created by insurance policies. These reserves must be reported in statements filed with insurance regulatory bodies. They are calculated with a certain level of conservatism in order to protect policyholders and beneficiaries.<ref name=Klugman295>{{cite book |editor-first=Stuart A. |editor-last=Klugman |first1=Jeffrey A. |last1=Beckley |first2=Patricia L. |last2=Scahill |first3=Matthew C. |last3=Varitek |first4=Toby A. |last4=White |title=Understanding Actuarial Practice |publisher=[[Society of Actuaries]] |year=2012 |page=295}}</ref>
==Methods== There are two types of methods for calculation of statutory reserves. Reserve methodology may be fully prescribed by law, which is often called formula-based reserving. This is in contrast to principles-based reserves, where [[actuaries]] are given latitude to use professional judgment in determining methodology and assumptions for reserve calculation.<ref name="Klugman295"/> In the United States, where formula-based reserves are used, the [[National Association of Insurance Commissioners]] plans to implement principles-based reserves in 2017.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Principle-Based Reserving (PBR) Implementation Plan |date=23 March 2015 |url=http://www.naic.org/documents/committees_ex_pbr_implementation_tf_150323_pbr_implementation_plan.pdf |publisher=[[National Association of Insurance Commissioners]]}}</ref>
==Life insurance in the United States== In the U.S. [[life insurance]] industry, statutory reserves are most commonly computed using the [[Commissioner's Reserve Valuation Method]], or CRVM, the method prescribed by law for computing minimum required reserves.
The size of a CRVM reserve, as with most life reserves, is affected by the age and sex of the insured person, how long the policy for which it is computed has been in force, the plan of insurance offered by the policy, the rate of interest used in the calculation, and the [[mortality table]] with which the [[actuarial present value]]s are computed.
The Commissioner's Reserve Valuation Method was itself established by the Standard Valuation Law (SVL), which was created by the [[National Association of Insurance Commissioners|NAIC]] and adopted by the several states shortly after World War II. The first mortality table prescribed by the SVL was the 1941 CSO (Commissioner's Standard Ordinary) table,<ref>The 1941 CSO table was prescribed for policies of ''ordinary'' life insurance. For policies of ''industrial'' life insurance the SVL prescribed use of the 1941 CSI (Commissioner's Standard Industrial) table.</ref> at a maximum interest rate of 3½%. Subsequent amendments to the Standard Valuation Law have permitted the use of more modern mortality tables and higher rates of interest. The effect of these changes has in general been to reduce the amount of the reserves which life insurance companies are legally required to hold.
==See also== *[[Actuarial reserves]] *[[Elizur Wright]] *[[Statutory accounting principles]]
==Notes== <references/>
==References== *N. L. Bowers, H. U. Gerber, J. C. Hickman, D. A. Jones, & C. J. Nesbitt, ''Actuarial Mathematics'', Society of Actuaries (1986). {{ISBN|0-938959-10-7}}
==External links== *[http://www.naic.org/ NAIC Official Website] *[http://www.naic.org/committees_e_app_sapwg.htm Statutory Accounting Principles Working Group]
[[Category:Actuarial science]] [[Category:Accounting in the United States]]

{{Infobox person | name = Suhail Bahwan | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |79|2018|03|01}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = [[Muscat]], [[Oman]] | nationality = Omani | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = businessman | known for = Owner, Suhail Bahwan Group | home_town = [[Sur, Oman|Sur]], Oman | salary = | networth = US$4.0 billion<ref name="Forbes profile">{{cite web|title=Forbes profile: Suhail Bahwan|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/suhail-bahwan/|website=Forbes|accessdate=1 March 2018}}</ref> | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = married | children = 15 | parents = | relatives = | website = }} '''Suhail Bahwan''' (born 1938/39) is an Omani [[billionaire]] businessman.
Bahwan began as a small-scale trader in [[Sur, Oman|Sur]], with one dhow, inherited from his father, doing business between Oman and India.<ref name="Forbes profile"/> In 1965, he moved to the capital, [[Muscat]] and opened a shop in the souq (market).<ref name="Forbes profile"/> In 1968, he obtained the local license for [[Seiko]], then one for [[Toyota]].<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
The Suhail Bahwan Group is now the largest privately owned business in Oman, including fertilizers, healthcare and construction.<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
In 2016, Bahwan passed much of the responsibility for running the Suhail Bahwan Group turned to [[Amal Bahwan]], his sixth child, and second-eldest daughter.<ref name="Forbes_2017">{{cite news|last1=Wendel|first1=Samuel|title=From Humble Beginnings, Suhail Bahwan Became A Billionaire In Oman|url=https://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/exclusive-from-humble-beginnings-suhail-bahwan-became-a-billionaire-in-oman/|accessdate=1 March 2018|work=Forbes|date=11 April 2017}}</ref>
Bahwan is married, with 15 children, and lives [[Muscat]], Oman.<ref name="Forbes profile"/><ref name="Forbes_2017"/> In September 2017, Bahwan won the Sheikh Issa bin Ali al Khalifa Award for voluntary work by the Arab League.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Oman/Sheikh-Suhail-Bahwan-receives-Arab-League-award-for-voluntary-work-53ly|title=Sheikh Suhail Bahwan receives Arab League award for voluntary work - Oman|last=Newspaper|first=Muscat Daily|work=Muscat Daily News|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox building |name = TIAA Bank Center |image = |image_size = 220px |architectural_style= [[Modern architecture|Modernist]] |location = 301 West Bay Street<ref name=LOOP /> |coordinates = {{coord|30.32754|-81.66222|region:US-FL_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=inline,title}} |map_type = United States Jacksonville#USA Florida |start_date = 1982 |completion_date = 1983<ref name=EMP /> |opening = 1983<ref name=EMP /> |building_type = Class "A" office<ref name=EMP /> |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|447|ft|m|abbr=on}}<ref name=EMP>[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=118950] Emporis Building Reference, Jacksonville, AT&T Tower</ref> |floor_count = 32<ref name=EMP /> |floor_area = {{convert|956,201|sqft|abbr=on}} |elevator_count = 14 |cost = |architect = [[KBJ Architects]]<ref name=EMP /> |developer = |owner = Amkin Real Estate }} '''TIAA Bank Center''' is a [[skyscraper]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], USA. Standing 447 feet (136 m) tall,<ref name="EMP"/> it is the city's [[List of tallest buildings in Jacksonville|third-tallest building]], as well as the largest in terms of class "A" rentable area with {{convert|956201|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}.<ref name=LOOP>[http://www.loopnet.com/property/15130996/301-West-Bay-Street/] LoopNet Office Property For Lease, AT&T Tower</ref> Formerly known as the '''Southern Bell Telephone Building''', the '''AT&T Tower''', and '''EverBank Center''', it took its former name in 2012 when [[EverBank]] moved employees into the building and acquired signage rights.<ref name=Mathis>{{cite news |title= EverBank to move Downtown, AT&T Tower 301 becomes EverBank Center|author= Karen Brune Mathis |url= http://jaxdailyrecord.com/showstory.php?Story_id=535190&mailer=20111219|newspaper= Financial News & Daily Record |date= December 19, 2011 |accessdate=December 19, 2011}}</ref><ref name=citynotes>{{cite news |title= City Notes 6/29/2012 |author= |url= http://www.jaxdailyrecord.com/citynotes.php?id=536852 |newspaper= Financial News & Daily Record |date= June 29, 2012 |accessdate=July 3, 2012 }}</ref> The building is currently called [[TIAA Bank]] Center, although no formal announcement has been made, and signage changes have not been completed, as of EverBank's rebranding, effective on June 4, 2018.
==History==
The building was designed by [[KBJ Architects]] and opened in 1983.<ref name=EMP /> It takes up an entire city block in Jacksonville's downtown. A notable feature of the structure is that each floor has 16 corner offices.<ref name=SKY>[http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=3751] Skyscraper Page.com, Jacksonville, Florida, AT&T Tower</ref> The building was constructed on the former site of the Hotel Mayflower.<ref name=EMP />
The tower was built for the [[Southern Bell]] Telephone company. The following year, [[American Telephone & Telegraph]] (AT&T) was forced to divest its regional phone companies and Southern Bell became a unit of [[BellSouth]]; the signage was changed to reflect the new name. In 2006 AT&T re-acquired BellSouth and the signage was changed back to AT&T in 2008.<ref name=JAX904>Trinidad, Alison (January/February 2009). ''[[Jacksonville Magazine's 904]]'', pp. 24-25.</ref>
In 2011 [[CSX]] vacated space it had rented in the tower, leaving it mostly empty. Later that year the City of Jacksonville finalized a deal with [[EverBank]], in which the bank received tax incentives to relocate over 1,200 employees into the building and add 200 new jobs. EverBank took over nine floors and acquired the naming rights to the tower, which was renamed EverBank Center. Employees moved into the building in summer 2012, with signage installed in September and October.<ref name=Mathis/><ref name=citynotes/>
==Details== The entrance to the building features a two-story atrium.<ref name=CNL>[http://www.cnl.com/commercialRealEstate/att/] [[CNL Commercial Real Estate]], Properties, AT&T Tower</ref> There is a 280-seat auditorium on the second level and a backup power system for the entire building. The [[JTA Skyway]] central station is across the street and an adjoining seven-level parking garage has spaces for 641 vehicles.<ref name=LOOP /> The building was purchased in 2004 by [[El-Ad Group|El Ad Florida]] for $91 million.<ref name=JAX904 /> In 2014 the building was acquired by Amkin Real Estate, a privately owned real estate investment company based in Miami, FL.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:JacksonvilleAT&TBldg-Feb2010.JPG| File:JacksonvilleAT&TBldg-Feb2010-a.JPG| File:EverBank Center 1.JPG| File:EverBank Center.jpg| </gallery>

{{Infobox convention | name = Tech Open Air | image = | alt = | caption = | status = Active | genre = Technology Conference | venue = | location = Berlin, Germany | coordinates = | country = | first = 2012 | last = | attendance = 15091 (2017) | organizer = Nikolas Woischnik<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-28/berlin-s-startup-hub-wants-to-prove-it-s-more-than-just-a-scene|title=How a Berlin factory became home to dozens of tech companies|first=Adam Satariano satariano Stefan Nicola StefanNicolaBBG|last=Reprints|publisher=}}</ref> | filing = | website = {{url|toa.berlin}} | footnotes = }}
'''Tech Open Air''' (often abbreviated as "TOA") is an annual interdisciplinary technology festival that takes place in [[Berlin]], Germany. It started in 2012 as the very first tech festival organised through [[crowdfunding]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kisskissbankbank.com/en/projects/tech-open-air-berlin-festival|title=TOABerlin presents Tech Open Air Berlin Festival — KissKissBankBank|author=KissKissBankBank|work=KissKissBankBank}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://venturevillage.eu/tech-open-air-berlin-confirms-kater-holzig-venue-launches-crowdfunding-campaign|title=Tech Open Air Berlin confirms Kater Holzig venue, launches crowdfunding campaign|work=VentureVillage}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://venturevillage.eu/tech-open-air-berlin-2012|title="Failure's OK in Berlin", but "Aim for a billion-dollar company" – Tech Open Air|work=VentureVillage}}</ref> The festival has developed into a well-known tech conference in and out of Europe. The main concept behind Tech Open Air is to bring together the areas of technology, music, art, and science<ref name="venturevillage.eu">{{cite web|url=http://venturevillage.eu/tech-open-air-returns|title=Tech Open Air Berlin returns for two days of startups, music and art|work=VentureVillage}}</ref> by providing a platform for [[multi-disciplinary]] knowledge exchange, collaboration, and development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130814-berlin-can-cool-and-capital-mix|title=BBC - Future - Berlin start-ups: Cool and commerce coming together?|author=Stephen Evans|work=bbc.com}}</ref> Tech Open Air is organised every year in June or July and gathers a number of influential speakers, entrepreneurs, artists, scientists, start-ups, and attendees from Germany and 55+ other countries.
== 2017 == The TOA17 Festival took place between the 11–14 July 2017, remaining for a second year at former GDR Radio Station, Funkhaus Berlin. 2017 saw the Satellites program extend even further with kick-off events (including the official Satellites launch party with [[Seth Troxler]]) taking place on the Tuesday before the Conference.
TOA Conference also expanded further with a brand new 4500qm exhibition hall "The House of Tech". This unique TOA style take on a traditional expo hosted brands such as Facebook, Google, Samsung NEXT, as well as a host of Europe's leading startups. Over 6,000 people attended the conference, where the 200+ speakers included [[Adam D'Angelo]] (Co-Founder & CEO, [[Quora]]), Richard Sharp (CTO, [[Shazam (company)|Shazam]]), [[Richie Hawtin]], Mate Galic (CTO, [[Native Instruments]]), [[Erika Lust]] (Co-founder, [[Erika Lust Films]]), [[Hector Ouilhet]] (Head of Design, [[Google Search]]), [[Imogen Heap]] (Founder, Mycelia).
2017 was also the inaugural year for TOA Music Fest which took place on the last night of the festival with over 2000 people in attendance. The night featured live performances from [[Machinedrum]] and Schwarz Don't Crack, as well as DJ sets from the likes of Blaenk Minds and Samuel Morgan.
== 2016 == Tech Open Air held its fifth edition on 13–15 July 2016,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dataconomy.com/tech-open-air/|title=Tech Open Air - Bringing everyone together - Dataconomy|date=2016-07-29|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-05}}</ref> with the conference taking place at a new venue, Funkhaus Nalepastraße, over the first two days. In 2016 the TOA satellite programme expanded to occur over the whole of 15 July as well as on the evenings of the conference. In total 177 satellite events took place in Berlin across three days.
The TOA conference hosted 166 speakers and included keynote talks from founders and entrepreneurs such as Yancey Strickler,<ref>{{Citation|last=Tech Open|title=TOA16: Keynote Talk with Yancey Strickler (Kickstarter CEO and Co-Founder)|date=2016-07-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E0OsQza8l-w|accessdate=2016-09-05}}</ref> Luis von Ahn<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.de/collection/business/hier-koennt-ihr-das-toa16-berlin-im-livestream-verfolgen|title=Hier könnt ihr das Tech Open Air in Berlin im Livestream verfolgen|date=2016-07-14|access-date=2016-09-05}}</ref> and Cindy Gallop.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tech.eu/features/10341/tech-open-air-berlin-2016/|title=Tech Open Air returns to Berlin next month - Tech.eu|date=2016-06-21|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-05}}</ref> In addition to the talks, attendees were able to take part in a number of different formats such as Pitch-nic, Music Meets Tech, and a Reverse Pitch where investors were able to pitch their investments to promising startups.
In total, 11,221 people attended TOA from over 40 countries. Speakers included [[Mathias Döpfner]] ([[Axel Springer SE|Axel Springer]]), [[Caterina_Fake|Catherina Fake]] ([[Flickr]]), Luke Woods ([[Facebook]]), Dominik Richter ([[HelloFresh]]), Katie Dill ([[Airbnb]]), [[Daniel Barenboim]] ([[Berlin State Opera]]), Gabriel Flateman (Casper) and [[Susan Danziger]] ([[Ziggeo]]).
==2015== Tech Open Air 2015 (#TOA15) took place July 15–17, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musikexpress.de/tech-open-air-2015-ein-festival-ohne-scheuklappen-275847/|title=Tech Open Air 2015: Ein Festival ohne Scheuklappen|work=Musikexpress}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-07-17/trying-to-impress-at-a-berlin-tech-festival|title=Trying to Impress at a Berlin Tech Festival|date=17 July 2015|work=Bloomberg.com}}</ref> The "Unconference"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://berlindustrie.de/fakten/veranstaltungstipp-tech-open-air-2015/|title=Veranstaltungstipp: Tech Open Air 2015|work=Berliner Industrie}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gruenderzeit.morgenpost.de/2015/07/13/tech-open-air-gilt-als-europas-coolste-konferenz/|title=Tech Open Air gilt als Europas coolste Konferenz|work=Gründerzeit}}</ref> as well as more than 150 satellite events<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bz-berlin.de/berlin/lichtenberg/tech-open-air-berlin-so-gechillt-netzwerkt-die-start-up-szene|title=Tech Open Air Berlin: So gechillt netzwerkt die Start-Up-Szene|work=bz-berlin.de}}</ref> across Berlin were the main components of the festival. The programme invited the event attendees to experience engaging talks presented by over 110 professionals,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/insider/2015/08/10/when-it-comes-to-health-and-wellness-tech-women-are-leading-the-way/|title=Women lead the way when it comes to health and wellness tech|author=Lisa Roolant|work=The Next Web}}</ref> as well as interactive panels, art installations, live music, and networking opportunities. Satellite events provided an opportunity for Tech Open Air attendees to fully immerse themselves in the Berlin startup culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://berlinlovesyou.com/2015/07/14/berlins-4th-tech-open-air-festival-with-140-free-and-inspiring-events/|title=Berlin's 4th Tech Open Air Festival With 140 FREE and Inspiring Events - BERLIN LOVES YOU|work=BERLIN LOVES YOU}}</ref>
One additional format of the "Unconference" was a networking session called Back to the Future: Enterprise Meets Startup which inspired and encouraged cross-industry collaboration; the Pitch-Nic (a high-speed pitching session for start-ups and investors);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.berliner-zeitung.de/wirtschaft/tech-open-air-in-berlin-internetszene-trifft-sich-in-der-teppichfabrik,10808230,31220748.html|title=Tech Open Air in Berlin: Internetszene trifft sich in der Teppichfabrik|author=Jutta Meier,|work=berliner-zeitung.de}}</ref> and the Hardware Pitch<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiredcraft.com/blog/toa-shenjs/|title=Two Conferences. Two Experiences.|work=Wiredcraft}}</ref> where six hardware innovations pitched their ideas on stage.
The 2015 edition was attended by over 5000 people<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.de/collection/latest/mit-wired-konnt-ihr-auch-vom-sofa-aus-beim-tech-open-air-dabei-sein|title=Mit WIRED könnt ihr auch vom Sofa aus beim Tech Open Air dabei sein|work=WIRED Germany}}</ref> from various industries and nations (over 30 countries represented). Around 150 media outlets were involved in this year's event including the Wall Street Journal, BBC and TechCrunch. The list of speakers included Mike Butcher ([[TechCrunch]]), Chris Barton ([[Shazam (service)|Shazam]]), Christoph Keese ([[Axel Springer SE]]), Niklas Oestberg ([[Delivery Hero]]), Robert Gentz ([[Zalando]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.zalando.de/de/blog/zalando-tech-open-air-berlin|title=Zalando @Tech Open Air Berlin|work=Zalando -- Corporate Blog}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://tech.zalando.com/blog/zalando-does-tech-open-air/|title=Zalando Does Tech Open Air|work=Zalando Tech}}</ref> Greg Dybec ([[Elite Daily]]), Assaf Biderman ([[Superpedestrian]]), and Dirk Ahlborn ([[Hyperloop]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nordsonne.de/tech-open-air-2015/|title=Tech Open Air 2015|work=Agentur NORDSONNE IDENTITY, Berlin}}</ref>
==2014== The third edition of Tech Open air took place in 2014 and included more than 100 speakers and more than 2750 attendees. The programme also included the first ever Design Slam in Berlin, start-up battles, collaborative workshops and live music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/tech-open-air-berlin-2014|title=Dritte Runde für das Tech Open Air Berlin|work=Gründerszene Magazin}}</ref> One of the hot topics discussed at the event was [[wearable technology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/de/read/unser-panel-zu-wearable-technology-auf-dem-tech-open-air-in-berlin|title=Wir diskutieren auf dem Berliner TechOpenAir die Zukunft von Wearable Technology|work=Motherboard}}</ref>
==2013== The second edition of Tech Open Air included 85 speakers,more than 2000 attendees<ref name="venturevillage.eu"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/toa2013-bilder-leute-statements|title=Die Highlights des Tech Open Air Berlin 2013 - Gründerszene|work=Gründerszene Magazin}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://venturevillage.eu/tech-open-air-speaker|title=Half festival, half conference: Tech Open Air Berlin announces speakers|work=VentureVillage}}</ref> and 50 satellite events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://berlinvalley.com/tech-open-air-festival-strictly-ungooglebar/|title=Tech Open Air Festival – strictly ungooglebar|work=Berlin Valley}}</ref>
==2012== Tech Open Air's inaugural event took place in 2012 in Berlin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/berlin-s-buzzing-with-tech-start-ups-1.525736|title=Berlin's buzzing with tech start-ups|date=3 September 2012|work=The Irish Times}}</ref> The first edition included nearly 60 speakers, 850 visitors and 23 satellite events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presseschauder.de/berlins-aufstieg-vom-abenteuerspielplatz-zum-europaischen-silicon-valley/#more-4338|title=Berlins Aufstieg vom Abenteuerspielplatz zum europäischen Silicon Valley|work=der presseschauder}}</ref>
==See also== *[[South by Southwest]]

page.title: Wily & Right no RockBoard: That's Paradise

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Wily & Right no RockBoard:
That's Paradise | image = Rock Board Cover.png | caption = Box art | developer = [[Capcom]] | publisher = Capcom | designer = Yoshinori Takenaka | artist = [[Keiji Inafune]] | composer = Yuki Iwai | released = {{vgrelease|JP|January 15, 1993{{cite book|isbn=978-1-897376-79-9 |date=January 6, 2010 |title=Mega Man: Official Complete Works|publisher=[[UDON|Udon Entertainment]] | page=82}}}} | genre = [[Business simulation game|Business simulation]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | platforms = [[Nintendo Entertainment System|Family Computer]] }} {{nihongo|'''''Wily & Right no RockBoard: That's Paradise'''''|ワイリー&ライトのRockBoard ザッツ*パラダイス}} is a spin-off [[video game]] title in the original ''[[Mega Man (original series)|Mega Man]]'' series from [[Capcom]]. It is a [[business simulation game]] that is similar to [[board game]] [[Monopoly (game)|''Monopoly'']], in which players and the computer [[artificial intelligence|AI]] take turns going around a set of connected squares, buying up [[property]], and charging other participants [[renting|rent]] when they land on those spaces. ''Wily & Right no RockBoard'' was released on January 15, 1993 for the [[Nintendo Entertainment System|Family Computer]] only in [[Japan]], though an unreleased English translation and a [[Game Boy]] version may have been in development. Critical reception for the game from Western gaming websites has been decidedly poor. ==Gameplay== ''Wily & Right no RockBoard: That's Paradise'' is a [[business simulation game]] in which the player chooses among several characters in the [[Mega Man (original series)|original ''Mega Man'' series]] and competes with other players or the computer AI in purchasing spaces of [[property]]. The characters include [[Roll (Mega Man)|Roll]], [[Dr. Light (Mega Man)|Dr. Light]], [[Doctor Wily|Dr. Wily]], [[Dr. Cossack]], and [[Kalinka Cossack|Kalinka]].{{cite journal | journal=Rockman Big Reference Book | publisher=[[Capcom]] | date=Spring 1993 | title=''Wily & Right no RockBoard: That’s Paradise'' | language=Japanese | pages=78–80}}{{cite web | author=Fletcher, JC | date=November 29, 2007 | title=Virtually Overlooked: ''Wily & Right no Rockboard: That's Paradise'' | url=http://www.joystiq.com/2007/11/29/virtually-overlooked-wily-and-right-no-rockboard-thats-paradise/ | publisher=[[Joystiq]] | accessdate=February 12, 2011}} Each participant is given a turn, moving a certain number of spaces on the board. If they land on a property square, they are given the option to buy it with a certain about of Zenny (the game's currency). They can then charge other characters [[Renting|rent]] when they land on that building. However, other characters can also buy part of the same square, allowing each owner to charge a smaller amount of rent. Some squares contain cards that cause various effects on the board such as raising property prices or the development level of a building. The game's winning conditions can vary depending on the set rules. The winner may be the character with the most owned spaces, the most remaining Zenny, or the most developments. ==Development== ''Wily & Right no RockBoard: That's Paradise'' was developed by [[Capcom]] during a time when the ''Mega Man'' franchise was at its height of its popularity.{{cite web |author1=Nutt, Christian |author2=Speer, Justin |lastauthoramp=yes | title=The History of ''Mega Man'' | url=http://www.gamespot.com/features/6076983/p-26.html | publisher=[[GameSpot]] | accessdate=June 10, 2010}} Series artist [[Keiji Inafune]] had very little involvement in the development of ''Wily & Right no RockBoard: That's Paradise'', simply designing the cover art and the new character [[List of Mega Man characters#Reggae|Reggae]]. When developing the game, the team wanted to include as many bosses from previous titles in the series as possible.{{cite journal | journal=Club Capcom | publisher=[[Capcom]] | date=Spring 1993 | title=''Wily & Right no RockBoard: That’s Paradise'': A Development Team Inside Story | language=Japanese | page=86}} However, they ultimately decided to leave room for an original character that fans could associate with the new game. When discussing a bird character labeled {{nihongo|''fukou no tori''|フコウノトリ||lit. "bird of misfortune"}}, one of the team members misread it as {{nihongo|''kounotori''|コウノトリ||lit. "[[Oriental stork]]"}}, resulting in Reggae's resemblance to the species. The January 1993 issue of the [[Mexico|Mexican]] magazine ''[[Club Nintendo]]'' featured ''Wily & Right no RockBoard'' as part of a preview article for the 1993 [[Consumer Electronics Show]]. Titling the game as "Mega Board", the article even had a screenshot featuring [[English language|English]] text.{{cite journal | journal=[[Club Nintendo]] | publisher=[[Nintendo]] | page=23 | title=''Mega Board'' | author=Ham, Richard | language=Spanish | date=January 1993 | volume=2 | issue=1}} An unreleased [[Game Boy]] version was apparently in the works by the Japanese company Dual, which listed the game on the credits page of its official website.{{cite web | script-title=ja:開発業歴 |trans-title=Development History | url=http://www.dual-inc.co.jp/kaihatu.html | publisher=Dual | language=Japanese | accessdate=January 30, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070726100055/http://www.dual-inc.co.jp/kaihatu.html |archivedate = July 26, 2007}} [[Hitoshi Sakimoto]] was responsible for the audio in this version.{{cite web | title=Hitoshi Sakimoto - Official English Website (Discography) | url=http://sakimoto.cocoebiz.com/discography/index.shtml | publisher=[[Hitoshi Sakimoto]] | accessdate=January 30, 2009}} ==Reception== {{Globalize/USA|section|date=November 2018}} Critical reception for ''Wily & Right no RockBoard: That's Paradise'' outside Japan has been poor. [[GameSpot]] contributors Christian Nutt and Justin Speer found the relatively obscure game to be of no particular interest to anyone other than ''Mega Man'' fans. Jeremy Parish of [[1UP.com]] summated, "An oddity of the Famicom era, this import title was a simple "[[The Game of Life|''Game of Life'']]"-style board game with a ''Mega Man'' motif -- novel, but hardly essential."{{cite web | author=Parish, Jeremy | date=May 10, 2007 | title=The ''Mega Man'' Series Roundup | url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?pager.offset=0&cId=3159344 | publisher=[[1UP.com]] | accessdate=April 17, 2010}} [[GamesRadar]] editor Brett Elston called it a "probably better-off-lost excursion into Mega-mediocrity."{{cite web | author=Elston, Brett | date=June 30, 2008 | title=The ultimate ''Mega Man'' retrospective | url=http://www.gamesradar.com/f/the-ultimate-mega-man-retrospective/a-2008062794557758069/p-3 | publisher=[[GamesRadar]] | accessdate=April 17, 2010}} However, not all views of the game have been negative. JC Fletcher of [[Joystiq]] expressed desire for the game's release on the [[Wii]]'s [[Virtual Console]] service. He opined that it is "actually nowhere near as terrible as a ''Mega Man'' board game ''should'' be" and that its various effects and winning conditions grant it a much faster pace than [[Monopoly (game)|''Monopoly'']]. ==See also== * [[Fortune Street]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Japan|Video games|1990s}} *[http://www.capcom.com/ Capcom Global website] *[http://www.capcom.co.jp/rockman/ Official ''Rockman'' website] {{ja icon}} {{Mega Man series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wily and Right no RockBoard: That's Paradise}} [[Category:1993 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Cancelled Game Boy games]] [[Category:Japan-exclusive video games]] [[Category:Mega Man games]] [[Category:Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:Nintendo Entertainment System-only games]] [[Category:Board game-style video games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]]

revision.comment: removed grandparent category of [[Category:Human resource management]]
revision.text:
{{peacock|date=January 2014}}
'''Workforce modeling''' is the process by which the need for skilled workers at a particular point in time (demand) is matched directly with the availability and preference of [[skilled workers]] (supply). The resulting mathematical models may be used to perform [[sensitivity analysis]] and generate data output in the form of reports and schedules.
Due to the complexity level of building a workforce model, adoption of a workforce model is usually found in industries that have complex work rules, skilled or certified workers, medium to large teams of workers and fluctuating demand. Some examples include [[healthcare]], [[public safety]], and retail.
A workforce modeling solution can also refer to software that effectively captures all the complexity of process from start to finish and delivers complete and correct results. Components include: *[[Demand management]] – tracking the demand for skilled workers by small units of time (generally 15 or 30 minutes) *Employee availability – tracking of contractual work hour obligations and limits on an individual basis for each employee *Employee preference – tracking of preferred times and dates that employees wish to work (used to help increase [[job satisfaction]]) *[[Workflow management]] – ability for the solution to automate normally manual processes such as requesting and approving time off, requesting shift swaps, and generating and posting schedules *Optimization Engine – uses the mathematical model to create numerous schedules that are complete and correct and can be optimized on many dimensions simultaneously. The most important are cost, [[overtime]] and [[employee satisfaction]]
==Definition== For a more detailed definition, the term must be differentiated from traditional staff [[Schedule (workplace)|scheduling]]. Staff scheduling is rooted in [[time management]] and encompasses the mere administration of past and future working times. However, during the last ten to fifteen years, this traditional approach has evolved towards a demand-oriented solution which, under economic aspects, also includes changes in personnel requirements and objectives when optimizing the scheduling of staff. Besides the two core aspects of demand-orientation and optimization, workforce modeling also incorporates the forecast of the workload and the required staff, the integration of employees into the scheduling process through interactivity, the management of working times and accounts as well as analyzing and monitoring the entire process.
Workforce modeling solutions can, and should, be deployed enterprise-wide wherever complex scheduling needs or legal staffing ratios must be met. Due to the complex nature of a workforce model, creating one by hand is nearly impossible. By using a software solution for demand-oriented workforce management, planners can optimize staffing by creating schedules that at all times conform as closely as possible to the actual requirement. At the same time, a workforce modeling solution helps users to observe all relevant legislation, local agreements and the contracts with individual employees – including [[work-life balance]] guidelines.
==Complexity of model== Many workforce modeling solution applications use the more common [[linear programming]] approach to create the Workforce Model. Linear methods of achieving a schedule are generally based on assumptions that demand is based on a series of independent events, all of which have a consistent, predictable outcome.<ref name="Clancy, Thomas R. 2008">Clancy, Thomas R. ''Managing Organizational Complexity in Healthcare Operations.'' The Journal of Nursing Administration 38.9 (2008): 367-70. Print.</ref> Although this method is very common, the results are in most cases not as complete or efficient. In general, they produce a resulting schedule that is up to 75% complete and leaves the scheduler to complete the remaining shift assignments.
[[Heuristics]] have been applied to the problem and [[metaheuristics]] has been identified as the best method for generating complex scheduling solutions.<ref>Burke, Edmund, Patrick De Causmaecker, Greet Vanden Berghe, and Hendrik Van Landeghem. ''[https://lirias.kuleuven.be/bitstream/123456789/123829/1/JOS_ The State of the Art of Nurse Rostering].'' Journal of Scheduling 7.6 (2004): 441-99. Print.</ref> Using this technique, many more solutions are available to the modeling process resulting in schedules that are not only closer to 100% complete, but are also optimized to many different criteria at the same time.<ref name="Clancy, Thomas R. 2008"/>
==Notes== <references/>
==Further reading== *Sterman JD. ''Business Dynamics: Systems Thinking and Modeling For a Complex World.'' Boston, MA: McGraw-Hill Publishers; 2000. *Taleb NN. ''The Black Swan.'' New York, NY: Random House; 2007. *West B, Griffin L. ''Biodynamics: Why the Wirewalker Doesn't Fall.'' Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons Inc; 2004.

{{Infobox person | name = Yury Vyacheslavovich Molchanov
Юрий Вячеславович Молчанов | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|06|19}} | birth_place = [[Kolomna]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Russian | other_names = | occupation = Businessman and politician | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Yury Vyacheslavovich Molchanov''' ({{lang-ru|Юрий Вячеславович Молчанов}}) (born July 19, 1952, in [[Kolomna]], [[Moscow Oblast]], [[Soviet Union]]) is a [[Russia]]n businessman and politician. From 1987 to 1999, he was the Deputy [[Rector (academia)|Rector]] of [[Saint Petersburg State University]]. Since 2004 he has been the Deputy [[Governor]] of [[Saint Petersburg]]. He is the adoptive father of the [[Andrey Molchanov (businessman)|Andrey Molchanov]], the [[List of Russian billionaires by net worth|Russian billionaire]] who owns [[LSR Group]], one of Russia's largest [[construction]] firms.https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/10/billionaires08_Andrei-Molchanov_5ZJC.html ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722084423/http://www.petersburg-dialog.ru/ru/data/org/2566/document2634.shtml Biography] (in Russian) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Molchanov}} [[Category:Russian politicians]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:People from Kolomna]] {{Russia-politician-stub}} {{Russia-business-bio-stub}}
